questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a history of pelvic pain, bloating, and a recent increase in abdominal girth. On examination, she has ascites and a pelvic mass. CA-125 is elevated. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, physical findings, and elevated CA-125 are concerning for ovarian cancer. The next step is to perform a CT scan (OPTION D) of the abdomen and pelvis to assess the extent of the disease, guide surgical planning, and help with staging.

Observation (OPTION A) is not appropriate given the suspicion of malignancy.

Diagnostic laparoscopy (OPTION B) may be useful for initial assessment, but given the presence of ascites and a significant pelvic mass, an exploratory laparotomy (OPTION C) for surgical staging and debulking is typically performed after imaging.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Ovarian malignancy

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 3rd edition, Chapter 35, Epithelial Ovarian Cancer, Page no. 748-749

questions.text: ITO cells are located in the:
questions.solution:
• Ito cells reside in the perisinusoidal space (space of Disse), adjacent to hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells.
  • Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) play a crucial role in:
    • Collagen synthesis and storage
    • Liver fibrosis
    • Vitamin A storage
  • Activation of Ito cells occur in response to:
    • Chronic liver injury (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis)
    • Fatty liver disease
    • Liver fibrosis

questions.text: A 26 year old woman discovered that she was unexpectedly pregnant. She had been regularly taking an oral contraceptive medication for several years. Two months earlier, she was diagnosed with complex partial seizures and started the prescribed therapy. Which of the following drugs was she most likely taking?
questions.solution:
• Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer; can reduce efficacy of haloperidol, oral contraceptives, lamotrigine, valproate and topiramate.
  • There have been several reports of reduced efficacy of oral contraceptives in patients receiving various antiseizure drugs.
  • Carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, and felbamate have been shown to increase the metabolism of ethinyl estradiol and progestins by inducing microsomal enzymes.
  • Mnemonic
    • Enzyme inhibitors[Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]
      • Valproate
      • Ketoconazole
      • Cimetidine
      • Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin
      • Erythromycin
      • INH
    • Enzyme Inducers[GPRS Cell Phone]
      • G - Griseofulvin
      • P - Phenytoin
      • R - Rifampicin
      • S - Smoking
      • Cell - Carbamazepine
      • Phone - Phenobarbitone

Option A, B & C: This effect is not associated with other anticonvulsant drugs, including lamotrigine, valproic acid and levetiracetam

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 442

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of double vision, particularly when looking down and to the side. She reports that her symptoms worsened after a recent episode of headache. On examination, the following findings are noted:

  • Visual acuity: 20/20 in both eyes.
  • Left eye is unable to depress during adduction (noted while asking her to look down and in).
  • Right eye has a slight upward deviation when the patient is looking straight ahead.
  • No other cranial nerve deficits are observed, and the rest of the neurological examination is unremarkable.

What is the most likely underlying cause of condition?
questions.solution:
• A. Idiopathic: While idiopathic fourth nerve palsy is common, the acute onset of headache along with diplopia suggests a possible underlying cause, such as a mass lesion.
  • B. Trauma: Fourth nerve palsy can indeed be caused by trauma, but in this case, there is no history of head injury mentioned, and the sudden onset of headache raises suspicion for another cause.
  • C. Vascular ischemia: While vascular causes (like diabetic microvascular disease) can cause cranial nerve palsies, the presentation with headache and specific ocular findings leans more toward a structural lesion.

Fourth Nerve Palsy:

  1. Anatomy and Function:
    • The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, responsible for depression and intorsion of the eye.
  2. Clinical Presentation:
    • Diplopia that worsens with downward gaze or adduction of the affected eye.
    • Patients may adopt a head tilt toward the side opposite the affected eye to compensate for the misalignment.
  3. Common Causes:
    • Idiopathic: Often seen in adults without a known cause.
    • Trauma: A common cause in younger individuals, including sports injuries.
    • Vascular ischemia: Common in older patients, often associated with diabetes or hypertension.
    • Intracranial mass lesions: Tumors or hemorrhages affecting the posterior cranial fossa can compress the trochlear nerve.
  4. Management:
    • Addressing the underlying cause (if identified).
    • Prism glasses may be prescribed to alleviate diplopia.
    • Surgical intervention may be considered for persistent cases or significant misalignment.

References: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th ed, Chapter 9, Cranial Nerve Palsies, pg 300.

questions.text: A previously well 5-year-old boy presents with recent onset of abdominal pain and diarrhea (that has contained blood on several occasions). A stool culture is subsequently positive for Shiga like toxin-producing Escherichia coli O157:H7. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Most children with diarrhea caused by Shiga like toxin-producing E. coli O157:H7 (EHEC) should be treated only with fluid replacement and not an antimicrobial agent.
  • Patients treated with an antimicrobial for hemorrhagic colitis caused by EHEC are at greater risk of developing hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) as its use can increase the toxin production.
  • TMP/SMX is drug of choice for EIEC, ETEC and EPEC. (Option D)
  • Option A and C are not commonly used in these infections.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1514

questions.text: MRI uses the property of which atom's resonance in the body to produce images?
questions.solution:
Protons, specifically the hydrogen protons found in water molecules, play a crucial role in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Since the human body is composed largely of water, and each water molecule contains hydrogen atoms (which have a single proton), these protons become the basis for creating MRI images.

Protons have a property called spin, which makes them behave like tiny bar magnets with a north and south pole. In the absence of a strong magnetic field, these proton spins are randomly oriented.

When a person is placed inside the MRI scanner, which contains a strong magnetic field (often 1.5 to 3 Tesla), the magnetic field forces the protons to align either parallel (low energy state) or anti-parallel (high energy state) to the direction of the magnetic field.

A slight majority of protons align with the magnetic field, creating a small but detectable net magnetization along the direction of the field.

Incorrect Options: A, B and D

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Protons, specifically the hydrogen protons found in water molecules, play a crucial role in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Since the human body is composed largely of water, and each water molecule contains hydrogen atoms (which have a single proton), these protons become the basis for creating MRI images

Reference: MRI made easy, second edition, page no 1

questions.text: A 74-year-old gentleman came with complaints of occasional body pain and forward bending posture. His dorso-lumbar spine x-ray lateral view showed codfish vertebrae. All these drugs can be used to treat him except:
questions.solution:
Cod Fish Vertebrae in Osteoporosis:

  • Characterized by biconcave vertebrae with anterior wedging, leading to anterior bowing of the upper body.
  • Commonly seen in elderly people with osteoporosis.

Medical Treatment of Osteoporosis:

  1. High Protein Diet:
    • Helps in increasing the formation of the organic matrix of the bone, especially in malnourished elderly patients.
  2. Calcium Supplementation:
    • Role is uncertain but may be beneficial in cases of dietary calcium deficiency.
  3. Androgens:
    • Anabolic effect on the bone's protein matrix; may reduce symptoms in some patients.
  4. Estrogens:
    • Prevents progressive loss of bone mass in postmenopausal osteoporosis.
  5. Vitamin D:
    • Increases calcium absorption from the gut when given with other treatments.
  6. Fluoride:
    • Under study; believed to increase bone crystallinity, reducing bone resorption.
  7. Bisphosphonates (e.g., Alendronate, Zoledronate): (Option B)
    • Taken on an empty stomach; intravenous options available. Common side effect is oesophagitis.
  8. Calcitonin: (Option A)
    • Administered parenterally; helps build bone mass and provides analgesic effects.
  9. Teriparatide: (Option D)
    • Recombinant Parathyroid Hormone (PTH); acts as an anabolic agent, promoting new bone formation.
  10. Denosumab:
    • A newly developed immunomodulator; acts as an antiresorptive agent to prevent bone loss.

Note: (Option C) Omalizumab: It is an anti-IgE monoclonal antibody used in asthma ,which is approved for patients of >12 years of age. It is given subcutaneously. It is not used for osteoporosis treatment. Instead, Denosumab is the recommended immunomodulator for osteoporosis.

General orthopaedics/Osteoporosis/Must know

Tag: Easy

Reference: J. Maheshwari's, 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page no. 309

questions.text:
A 50 year old male presents with sense of lump in the lumbar area. Evaluation confirms the diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. History reveals that his father had an intracranial hemorrhage at the age of 55 years and was diagnosed to have adult onset polycystic kidney disease.
Which of the following investigations is recommended in this male patient as part of work up?
questions.solution:
Patients of ADPKD with family history of intracranial aneurysm and rupture are at significantly increased risk of aneurysm rupture and they need screening with MR angiography even at asymptomatic stage.

  • Intracranial aneurysm (ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in ADPKD patients than in the general population and causes high mortality. A family history of ICA is a risk factor of aneurysm rupture in ADPKD; whether hypertension and cigarette smoking are independent risk factors is not clear.
  • The role of radiologic screening for ICA in asymptomatic patients with ADPKD remains unclear. ADPKD patients with a positive family history of ICAs may undergo presymptomatic screening of ICAs by MR angiography.
  • Other vascular abnormalities in ADPKD patients include diffuse arterial dolichoectasias of the anterior and posterior cerebral circulation, which can predispose to arterial dissection and stroke.
  • A. Contrast MRI abdomen is not relevant in this case.
  • B. Although NCCT Brain is used for diagnosis of Subarachnoid hemorrhage, it is not used for screening of aneurysm.
  • C. Other cardiac abnormalities include Mitral valve prolapse, insufficiency of mitral, aortic and tricuspid valves. These conditions may require screening by Echocardiography, not ECG.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 2352

questions.text: Child presented with growth Retardation and recurrent attacks of Hypoglycemia. His face is like doll and extremities are thin. Hepatomegaly is present. Increased Level of Lactic acid and uric acid seen. All of the following complications can be expected in the child except
questions.solution:
Above clinical case scenario is suggestive of Glycogen storage Disorder most probably Von Gierke Disease. Deficiency of Enzyme Glucose 6 phosphatase is present. Clinical Symptoms including Severe Fasting Hypoglycemia.

Purine overproduction and hyperuricemia in von Gierke disease (glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency) occurs secondary to enhanced generation of the PRPP precursor ribose 5-phosphate. An associated lactic acidosis elevates the renal threshold for urate, elevating total body urates.

Cardiomyopathy is complication occurred in Pompe Disease not in von Gierke Disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, chapter 18, Page 174

questions.text: A 45 year old female brought to medicine department seeking treatment for acute uric acid nephropathy. The disorder is characterized by the acute overproduction of uric acid. Which of the following agent can be best used to prevent extreme hyperuricemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Acute hyperuricemia, which often occurs in patients who are treated with cytotoxic drugs for neoplastic disorders, can lead to the deposition of urate crystals in the kidneys and their collecting ducts.
  • This can produce partial or complete obstruction of the collecting ducts, renal pelvis, or ureter.
  • Allopurinol and its primary metabolite, alloxanthine, are inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, an enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid.
  • The use of allopurinol in patients at risk can markedly reduce the likelihood that they will develop acute uric acid nephropathy.
  • Allopurinol (hypoxanthine analog) and recently approved drug, febuxostat (a non-purine drug) decrease the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase.

Flowchart Showing synthesis and inhibition of uric acid synthesis:

Option A, B & D: All other options are not associated with decrease uric acid levels as allopurinol hence they cannot be used.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 235

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with dysuria, frequency, and urgency for the past 3 days. She has no fever, flank pain, or history of urinary tract infections. A urine dipstick shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and urine dipstick findings are consistent with uncomplicated cystitis.

OPTION A: The recommended treatment is a short course of oral antibiotics, such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 3 days.

OPTION B: Urine culture is not routinely required in uncomplicated cases unless the patient has recurrent infections or risk factors for multidrug-resistant organisms.

OPTION C: Intravenous antibiotics and hospitalization are not necessary for uncomplicated cystitis.

OPTION D: Increased fluid intake and cranberry juice can be adjunctive but are not first-line treatments for active infection.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Urinary Tract Infections

Reference: www.ncbi.com

choices.text: Inhibition of folate metabolism leading to mitochondrial dysfunction
Direct axonal toxicity from metabolite accumulation

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with progressive visual loss over the past three months. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and is being treated with methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine. Additionally, she reports significant weight loss and fatigue over the same period. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. Color vision testing reveals severe red-green color deficits. Fundoscopic examination is as shown.

Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which her medications may have contributed to her optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
• B. Accumulation of retinal toxic metabolites: While drug-induced retinal toxicity can occur, the specific medications listed do not primarily operate through this mechanism to cause optic neuropathy.
  • C. Immune-mediated optic nerve inflammation: This is characteristic of optic neuritis, typically seen in demyelinating diseases, and does not apply to the mechanism of action of methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine.
  • D. Direct axonal toxicity from metabolite accumulation: Although methotrexate can be toxic, the more relevant mechanism in this context involves its effect on folate metabolism rather than direct axonal toxicity.

Drug-Induced Toxic Optic Neuropathy:

  1. Commonly Associated Drugs:
    • Methotrexate: Can inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, leading to decreased folate levels, which is crucial for neuronal health.
    • Hydroxychloroquine: Typically associated with retinal toxicity but can also lead to optic neuropathy in rare cases, particularly with long-term use.
  2. Clinical Features:
    • Visual Acuity Changes: Patients often report progressive loss of vision; acuity may drop significantly.
    • Color Vision Deficits: Red-green color vision is often affected, indicating optic nerve involvement.
    • Fundoscopic Findings: Bilateral optic disc pallor suggests optic nerve damage.
  3. Investigations:
    • Visual Field Testing: May reveal central or cecocentral scotomas.
    • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Can assess retinal nerve fiber layer thickness and detect early damage.
    • Serum Folate and Vitamin Levels: Evaluating for deficiencies that might contribute to the neuropathy.
  4. Management:
    • Discontinuation of the Offending Agents: Critical to prevent further damage to the optic nerve.
    • Nutritional Support: Supplementation with folate and other vitamins as indicated.
    • Monitoring: Regular follow-up to assess for recovery of visual function.

#optic neuropathy #pale disc #causes of optic neuropathy

References: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th ed, Chapter 12, Toxic Optic Neuropathies, pg 490.

questions.text: Maddrey discriminant factor is used for severity assessment of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
The Maddrey Discriminant Function (MDF) is used to assess the severity of alcoholic hepatitis and to help determine the need for corticosteroid therapy. The formula for calculating the MDF is

MDF=4.6×(PT-PTcontrol)+Bilirubin

Where:

  • PT = Prothrombin time (in seconds)
  • PTcontrol = Prothrombin time of the control sample (usually expressed in seconds)
  • Bilirubin = Serum bilirubin level (in mg/dL)

A MDF score of 32 or higher typically indicates severe alcoholic hepatitis and may suggest the need for corticosteroid treatment.

Options A,C,D are not related to this score.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 2618

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G1P0, at 36 weeks of gestation, presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of hypertension but no liver disease. On examination, she is hypertensive (BP 160/100 mmHg), and her labs show elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, and hemolysis on peripheral smear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy:

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy typically presents with severe symptoms, including right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, elevated liver enzymes, and often hypoglycemia. However, it generally occurs earlier in pregnancy (usually after 30 weeks) and is less commonly associated with the severe hypertension and hemolysis seen in this case.

OPTION B) HELLP syndrome:

HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets. The patient's elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, and hemolysis, combined with severe hypertension and right upper quadrant pain, are consistent with HELLP syndrome.

OPTION C) Severe preeclampsia:

Severe preeclampsia is characterized by severe hypertension and organ dysfunction. While it can present with elevated liver enzymes and right upper quadrant pain, HELLP syndrome is a more specific diagnosis that encompasses these findings along with thrombocytopenia and hemolysis.

OPTION D) Acute cholecystitis:

Acute cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and possibly elevated liver enzymes, but it is less likely to cause severe hypertension and significant hemolysis or thrombocytopenia. The lack of gallbladder findings and specific laboratory findings makes this diagnosis less likely.

Given the presence of severe hypertension, elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, hemolysis, and right upper quadrant pain, HELLP syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

Type: Must know

Topic: HELLP syndrome

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics, 9th edition, Chapter 18, Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, Page no. 263

questions.text: A 20-year-old female was trapped in a closed small bunker. She is having claustrophobia (fear of closed spaces). Patient has blurred vision, dizziness, lightheadedness. She has panic attack. Most likely cause of patient's symptoms is
questions.solution:
• Patient has panic attack and hyperventilation also.
  • Option b: Decreased PCO2 in the arteries leads to excessive exhalation of CO2. This causes a decrease in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) in the blood.
  • The reduced CO2 levels cause cerebral vasoconstriction (narrowing of the blood vessels in the brain), leading to reduced blood flow to the brain and subsequent symptoms like dizziness and blurred vision.
  • Option a: In this case hyperventilation causes fall in arterial PCO2 causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Option c: In the case of a panic attack, the primary physiological change is hyperventilation, which increases oxygen intake while reducing CO2 PO2 tension rises in this case.
  • Option d: Hyperventilation associated with a panic attack; blood lactate levels do not usually decrease. It does not produce above mentioned symptoms.

Tag: Regulation of respiration

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 26th edition, pg no. 1511

questions.text: All of the following structures are passing deep to the flexor retinaculum, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The flexor retinaculum (transverse carpal ligament):

  • It is a strong fibrous band which bridges the anterior concavity of carpus and converts it into an Osseo fibrous tunnel called carpal tunnel for the passage of flexor tendons of the digits.
  • The flexor retinaculum is rectangular and is formed due to thickening of the deep fascia in front of carpal bones.
  • Attachments
    • Medially: It is attached to the pisiform and the hook of hamate.
    • Laterally: It is attached to the tubercle of scaphoid and the crest of trapezium.
  • Structures passing superficial to flexor retinaculum
    • Ulnar nerve and vessels
    • Palmar cutaneous branch of ulnar nerve
    • Tendon of palmaris longus
    • Palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve
    • Superficial palmar branch of radial artery
  • Structures passing deep to the flexor retinaculum (through carpal tunnel)
    • Four tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS)
    • Four tendons of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)
    • Tendon of flexor pollicis longus (FPL)
    • Median nerve
    • Radial and ulnar bursas

Topic: The palm

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Volume-1, Page No - 140, 141

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a large, rapidly growing vulvar mass. Biopsy reveals vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most important prognostic factor for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most important prognostic factor in vulvar squamous cell carcinoma is lymph node involvement (Option D). This factor significantly influences the overall survival and prognosis of the patient. The presence of metastatic spread to the inguinal or pelvic lymph nodes dramatically worsens the prognosis and is associated with a higher risk of recurrence and lower survival rates.

OPTION A: Size of the Tumor: While tumor size is important, it is not as predictive of outcomes as lymph node status.

OPTION B: Histological Grade: The histological grade can provide some prognostic information, but it is not as impactful as lymph node involvement.

OPTION C: Depth of Invasion: The depth of invasion is also an important factor, particularly in early-stage disease, but again, it does not outweigh the impact of lymph node involvement.

Therefore, lymph node status is the most significant prognostic indicator in vulvar squamous cell carcinoma, guiding the treatment approach and informing the prognosis.

Type: May know

Topic: Vulvar cancer

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 3rd edition, Chapter 31, Vulvar Cancer, Page no. 684

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient with south India origin presented with complain of nasal obstruction and red polypoidal mass with white dots arising from nasal cavity. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Rhinosporidiosis. It is a granulomatous condition developing due to a protozoan infection Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is commonly seen in lakes and ponds of south India. It develops in healthy and immunocompetent individuals.
  • Clinical features: It presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis and reddish polypoidal mass with strawberry white dots on anterior rhinoscopy. It also shows cutaneous nodules.
  • Biopsy shows presence of sporangia. Russel's body is a histological feature of rhinoscleroma and not of rhinosporidiosis.
  • Management: wide local excision with cauterization of base is the treatment of choice. Oral dapsone is used post operatively.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 185-186.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as Kanavel's cardinal sign?
questions.solution:
• Pyogenic Flexor Tenosynovitis (FTS)
  • Definition: Infection of the flexor tendon sheath.
  • Etiology:
    • Can occur in a delayed fashion after penetrating trauma.
    • Common Pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (most common).
  • Kanavel Signs (Four classic signs):
    1. Flexed resting posture of the digit. (Option D)
    2. Fusiform swelling of the digit. (Option A)
    3. Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath.
    4. Pain with passive extension of the digit. (Option B)
  • Treatment Approaches:
    • Early Treatment:
      • Hospital admission.
      • Splinting of the affected digit.
      • Intravenous (IV) antibiotics.
      • Close observation.
      • If signs improve within the first 24 hours, surgery may be avoided.
    • Late Treatment:
      • Incision and drainage of the flexor tendon sheath.
      • Techniques:
        • Open Drainage: Long mid-axial or Bruner incision.
        • Closed-Catheter Irrigation (CCI):
          • Two small incisions: one distally (open A5 pulley) and one proximally (open A1 pulley).
          • Use of a pediatric feeding tube.
      • Studies show similar outcomes for open and catheter irrigation techniques.
  • Classic Horseshoe Abscess:
    • Proximal communication between the thumb and small finger flexor tendon sheaths in the Parona space (potential space between the pronator quadratus (PQ) and flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendons).
  • Postoperative Care:
    • Aggressive hand therapy is essential to prevent tendon adhesions and digital stiffness.

Musculoskeletal infections/Good to know

Tag: Moderate

Reference: Miller's, 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1588

questions.text: ANM ensures the registrations of the pregnancy from her area for tracking down the pregnancies with the help of ASHA's and AWW's. How many pregnancies should be registered in any month by the ANM if the birth rate of India is 16 per 1000 population and the population under ANM is 5000.
questions.solution:
• To know the expected number of pregnancies registered with ANM in any month, we first have to calculate the number of expected pregnancies in a year. As a thumb rule, in any given month, approximately half the number of pregnancies estimated per year should be in records.
  • The ANM must know the population size and birth rate of the area under her jurisdiction. The expected number of live births (Y) may be calculated by Birth rate/1000 population*population of area/1000
  • As some pregnancies may not result in a live birth (abortions and still birth), the expected number of live births would be an under-estimation of the total number of pregnancies. Hence a correction factor of 10% is required. So, the total number of expected pregnancies per year (Z) = Y + 10% Of Y.
  • In above case Y= 16*5000/1000, that will come 88, and as a rule half a number of that, that is 44 pregnancies should be registered by ANM in any month.

Reference: - Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.600.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of excessive tearing and yellowish discharge from the left eye since birth. The parents have noticed intermittent matting of the eyelashes, especially after naps. There is no history of eye redness or trauma. On examination, the infant's left eye has mild conjunctival injection and a positive regurgitation test from the puncta when pressure is applied to the lacrimal sac. Fluorescein dye disappearance test confirms delayed clearance in the left eye. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• A. Immediate probing under anesthesia: Probing is a treatment option for nasolacrimal duct obstruction, but it is usually reserved for children older than 12 months who fail to respond to conservative management. In infants younger than one year, most cases resolve spontaneously with non-invasive treatments like massage.
  • B. Topical antibiotic therapy: Antibiotics are typically prescribed for acute dacryocystitis or secondary bacterial infections. In this case, the patient does not have signs of infection (e.g., redness, swelling, or fever), so antibiotics alone are not sufficient for managing congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO).
  • D. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): This surgical procedure is usually performed in adults with chronic nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In children, DCR is not indicated unless all other treatments, including probing, balloon catheter dilation, or intubation, have failed.

NOTE:

This is the first-line treatment for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) in infants.

  • Massage of the nasolacrimal sac (Crigler's massage) helps to increase pressure in the lacrimal system and may facilitate spontaneous opening of the membranous obstruction at the valve of Hasner.
  • It is recommended to perform the massage several times a day, and most cases resolve spontaneously by the age of 1 year.

Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction (NLDO):

  1. Clinical Features
    • Epiphora (Excessive tearing): Constant or intermittent watery eye since birth due to the obstruction at the nasolacrimal duct.
    • Mucopurulent discharge: Yellowish discharge can occur, especially in the morning, due to stagnant tears becoming secondarily infected.
    • Crusting of eyelashes: Commonly seen after naps due to the accumulation of mucopurulent material.
    • Positive regurgitation test: When pressure is applied to the lacrimal sac, reflux of tears or mucopurulent material through the puncta is suggestive of a blocked nasolacrimal duct.
  2. Investigations:
    • Fluorescein dye disappearance test: This test involves placing fluorescein dye in the conjunctival sac and observing how quickly it clears. Delayed clearance suggests impaired drainage due to nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
    • Probing and irrigation: These are usually performed as a therapeutic and diagnostic procedure after the age of 12 months if conservative management fails. It helps confirm the exact site of obstruction.
  3. Management of NLDO in children:
    1. Initial Diagnosis & Conservative Management
      • Age of Onset: Typically congenital
      • Symptoms: Persistent tearing, discharge, recurrent conjunctivitis
      • Conservative Measures:
        • Lacrimal Sac Massage (Crigler's Maneuver): Performed several times a day for the first few months of life
        • Topical Antibiotics: Only if associated with mucopurulent discharge
      • Monitoring: Spontaneous resolution expected in 90% of cases by 12 months of age
    2. Failure of Conservative Treatment by Age 12 Months
      • Probing of Nasolacrimal Duct (First-line Intervention)
        • Performed under anesthesia
    3. Persistent NLDO after Probing
      • Re-Probing or Balloon Catheter Dilation
        • Indicated if probing fails (considered in children >2 years)
        • Balloon catheter dilation or probing under more controlled conditions
      • Intubation with Silicone Tubes: In recurrent cases or failed dilation
    4. Surgical Management for Severe/Persistent NLDO
      • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)
        • Rare in children but considered in cases of failed conservative and interventional management

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2016. p. 477.

questions.text: Which of the following media is specifically designed as selective for isolating Leptospira species?
questions.solution:
Leptospira is a spirochete that causes leptospirosis.

Transmission:

  • Primarily transmitted through contact with water, soil, or food contaminated with the urine of infected animals (especially rodents, cattle, dogs, and pigs).
  • Humans become infected when the bacteria enter through broken skin or mucous membranes (eyes, nose, mouth).

Reservoir Hosts:

  • Rats and other rodents are common reservoir hosts and can shed the bacteria in their urine for long periods without showing symptoms.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Biphasic disease:
    • Acute (Leptospiremic) phase: Sudden onset of fever, headache, myalgia (particularly calf pain), conjunctival suffusion, and vomiting.
    • Immune phase: Appears after a brief asymptomatic period and can involve meningitis, jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, and other systemic complications.
  • Weil's Disease: Severe form of leptospirosis characterized by jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, and sometimes pulmonary hemorrhage.
  • Pulmonary Leptospirosis: Can cause severe haemoptysis and respiratory failure.

Diagnosis:

  • Serology: Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard. ELISA can also detect antibodies.
  • PCR: Can detect leptospiral DNA in blood or urine during early infection.
  • Culture: Leptospira can be cultured from blood or urine, but it is slow and requires EMJH media.
  • Direct Observation: Dark-field microscopy can sometimes be used to detect Leptospira in fluid samples.

Treatment:

  • Antibiotics: Doxycycline or Penicillin are the first-line treatments. Ceftriaxone or Azithromycin may also be used.

  • A. Blood Agar Plate: Incorrect. Blood Agar Plate is a general-purpose medium that supports the growth of a wide variety of bacteria but is not selective for Leptospira.
  • B. Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) Medium: Correct. EMJH medium is specifically designed for the isolation and cultivation of Leptospira species. It contains nutrients and inhibitors to support the growth of Leptospira while inhibiting other microorganisms.
  • C. MacConkey Agar: Incorrect. MacConkey Agar is selective for Gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric bacteria like E. coli and Salmonella. It is not used for isolating Leptospira.
  • D. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Incorrect. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is used for the isolation of fungi and yeast, not for Leptospira.

Key Takeaway: EMJH (Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris) Medium is a selective medium specifically designed for the isolation and growth of Leptospira species.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Leptospirosis: Laboratory Diagnosis." CDC Leptospirosis Page. Accessed August 30, 2024.

questions.text: Deficiency of complement components -C5,C6,C7,C8,C9 predispose to infection by which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
• C56789(aka Membrane attack complex) is involved in lysis of external microorganisms.

Deficiencies of any complement component involved in the lytic phase (C5, C6, C7, C8, and, to a lesser extent, C9) predispose affected individuals to systemic infection by Neisseria. This is explained by the critical role of complement in the lysis of the thick cell wall possessed by this class of bacteria.

Complement deficiencies are conditions where parts of the complement system, which is a crucial component of the immune response, are missing or not functioning properly. Here's a list of key complement deficiencies:

  1. C1 Inhibitor Deficiency:
    • Hereditary Angioedema (Type I and II)
  2. C3 Deficiency:
    • Increases susceptibility to severe bacterial infections, particularly with encapsulated bacteria.
  3. C5-C9 Deficiencies:
    • Terminal Complement Component Deficiencies: Lead to increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections, such as gonorrhea and meningitis.
  4. C1q, C1r, C1s Deficiencies:
    • Associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and increased susceptibility to infections.
  5. C2 Deficiency:
    • Increases susceptibility to infections and can also be associated with autoimmune diseases like SLE.
  6. C4 Deficiency:
    • Often associated with SLE and increased risk of infections.
  7. Factor H Deficiency:
    • Associated with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS) and increased risk of kidney damage.
  8. Factor I Deficiency:
    • Leads to a predisposition to infections and can be associated with aHUS.
  9. Properdin Deficiency:
    • Increases susceptibility to infections, particularly with Neisseria species.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2693

questions.text: A male infant is born at an estimated gestational age of 34 weeks. His measurements at birth are: weight- 1,200 g (<10th percentile); length- 40 cm (10th percentile); and head circumference: 31.5 cm (50th percentile). Of the following, the MOST likely explanation for the growth pattern of this infant is
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has asymmetrical growth retardation. Weight and length are affected with head spared (head sparing effect).
  • Causes of asymmetrical IUGR are the ones causing placental insufficiency. This includes PIH, maternal medical diseases.
  • Gestational diabetes causes macrosomia. (Option c)
  • Chromosomal abnormality and congenital viral infection cause symmetrical IUGR. (Option a, b)
  • Following are the differences between symmetrical and asymmetrical IUGR:

Reference: Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th ed., pg. 155

questions.text: During a routine psychiatric evaluation, a 30-year-old male patient is observed to display unusual motor symptoms. The examiner attempts to move his arms, there is a noticeable resistance initially and then the examiner is able to move the arms freely and makes the patient come in a position as shown in the image below and slowly the arms of the patients come down. Which of the following terms best describes the patient's behavior?
questions.solution:
• Waxy flexibility is a motor symptom commonly observed in patients with catatonic features of schizophrenia. It is characterized by the feeling of resistance encountered when attempting to move the patient's limbs or body into different positions. The patient's body seems to exhibit a pliable and moldable quality, similar to the bending of a wax candle. Waxy flexibility is a passive phenomenon, meaning the resistance is felt when the examiner tries to move the patient's body.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Catalepsy

  • Catalepsy refers to maintaining an odd posture for an extended period of time. It is a passive phenomenon where the patient maintains the posture in response to external instructions, such as the examiner asking the patient to hold a particular position. Catalepsy does not involve the feeling of resistance encountered during movement, as seen in the described scenario.

Option B - Posturing

  • Posturing is similar to catalepsy in that it involves maintaining an odd posture for an extended duration. However, posturing is an active phenomenon where the patient spontaneously assumes the posture without external instructions. In the described scenario, the patient complies with the examiner's request, suggesting a response to external instruction rather than spontaneous posturing.

Option D - Negativism

  • Negativism refers to the patient's opposition or lack of response to instructions. It is characterized by a resistance to comply with commands or a tendency to do the opposite of what is requested. While negativism can be observed in patients with catatonic features, it does not specifically describe the motor symptoms mentioned in the scenario.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry - 12th Edition - Page no 3556

questions.text: A 20 years old male with chronic diarrhoea presents for evaluation. History is suggestive of small bowel diarrhoea. He also gives history of vesicular skin rash. Evaluation shows serum IgA tissue transglutaminase is positive. Biopsy of the skin lesion shows IgA deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis of skin lesion?
questions.solution:
History of small intestinal diarrhea and IgA TTG confirms the diagnosis of Celiac disease.


Fig. Extraintestinal features of Celiac Disease

  • Patients with celiac disease have a higher incidence of other autoimmune disorders such as type 1 diabetes mellitus and autoimmune thyroid disease as well as extraintestinal manifestations (Refer to picture above). Dermatitis herpetiformis, one of the common extraintestinal features, is a skin disorder that is highly associated with celiac disease, characterized by a vesicular rash mediated by IgA deposits in the skin

Diagnosis:

  • Screening: Test for serum antibodies (tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin). In IgA-deficient patients, use deamidated anti-gliadin IgG or tissue transglutaminase IgG.
  • Confirmation: In adults with positive antibody levels, confirm diagnosis via endoscopy with small-intestinal biopsy, which typically shows villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.

The Marsh classification categorizes different types of celiac disease related lesions and is currently used to quantify severity of disease involvement.

  • A,B,D: These conditions are not relevant in this case.

Refeence: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2463

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with primary infertility. His semen analysis shows azoospermia. Testicular biopsy reveals normal spermatogenesis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. Obstructive azoospermia (Correct Answer)

Obstructive azoospermia is characterized by normal spermatogenesis within the testes, but there is a blockage in the male reproductive tract that prevents sperm from being present in the ejaculate. The presence of normal spermatogenesis on testicular biopsy and azoospermia on semen analysis indicates a blockage, making this the most likely diagnosis.

OPTION B. Non-obstructive azoospermia

Non-obstructive azoospermia is caused by impaired spermatogenesis, often due to testicular failure, hormonal imbalances, or genetic factors. In this condition, testicular biopsy would show impaired or absent spermatogenesis, which does not match the patient's finding of normal spermatogenesis on biopsy.

OPTION C. Klinefelter syndrome

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47,XXY), which leads to testicular atrophy, hypogonadism, and typically non-obstructive azoospermia with impaired spermatogenesis. A testicular biopsy in Klinefelter syndrome usually shows small, fibrotic testes with hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules, not normal spermatogenesis.

OPTION D. Testicular torsion

Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency involving twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to ischemia and testicular damage. It typically presents with acute pain and swelling rather than infertility. If severe, it can cause testicular atrophy, but it would not present with normal spermatogenesis on biopsy, making this diagnosis unlikely.

The patient's presentation of azoospermia with normal spermatogenesis on testicular biopsy is consistent with obstructive azoospermia, where a physical blockage in the reproductive tract prevents the release of sperm despite normal sperm production in the testes. Following are the different types of azoospermia:


Type: Must know

Topic: Male infertility

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 19 Evaluation of the Infertile Couple, Page no. 433

questions.text: Which of the following types of motility is associated with Treponema pallidum?
questions.solution:
• A. Darting/Vibratory Motility: Incorrect. This type of motility is observed in Vibrio and Campylobacter, not in Treponema pallidum.
  • B. Swarming Motility: Incorrect. Swarming motility is associated with Clostridium septicum, Bacillus cereus, Proteus, and some Vibrio species.
  • C. Tumbling Motility: Incorrect. Tumbling motility is characteristic of Listeria monocytogenes.
  • D. Cork-Screw Motility: Correct. Treponema pallidum exhibits cork-screw motility, which is a distinguishing feature of this bacterium.


Key Takeaway: Treponema pallidum is known for its cork-screw motility, which helps in its identification and understanding of its movement characteristics.

Tag line: Moderate

Reference: Microbiology textbooks and resources, such as "Medical Microbiology" by Murray, Rosenthal, and Pfaller.

questions.text: What is the macromolecular complex that associates with introns during mRNA splicing?
questions.solution:
The spliceosome is a large macromolecular complex that plays a crucial role in mRNA splicing, the process by which introns (non-coding regions) are removed from pre-mRNA, and exons (coding regions) are joined together to form mature mRNA.

The spliceosome is composed of small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) and associated proteins, forming small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs), which recognize and splice introns at specific sites.


Option A) Splicer and Slicer are not involved in mRNA splicing.

Option B) Dicer is involved in RNA interference and the processing of microRNAs and small interfering RNAs (siRNAs).

Option C) Nuclear body refers to a broad class of subnuclear structures, not specifically involved in splicing

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry Chapter 36 Page 400-402

questions.text: A 47-year-old female with a complaint of nervousness, palpitations and weight loss visited the doctor. She works at the hospital. With the advice of the nurse she was taking levothyroxine drug to lose the body weight. Her blood TSH levels are low. The most likely cause of low blood TSH level in this patient is
questions.solution:
• Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of thyroxine (T4). When a patient takes levothyroxine, it increases the levels of free T4 in the blood.
  • Option a: In peripheral tissues T4 is converted into T3 hormone. T3 is more potent hormone. Majority of the effect of thyroid hormone is due to active T3 hormone which is not bound to plasma protein. Free T4 does not have important role in TSH level.
  • Option b: Free T3 causes downregulation of TRH receptors in the anterior pituitary gland causing decreased level of TSH hormone.
  • Option c: T3 insensitivity refers to a rare condition where tissues are resistant to the effects of T3. If this were the case, the body would typically respond by increasing TSH levels, not decreasing them.
  • Option d: Thyroxine (T4) in the blood is mostly bound to plasma proteins like thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) and albumin. Only the free (unbound) T4 is biologically active.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - REGULATION OF THYROID HORMONES

TRH -> ⊕ TSH release -> ⊕ follicular cells. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) may ⊕ follicular cells in Graves' disease.

Negative feedback primarily by free T3/T4:

  • Anterior pituitary ↓ sensitivity to TRH
  • Hypothalamus ↓ TRH secretion

Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) binds most of the T3/T4 in blood. Bound T3/T4 = inactive.

  • ↑TBG in pregnancy, OCP use (estrogen ↑ TBG) -> ↑ total T3/T4
  • ↓TBG in steroid use, nephrotic syndrome

T3 and T4 are the only lipophilic hormones with charged amino acids and require specific transporters to diffuse into the cell (facilitated diffusion).

Tag: Thyroid hormone

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology 26th edition pg no. 837 fig. 20-8

choices.text: Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction and nasal polyps
CT showing hazy sinuses with heterogeneous opacity

questions.text: All of the following are the parts of Bent and kuhn criteria for diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis except?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis occurs in genetically predisposed individuals towards fungal allergy (atopy).

Bent and Kuhn diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis includes:

  1. Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
  2. Nasal polyps
  3. Positive fungal stain
  4. Biopsy showing fungal elements, and eosinophilic mucin or allergic mucin which is a hallmark of ARFS. Having a peanut butter appearance without invading sinus or mucosa.
  5. CT showing hazy sinuses with heterogeneous opacities.

Option D is a feature of invasive fungal infection like mucormycosis. It is not included in Bent and kuhn criteria for allergic fungal rhinitis.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 229.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of endometriosis presents with a complaint of infertility. Laparoscopy confirms the presence of deep infiltrating endometriosis. Which treatment is likely to improve her fertility?
questions.solution:
OPTION A) Oral contraceptive pills:

Oral contraceptive pills are used to manage symptoms of endometriosis by suppressing ovulation and reducing menstrual flow. While they help control pain and symptoms, they do not address the underlying lesions or improve fertility. Therefore, they are not the best option for improving fertility.

OPTION B) Surgical excision of endometriotic lesions:

Surgical excision of deep infiltrating endometriosis is aimed at removing the endometriotic lesions and can improve fertility by addressing the anatomical and functional issues caused by the disease. This approach helps to restore normal pelvic anatomy and potentially improves fertility outcomes.

OPTION C) GnRH agonists:

GnRH agonists are used to manage endometriosis by inducing a temporary menopausal state, reducing estrogen levels, and decreasing endometriotic lesions. However, they are primarily used for pain management and not directly for improving fertility. Additionally, they can cause temporary ovarian suppression, which is not ideal when trying to conceive.

OPTION D) In vitro fertilization (IVF) without surgery:

IVF is a treatment for infertility that bypasses the need for the reproductive organs to be functional. While it can be effective for achieving pregnancy in women with endometriosis, addressing the underlying endometriosis through surgical excision may improve the likelihood of IVF success and address fertility issues more comprehensively.

For a woman with deep infiltrating endometriosis (DIE) and infertility, surgical excision of endometriotic lesions is likely to improve fertility by addressing the anatomical issues and improving the chances of conception.

Type: Must know

Topic: Management of DIE

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 10 Endometriosis Page no. 240-242

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are characteristic of which of the following histological patterns?
questions.solution:
C. Papillary carcinoma:

  • Typically features psammoma bodies.
  • Seen in thyroid, ovarian, and other papillary carcinomas.


REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1088.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition in the spinal cord
questions.solution:
• Option C) Impulse generated in motor neuron activates inhibitory interneuron (Renshaw cell) to secrete inhibitory mediator which inhibit motor neuron. It is also called feedback inhibition (type of post synaptic inhibition)

  • Option A) The basket cells and Purkinje cells are both excited by the same parallel-fiber input. Stimulation of cerebellar basket cells that produces IPSPs in the Purkinje cells. It feed forward inhibition.

  • Option B) Type of inhibition which occurs in the presynaptic terminals before the signal even reaches the synapse is a presynaptic inhibition seen in gate control mechanism of pain inhibition.

Topic: Synapse- CNS

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 318 fig 6-10

questions.text: 12 years old male child was diagnosed with the appendicitis. He has undergone appendicectomy. Which of the following is the commonest position of the appendix?
questions.solution:
• Appendicitis:
    • The inflammation of the appendix is called appendicitis.
    • Acute appendicitis is a common occurrence and is a surgical emergency.
    • It commonly occurs due to obstruction of its lumen by fecaliths or edema.
  • Appendicectomy:
    • The surgical removal of appendix.
  • Position of the appendix:
    • The appendix usually lies in the right iliac fossa.
    • The base of appendix is fixed but the remaining part may occupy any of the following positions, which are often indicated with an hour hand of a clock.
    • Retrocaecal/retrocolic (12 o'clock) position:
      • The appendix passes upward behind the caecum and the ascending colon.
      • It is the commonest position (65.28%) of the appendix.
  • Splenic (2 o'clock) position:
    • The appendix passes upward and medially in front of (pre-ileal) or behind (post-ileal) the terminal part of the ileum.
    • The pre-ileal position is the most dangerous because inflammation from the appendix spreads into the general peritoneal cavity.
    • The pre-ileal position occurs in 1% of the cases and post-ileal in 0.4% of the cases.
  • Pelvic (4 o'clock) position:
    • The appendix descends downward and medially, and crosses the pelvic brim to enter the true pelvis. In females, it may be related to the right uterine tube.
    • It is the second commonest position (31.01%).
  • Midinguinal/subcaecal (6 o'clock) position:
    • The appendix passes vertically downward below the caecum (subcaecal) and points toward the inguinal ligament.
    • It occurs in 2% of the cases.

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Volume-2, Page No - 142, 143

questions.text: Identify the procedure seen in below image used for rectal prolapse
questions.solution:
Altemeier Operation (Perineal Rectosigmoidectomy):

  • Indication: Primarily used for full-thickness rectal prolapse, especially in elderly or high-risk patients.
  • Procedure:
    • The rectum and part of the sigmoid colon are resected through a perineal (anal) approach.
    • The remaining bowel is then sutured to the anus.
  • Advantages: Minimally invasive, no abdominal incision, suitable for frail patients.
  • Complications: Risk of recurrence, anastomotic leak, fecal incontinence.

Option A) :

Thiersch's operation : In this procedure, a steel wire, or silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. It has become largely obsolete owing to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis and obstructed defecation, but may be used to augment perineal repair in cases of severe pelvic floor weakness.


Option B) : Delorme Operation:

  • Indication: Used for partial or full-thickness rectal prolapse, especially in younger or healthier patients.
  • Procedure:
    • The mucosal layer of the prolapsed rectum is stripped off.
    • The muscle layer is plicated (folded and sutured) to shorten and strengthen the rectum.
  • Advantages: Minimally invasive, perineal approach, good for limited prolapse.
  • Complications: Risk of recurrence, minor complications related to wound healing.

Option D) : Ventral Mesh Rectopexy:

  • Indication: Used for rectal prolapse and pelvic floor disorders.
  • Procedure:
    • An abdominal approach is taken, usually laparoscopically.
    • A mesh is placed ventrally (anteriorly) to the rectum and secured to the sacrum to support and lift the rectum.
    • The mesh helps prevent future prolapse and corrects associated prolapse of the pelvic organs.
  • Advantages: Low recurrence rate, improves function, avoids dissection of nerves (less risk of sexual and bladder dysfunction).
  • Complications: Mesh-related issues like infection or erosion, although rare.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 79; page 1399, 1400.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old individual sustained an injury to his arm during a road traffic accident. His radiograph was taken which was as follows. Choose the possible modes of treatment in this particular case from the given options.

1. Sarmiento brace
2. ORIF with plating
3. CRIF with intra- medullary nailing
4. Figure of 8 brace/strapping
questions.solution:
A. Sarmiento brace

B. ORIF with plating

C. CRIF with intra- medullary nailing


  1. U-slab:
    • A plaster slab extending from the base of the neck over the shoulder to the lateral side of the arm and under the elbow to the medial side.
    • Moulded laterally to prevent angulation and supported with a triangular sling.
    • Removed after 6-8 weeks once the fracture heals, followed by shoulder exercises.
  2. Hanging Cast
    • Used for lower-third humerus fractures.
    • The weight of the limb and cast provides traction to keep the fracture aligned.
  3. Chest-Arm Bandage
    • Used for humerus fractures in children under five.
    • The arm is strapped to the chest, providing sufficient immobilization.
  4. Functional (Sarmiento) Brace (Option 1)
    • Used for closed humerus fractures that can be managed without surgery.
  5. Operative Methods
    • Required when closed reduction is not possible or the fracture is unstable.
  6. ORIF with plates and screws (Option 2)
    • Usually gives high union rates.
    • Allows exploration of radial nerve as well.
    • Weight-bearing tolerance is safe after plate fixation.
  7. CRIF with intramedullary nailing (Option 3)
    • Mostly used for segmental or pathologic fractures.
    • Complications include a higher rate of reoperation and shoulder pain.
    • Higher chances of nerve injury as compared to ORIF.
  8. External fixators
    • Usually reserved for open/contaminated fractures.

Option 4- Figure of 8 bandage/strapping is used to conservatively treat clavicle fractures, not humerus fractures.

Upper limb trauma/ Good to know

Tag : Moderate

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 2175

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 94

questions.text: Which fungal infection is commonly associated with immunocompromised individuals and is characterized by meningitis?
questions.solution:
• Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that causes cryptococcosis, a serious fungal infection, particularly in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with HIV/AIDS).

Transmission:

  • Acquired through the inhalation of spores found in soil, especially in areas contaminated with bird droppings, particularly pigeon droppings.
  • It is not transmitted person-to-person.

Risk Factors:

  • Immunocompromised patients: Individuals with HIV/AIDS, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., corticosteroids), and those with hematologic malignancies are at higher risk.
  • Can occur in immunocompetent individuals but is rare.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Pulmonary cryptococcosis: Presents as a pneumonia-like illness with cough, fever, and chest pain, which may be asymptomatic or mild in healthy individuals.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis: The most common and serious form, especially in HIV-positive patients. Symptoms include fever, headache, neck stiffness, nausea, and altered mental status.
  • Disseminated cryptococcosis: Can affect the skin, bones, and other organs, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Diagnosis:

  • Lumbar puncture: For suspected meningitis, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is tested for India ink staining (to detect the capsule), cryptococcal antigen test, and fungal culture. Brain biopsy is stained with mucicarmine stain.

  • Cryptococcal antigen test: Latex agglutination test detects cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen in blood or CSF. It is highly sensitive and specific.
  • Fungal culture: Can grow from blood, CSF, or other body fluids.

Appears brownish on Bird seed/ niger agar due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme


  • Chest X-ray/CT scan: May show lung nodules or infiltrates in pulmonary involvement.

Treatment:

  • Meningitis and severe infections: Treated with a combination of Amphotericin B and Flucytosine for 2 weeks, followed by long-term Fluconazole for consolidation and maintenance therapy (especially in HIV/AIDS patients).

Explanation of Other Options:

  • A. Candida albicans: Typically causes opportunistic infections but usually not meningitis.
  • B. Histoplasma capsulatum: Causes histoplasmosis, primarily affecting the lungs.
  • C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Known for causing cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
  • D. Aspergillus fumigatus: Causes aspergillosis, typically affecting the lungs rather than causing meningitis.

Key Takeaway: Cryptococcus neoformans is a key pathogen in fungal meningitis, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.

Reference: CDC Fungal Diseases. CDC - Fungal Diseases

questions.text: All of the following structures are attached to marked bone in the following diagram, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is pisiform bone.

The Pisiform:

  • Pisiform is a sesamoid bone in tendon of FCU.
  • It's Pea-shaped smallest carpal bone.
  • Oval facet for triquetral bone on the proximal part of its dorsal surface
  • The lateral surface is grooved by the ulnar nerve.
  • It is also known as 'Os centrale'.
  • Ossification: 12th year in males and 9th to 10th year in females.
    • It is last carpal bone to develop.
  • The pisiform gives:
    • Insertion to
      • Flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU)
    • Origin to
      • Flexor digiti minimi
      • Abductor digiti minimi
    • Attachment
      • Flexor retinaculum and its superficial slip
      • Extensor retinaculum

Topic: The shoulder girdle

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Volume-1, Page No - 29

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), Hematuria, Proteinuria. Serum analysis reveals Positive PR3-ANCA. Renal biopsy shows Necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wegener's granulomatosis, now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is a rare autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of the small and medium sized blood vessels (vasculitis).

Pathophysiology:

  • Immune-mediated response: GPA is associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), particularly PR3-ANCA (Proteinase 3-ANCA). These antibodies cause neutrophils to damage blood vessels, leading to vasculitis.

  • Granulomatous inflammation: The disease leads to the formation of granulomas, which are localized inflammatory responses involving immune cells. These granulomas can occur in various organs, causing localized tissue necrosis and further complicating blood flow.

Microscopic image showing features characteristic of granulomatosis with polyangiitis - a vasculitis and granulomas with multi-nucleated giant cells.

Clinical Presentation:

  1. Upper respiratory tract:
    • Chronic sinusitis, nasal crusting, and sometimes nasal septal perforation.
    • Saddle nose deformity due to cartilage destruction.

2. Lungs:

  • Cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain.
  • Pulmonary nodules or cavitating lesions seen on imaging.

3. Kidneys:

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) leading to renal failure.
  • Hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension.

4. Other systems

  • Skin: Purpura, ulcers.
  • Eyes: Scleritis, conjunctivitis.
  • Joints: Arthritis.

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a hallmark of GPA.


Option A: MPA: typically associated with MPO-ANCA, not PR3-ANCA. Unlike granulomatosis with polyangiitis, MPA typically lacks granulomatous inflammation but can cause rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

Option C: EGPA: It is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and MPO-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Goodpasture Syndrome: associated with anti-GBM antibodies, not PR3-ANCA.

Reference: Robbins & cotran, 10th edition, page no. 910.

choices.text: Low heating volume- above 2000 kcal/kg for single chamber incinerators and above 3500 kcal/kg for pyrolytic double chamber incinerators.
Content of non-combustible solids below 20% and non-combustible fines below 5%.

questions.text: Anatomical and cytotoxic wastes are treated by the process of incineration which is a high temperature dry oxidation process. There are certain characteristics of the waste suitable for incineration, all of the following characteristics are true except?
questions.solution:
• Incineration is a high temperature dry oxidation process that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic and incombustible.
  • Incineration requires no pretreatment.

Characteristics of waste material to be incinerated are: -

  • Heating volume - above 2000kcal/kg for single chamber incineration and 3500kcal/kg for pyrolytic double chamber incinerators.
  • Content of combustible matter above 60%.
  • Content of non-combustible solids below 5%.
  • Content of non-combustible fine below 20%.
  • Moisture content below 30%.

Reference: - Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.916.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea for 6 months after discontinuing oral contraceptives. Her BMI is 18, and she is a regular sportsperson indulged in competitive athletics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
High levels of physical activity as in this patient can predispose to hypothalamic amenorrhea.

OPTION A. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

PCOS typically presents with irregular menstrual cycles, obesity, hirsutism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. It is less likely in this patient because she is underweight (BMI 18), an athlete, and there are no signs of hyperandrogenism or polycystic ovaries mentioned.

OPTION Hypothalamic amenorrhea (Correct Answer)

Hypothalamic amenorrhea is a common cause of secondary amenorrhea, especially in women with low body weight, high levels of physical activity, stress, or eating disorders. This condition is characterized by decreased GnRH secretion due to energy deficiency, leading to low levels of LH and FSH. The patient's low BMI and involvement in competitive athletics strongly suggest hypothalamic amenorrhea.

OPTION C. Premature ovarian insufficiency

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) usually presents with secondary amenorrhea, hot flashes, and elevated FSH levels in women under 40 years of age. It is less likely in this case as there is no mention of menopausal symptoms, and the patient's history of athleticism and low BMI point towards hypothalamic causes.

OPTION D. Asherman syndrome

Asherman syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions that typically occur after uterine surgery or infection, leading to menstrual abnormalities such as amenorrhea. There is no history of surgical procedures or infections in this patient, making Asherman syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Female athlete triad

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Chapter 10 Amenorrhoea, Page no. 854

choices.text: External rotation deformity is less as compared to neck of femur fractures
Shortening is more as compared to neck of femur fractures
Hemiarthroplasty is preferred in cases above 65 years of age.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about inter-trochanteric femur fractures from the following:
questions.solution:
Intertrochanteric Femur Fractures:

  • Definition: A type of fracture that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanters of the femur.
  • Common in: Elderly individuals, typically over 60 years of age, with a higher incidence in males.
  • Cause: Often results from a significant trauma, such as a fall.
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe pain in the hip region.
    • Inability to bear weight or walk.
    • Swelling and ecchymosis (bruising) around the hip.
    • External rotation deformity of the leg (greater than 45°). (Option A)
    • Noticeable shortening of the affected limb (more than 1 inch). (Option B)
  • Physical Exam Findings:
    • Tenderness over the greater trochanter.
    • Severe swelling around the hip area.
  • Treatment:
    • Primarily surgical, involving internal fixation using a dynamic hip screw or intramedullary nail.
    • Non-surgical management with traction may be considered in non-ambulatory patients or those with significant comorbidities.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion (improper healing of the fracture). (Option C)
    • Postoperative infections, especially in elderly patients with other health issues.
  • Prognosis: Generally favorable with proper surgical intervention, but recovery depends on the patient's overall health and rehabilitation efforts.

Option D - Hemiarthroplasty is preferred in cases above 65 years of age in cases of neck femur fractures due to higher risk of non-union/AVN of femoral head.

Lower limb trauma/Must know

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 138

questions.text: Dilute Russel viper venom test is used for detection of which of the following antibody?
questions.solution:
Lupus anticoagulant,the most specific antibody associated with APLA can be detected indirectly by the prolongation of :

  • aPTT
  • Aptt
  • DRVVT(Diluted Russel Viper Venom Test)
  • KCT(Kaolin Clotting Time)

The important antibodies involved in APLA are:


A. Although Anticardiolipin antibody is involved, it is detected via ELISA and not by the test mentioned in the question.

B. Anticentromere antibody is associated with CREST syndrome (limited systemic sclerosis), and hence not related.

C. Anti beta 2 glycoprotein antibody is also an antibody associated with APLA syndrome but is not detected by the test mentioned.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2749

choices.text: Le fort 1 fracture runs through the root of nose, lacrimal bone, floor of orbit, upper part of maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
It presents with malocclusion of teeth with elongation of mid face
Surgical fixation of fracture by interdental wiring, open reduction and interdental wiring, wiring slings.
Le fort 3 fracture there is complete separation of facial bones from the cranial bones.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient developed injury over face due to a road traffic accident. His CT scan was suggestive of fracture of maxilla. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Fractures of maxilla are classified into three types :

Le fort 1 : Fracture runs above and parallel to the palate. It crosses nasal septum, maxillary sinus.

Le fort 2 : aka pyramidal fracture. fracture runs through the root of nose, lacrimal bone, floor of orbit, upper part of maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates.

Le fort 3 : There is complete separation of facial bones from cranial bones. The fracture line passes through the root of nose, ethmoidal frontal junction, superior orbital fissure.

Clinical features:

  • malocclusion of teeth with anterior open bite
  • elongation of mid face
  • mobility in the maxilla.
  • CSF rhinorrhoea.(in Le Fort 2 and 3)

Management: Fixation of maxillary fractures can be achieved by

  • Interdental wiring
  • Intermaxillary wiring
  • Open reduction and interosseous wiring
  • Wiring slings from frontal bone, zygoma or infraorbital rim.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 215- 216.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male is experiencing polyuria and polydipsia. He lost his weight recently. There is fruity smell in urine. Which of following points describes the acid-base status?
questions.solution:
• Above mentioned symptoms suggest patient is having diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia is typical feature of diabetes.
  • Excessive production of ketone bodies leads to excretion of it which produces fruity smell in urine. It produces diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • It is type of metabolic acidosis.
  • In this case PH and bicarbonate level are less than normal.
  • Point B refers to respiratory acidosis
  • Point C refers to the normal acid base status of normal healthy individual.
  • Point A refers to metabolic alkalosis.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1008,1477

questions.text: A 5 year old boy with mild development delay is brought for evaluation. Evaluation shows hypokalaemia, metabolic alkalosis, normal serum magnesium and high urinary calcium. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Barter syndrome (also known as Bartter syndrome) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the kidneys.

It is characterized by problems with the kidney's ability to reabsorb sodium, which leads to excessive loss of salt and water. This, in turn, can result in

  • Low levels of potassium (hypokalemia),
  • Elevated levels of renin and aldosterone (hormones that regulate blood pressure and electrolytes),
  • And metabolic alkalosis (an imbalance in the body's pH).

Bartter syndrome and Gitelman Syndrome are salt-wasting renal disease associated with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis and hyperreninemic hyperaldosteronism.

Liddle Syndrome:

  • Liddle syndrome is an inherited form of low-renin hypertension, transmitted with an autosomal dominant pattern,associated with a gain of function(GOF) mutation of ENaC channels in the collecting tubules.
  • The most common clinical presentation of the disease is early onset hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, suppressed plasma renin activity and low plasma aldosterone.
  • Consequently, treatment of Liddle syndrome is based on the administration of ENaC blockers, amiloride and triamterene.

Familial Hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

This condition is associated with a defect in Calcium sensing receptor(CaSR) in DCT,parathyroid gland and TAL causing low calcium excretion and hypercalcemia.

Gordon syndrome Also known as Pseudohypoaldosteronism type 2,this condition is just the reverse of Gitelman syndrome.This is associated with a gain of function mutation of Na-Cl symporter in DCT.Clinical features are: Hyperkalemia,acidosis,hypertension.(Note: Pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 is just the reverse of Liddle syndrome)

Key takeaway:

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2292

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a 6-month history of progressive bilateral vision loss, particularly worsening during night driving. He has a medical history significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and reports recent episodes of hypoglycemia. On examination, his visual acuity is 20/60 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral posterior subcapsular cataracts, with a notable snowflake appearance, and some punctate opacities in the anterior cortex.

Which of the following biochemical abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Elevated serum galactose levels: This finding would be more indicative of galactosemia, which is typically associated with congenital cataracts that present differently (e.g., not specifically posterior subcapsular) and generally in infants or young children.
  • High levels of serum copper: This is associated with Wilson's disease, which can cause corneal deposits (Kayser-Fleischer rings) rather than cataracts.
  • Elevated serum calcium: This would suggest conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism but does not correlate with the specific type of cataract presented.
  • Increased levels of serum phosphate: This is often associated with metabolic bone diseases or chronic renal failure but is not directly related to cataract formation.

Metabolic Cataracts:

Diabetes Mellitus and Sorbitol Accumulation:

  • In poorly controlled diabetes, glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase, leading to osmotic swelling of lens fibers and resulting in cataract formation.
  • The typical cataract associated with diabetes is a posterior subcapsular cataract, often described as having a “snowflake” appearance.

Other Metabolic Conditions:

  • Galactosemia: Characterized by high serum galactose, leading to cataracts, but usually not the “snowflake” type.
  • Cataracts in Wilson's Disease: Typically present with corneal deposits, not posterior cataracts.

Management:

  • Regular follow-up for diabetes management is essential, and surgical intervention may be indicated once the cataract significantly impairs vision.

References: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Chapter 8, Cataracts, p. 265.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. On examination, she has a BMI of 32 kg/m2, acanthosis nigricans, and multiple facial acne lesions. Laboratory results show elevated serum testosterone and an LH:FSH ratio of 3:1. Pelvic ultrasound reveals enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: The patient presents with features of PCOS, including oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, obesity, and biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism (elevated testosterone and LH:FSH ratio). Pelvic ultrasound findings of enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts further support the diagnosis. First-line treatment for PCOS, especially in women who do not desire pregnancy, is combined oral contraceptives to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce androgen levels, and manage symptoms like hirsutism and acne.

OPTION B: Non-classical congenital adrenal hyperplasia would present with elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels.

OPTION C: Cushing syndrome would involve specific signs like purple striae and muscle weakness.

OPTION D: Androgen-secreting tumor would typically present with rapidly progressive symptoms of virilization.

Type: Must know

Topic: PCOS

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Chapter 24 Benign diseases of the Ovary Page no. 315-316
