questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with infertility of 2 years' duration. His partner has a normal reproductive evaluation. Semen analysis reveals oligospermia and low motility. On examination, his right testis is smaller than the left. What is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. Varicocele (Correct Answer)

Varicocele is a common cause of male infertility and is characterized by dilated veins in the pampiniform plexus of the scrotum, leading to increased scrotal temperature, which can negatively affect spermatogenesis. Varicocele often results in oligospermia, low sperm motility, and testicular atrophy, which aligns with the patient's findings of smaller right testis and abnormal semen analysis.

OPTION B. Obstructive azoospermia

Obstructive azoospermia is a condition where there is a blockage in the male reproductive tract, preventing sperm from being present in the ejaculate. It typically presents with a normal semen volume but no sperm (azoospermia). Since this patient has oligospermia (reduced sperm count) and low motility, this option is less likely.

OPTION C. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition characterized by low levels of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), leading to reduced testosterone and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition usually presents with low sperm count and may be associated with small testes bilaterally. However, it does not typically cause the asymmetry in testicular size noted in this patient, making it a less likely diagnosis.

OPTION D. Retrograde ejaculation

Retrograde ejaculation occurs when semen is redirected into the bladder instead of exiting through the urethra. This condition is associated with low semen volume and the presence of sperm in the urine, not with oligospermia and low motility. Therefore, it does not match the patient's presentation.

Type: Must know

Topic: Male infertility

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 19 Evaluation of the Infertile Couple, Page no. 433

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his parents due to concerns about a white reflex in his right eye, noticed in photographs. The child has no complaints of pain or redness. Examination reveals leukocoria and strabismus. Fundoscopy shows a large, white, elevated retinal mass with areas of calcification in the posterior pole of the right eye. There is no intraocular inflammation or secondary glaucoma. An ultrasound confirms the presence of calcifications.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• Systemic corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are used for inflammatory conditions like uveitis, but they have no role in managing intraocular malignancies such as retinoblastoma.
  • Observation and follow-up: Retinoblastoma is an aggressive tumor that requires prompt intervention. Observation without treatment can lead to progression, intraocular extension, and metastasis.
  • Immediate external beam radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is generally used in advanced bilateral cases or where globe preservation is still possible. It is not indicated for unilateral disease where vision cannot be saved and the tumor threatens metastasis.

NOTE: Enucleation is the preferred treatment for advanced unilateral retinoblastoma when there is no potential to preserve useful vision, especially when the tumor occupies most of the eye and threatens to spread beyond the globe. After enucleation, histopathological examination determines whether further treatments (e.g., chemotherapy) are needed.

RETINOBLASTOMA:

Clinical Features:

  • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex): The most common presenting symptom of retinoblastoma (60% of cases), usually noted in photographs.
  • Strabismus: Misalignment of the eyes occurs in 20% of cases, often due to visual loss caused by the tumor.
  • Other symptoms: Reduced vision, secondary glaucoma (in advanced cases), or orbital cellulitis-like presentation in cases of extraocular spread.

Investigations:

  • Fundoscopy: Shows a white, elevated retinal mass with calcifications. Retinal detachment may be seen in larger tumors.
  • Ultrasound (B-scan): Confirms the presence of calcifications, which are characteristic of retinoblastoma.
  • MRI: Assesses for optic nerve involvement or extraocular spread, crucial for treatment planning.
  • Histopathology (post-enucleation): Histological examination reveals small, round, blue cells, often with Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes (specific for retinoblastoma). High-risk features include optic nerve invasion, choroidal infiltration, and scleral involvement.

Treatment:

  • Enucleation: This is the treatment of choice for large, unilateral retinoblastoma where vision preservation is unlikely, and the tumor threatens to spread beyond the eye. The removed eye is sent for histopathology to confirm the diagnosis and determine whether additional treatment, such as chemotherapy, is needed for high-risk features (e.g., optic nerve invasion).
  • Systemic chemotherapy: For bilateral disease or advanced cases, chemotherapy can be used to reduce tumor size and enable focal treatments. Common chemotherapeutic agents used include:
    • Carboplatin (primary agent).
    • Etoposide.
    • Vincristine These agents are given in multiple cycles to shrink the tumor, and subsequent focal therapies can be used for further management.

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2016. p. 682.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug has been found to reduce the progression of diabetic kidney disease by reducing intraglomerular hypertension?
questions.solution:
Sodium glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors have rapidly emerged as a novel therapy to reduce the rate of progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD). SGLT2 inhibitors trigger glucosuria, thus modestly improving glycemic control. In addition, they have pleiotropic effects, such as

  • Lowering blood sugar
    • SGLT2 inhibitors prevent the kidneys from reabsorbing sugar created by the body, which is then excreted in urine.
  • Lowering sodium levels
    • SGLT2 inhibitors reduce the amount of sodium the kidneys absorb.
  • Reducing pressure in the kidneys
    • Lowering blood sugar and sodium levels reduces pressure in the kidneys' small blood vessels, which can help prevent or slow kidney damage.
  • Improving tubuloglomerular feedback
    • SGLT2 inhibitors cause more sodium to pass along the nephron, which triggers tubuloglomerular feedback.This feedback constricts the afferent glomerular arterioles, which protects the glomeruli by reducing intraglomerular pressure.SGLT2 inhibitors are also used to manage other chronic conditions, including diabetes and heart disease.

Options A,C,D work by other mechanisms and do not have any effect on renal function as mentioned in the diagram above.

Reference: Sodium Glucose Cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors and CKD(Kidney Medicine) Anoushka Krishnan Mythri Shankar Edgar V. Lerma Nasim Wiegley

questions.text: The number of infants and children 1-5 years of age in a community, or attending a child health clinic, may be so large that it may not be possible to give sufficient time and attention to all of them, it is therefore necessary to identify at risk babies. All of the following are basic criteria for at-risk babies except.

The basic criteria for identifying at-risk babies are:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kg.
  • Twins
  • Birth order 5 and more.
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight.
  • Failure to gain weight during three successive months.
  • Children with PEM, diarrhoea.
  • Working mother/one parent.

Reference: Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.611.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with Hematuria, Flank pain, 5-cm renal mass. Biopsy reveals Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). What is the most likely genetic alteration?
questions.solution:
Clear cell renal cell carcinoma

Most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma (70-80%).

Characterized by clear cells with abundant cytoplasmic lipids and glycogen.


VHL Gene Mutation:

  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene located on chromosome 3p25-26.
  • VHL gene mutation is the most common genetic alteration in Clear cell RCC (70-80%)
  • Leads to accumulation of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF), promoting angiogenesis and tumor growth.

Pathogenesis:

  • VHL gene mutation disrupts normal ubiquitination and degradation of HIF-α.
  • HIF-α accumulation increases transcription of genes involved in angiogenesis, glucose metabolism, and cell proliferation.

Clinical Implications:

  • VHL gene mutation associated with increased risk of Clear cell RCC.
  • Germline VHL mutations can cause Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, increasing risk of multiple tumors.

Other Options:

  1. TP53 gene mutation: more commonly associated with papillary RCC and chromophobe RCC
  2. MET gene mutation: associated with papillary RCC
  3. KIT gene mutation: associated with chromophobe RCC and other tumor types

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 949.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vulvar itching and a lesion on her vulva that she noticed a few weeks ago. On examination, there is a well-demarcated white plaque on the labia majora with an atrophic, parchment-like appearance. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with clinical features suggestive of lichen sclerosus, which is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by white, atrophic plaques on the vulva.

OPTION A: The initial management involves the application of high-potency topical corticosteroids, which help reduce inflammation and symptoms such as itching and discomfort.

OPTION B: Topical antifungal therapy is not appropriate as there is no evidence of infection.

OPTION C: A biopsy is indicated if there is a suspicion of malignancy or if the lesion does not respond to initial treatment.

OPTION D: Topical estrogen therapy is used for vulvovaginal atrophy associated with menopause, not for lichen sclerosus.

Type: May know

Topic: Vulval disorders

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Chapter 25 Benign diseases of vulva Page no. 324

choices.text: Atypical giant cells and non-septate hyphae
Sclerotic bodies with a copper penny appearance
Hyaline, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a chronic, verrucous skin lesion on the leg. Histopathological examination of the biopsy reveals fungal elements that appear as thick-walled, brownish bodies within a background of chronic granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following findings is most indicative of chromoblastomycosis?
questions.solution:
Sclerotic bodies with a "copper penny" appearance: These are hallmark features of chromoblastomycosis. They are pigmented, thick-walled fungal cells and are critical for diagnosis.


Option A: Acanthosis and koilocytic changes: These are associated with viral infections like HPV, leading to warts and condylomas, not chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Atypical giant cells and non-septate hyphae: These features are more indicative of infections like mucormycosis or histoplasmosis, which are not characteristic of chromoblastomycosis.

OptionD: Hyaline, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching: This description is characteristic of Aspergillus species, not chromoblastomycosis.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, pg no 32,76

questions.text: Which machine from the provided image is used for the further management of a 60-year-old man with acute shortness of breath and respiratory acidosis due to COPD?
questions.solution:
• BiPAP (Bilevel PositiveAirway Pressure) is technically a CPAP that alternates between two pressure levels (inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) higher pressure and expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP) lower pressure).
  • The principal effect is to increase functional residual capacity and has an added advantage of alveolar recruitment.
  • BiPAP therapy is best for short-term use and in patients with the ability to cough and protect their airways.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Portable Ventilator:


  • A portable ventilator provides invasive ventilatory support and is connected via an endotracheal tube or a tracheostomy tube, not a face mask.
  • It is used to transport patients who require ventilatory support.

Option C - Mechanical Ventilator:


  • An invasive ventilator provides invasive ventilatory support and is connected via an endotracheal tube or a tracheostomy tube, not a face mask.
  • It provides respiratory support to patients who cannot breathe independently.
  • It has 3 modes of ventilation
    • Pressure Controlled Ventilation
    • Volume Controlled Ventilation
    • Pressure Support Ventilation

Option D - ECMO:


  • ECMO stands for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. The ECMO machine is similar to the heart-lung bypass machine used in open-heart surgery.
  • It pumps and oxygenates a patient's blood outside the body, allowing the heart and lungs to rest.
  • The main advantage of ECMO is that it can maintain the supply of oxygen to the body while resting the lungs.

Topic: Mechanical ventilation

Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia,9th edition, Page: 2521

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation with complaint of decreased fetal movements. On examination, the uterus is firm and tender, and there is vaginal bleeding. Fetal heart sounds are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Decreased fetal movements and firm tender uterus points towards Abruptio placenta.

OPTION A) Placenta previa:

Placenta previa is characterized by the placenta being abnormally low in the uterus and covering the cervix. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding. The absence of fetal heart tones and a firm, tender uterus are less characteristic of placenta previa, which usually does not cause a firm and tender uterus or fetal distress until later in the pregnancy.

OPTION B) Uterine rupture:

Uterine rupture is a serious complication that can present with sudden severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and signs of fetal distress. However, a firm and tender uterus with absent fetal heart tones are more consistent with abruptio placentae. Uterine rupture may present more acutely with additional symptoms such as maternal shock and may not necessarily have a firm, tender uterus.

OPTION C) Abruptio placentae:

Abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, occurs when the placenta detaches prematurely from the uterine wall. It is characterized by painful vaginal bleeding, a firm and tender uterus, decreased fetal movements, and absent fetal heart tones. These findings align with the presentation of abruptio placentae, making it the most likely diagnosis.

OPTION D) Vasa previa:

Vasa previa involves fetal blood vessels crossing the cervical os and can lead to fetal hemorrhage if they rupture. It typically presents with vaginal bleeding and fetal distress, but the firm, tender uterus and absence of fetal heart tones are more indicative of placental abruption.

Type: Must know

Topic: Abruptio placentae

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy 4th edition, Chapter 10 Antepartum haemorrhage Page no. 156

choices.text: Painful, multiple ulcers on the genitalia
Painless, solitary ulcer with a raised, indurated border
Papular rash on the trunk and extremities

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature of a Hunterian chancre, which is associated with primary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Characteristic Lesion of Primary syphilis : Chancre:

  • Painless ulcer at the site of infection (e.g., genital, anal, oral regions).
  • Firm, round, and has a clean base with raised edges.
  • Often accompanied by painless regional lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes near the site of the chancre).
  • The chancre heals spontaneously within 3-6 weeks, even without treatment.
  • If untreated, primary syphilis progresses to secondary syphilis and potentially to later stages (latent and tertiary).

  • Option A: Painful, multiple ulcers on the genitalia: Incorrect. A Hunterian chancre is typically painless and solitary, not painful or multiple.
  • Option B: Painless, solitary ulcer with a raised, indurated border: Correct. A Hunterian chancre, the primary lesion of syphilis, is characterized by a painless, solitary ulcer with a firm, indurated (raised) edge.
  • Option C: Papular rash on the trunk and extremities: Incorrect. A papular rash is more associated with secondary syphilis, not the primary chancre.
  • Option D : Vesicular lesions on mucous membranes: Incorrect. Vesicular lesions are characteristic of conditions like herpes simplex virus infections, not syphilis.

Key Takeaway: The Hunterian chancre is a hallmark of primary syphilis and is distinguished by its painless, solitary nature with a firm, indurated border.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Syphilis: Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis." CDC Syphilis Page. Accessed August 30, 2024.

choices.text: Inhibition of transporter of ADP into and ATP out of mitochondria
Inhibition of Complex I of ETC
Blocking of Flow of Protons through ATP synthase
Complex IV inhibitor leading to respiratory arrest

questions.text: 19-year-old female patient admitted in ICU with unconsciousness, decreased respiratory rate. She had taken Injection of KCN for suicide. Which biochemical reaction is responsible for patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Carbon Monoxide and Cyanide inhibit complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.

Above case study is suggestive of cyanide intoxication leading to impairment of Electron Transport chain.

Option A): Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transporter of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondria.

Option B) Barbiturate inhibits electron transport chain via complex I blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q.

Option C) Oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP Synthase


Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, chap 13 page 127

questions.text: A 49-year-old obese woman was admitted to emergency room with severe epigastric pain that starts after heavy meals. Similar episodes but milder occurred with fatty food consumption. There is tenderness over right subcostal area. Which of the following hormone can provoke this attack in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Above are typical symptoms of biliary colic. Well known risk factors are fatty, forty and female in this patient.
  • Cholecystokinin is the hormone responsible for gall bladder contraction produced by I cells in the duodenum in response to fat rich chyme in the duodenum.

It improves enzymatic secretion and causes gall bladder contraction.

In this case fatty food increase CCK secretion. Inflamed gall bladder contraction increases the pain in this patient.

Cholecystokinin inhibits gastric emptying but increases small bowel motility

  • Option A) Secretin promotes bicarbonate secretion from pancreas. It has no effect on gall bladder contraction.
  • Option C) VIP is stimulated by pancreas and causes increase in intestinal water secretion and bicarbonate secretion from pancreas.
  • Option D) Motilin hormone is produced by small intestine. It increases the motility of small intestine.

Topic: GI hormones

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1072-107.

choices.text: Referral to ophthalmology for prism therapy

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident. He reports immediate onset of double vision, particularly when looking to the left. On examination, the following findings are noted:

1. Right eye: Visual acuity 20/25, with a relative afferent pupillary defect.
2. Significant right periorbital edema and ecchymosis.
3. Extraocular movements show limited adduction and elevation of the right eye.
4. Tenderness over the right zygomatic and maxillary regions.
5. No nasal discharge or epistaxis observed.

Which of the following is the most critical next step in management to prevent long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Given these findings, a CT scan of the orbit reveals a fracture of the right orbital floor with herniation of the inferior rectus muscle.



  • Observation with follow-up imaging: While some non-displaced fractures can be managed conservatively, significant muscle entrapment (as indicated by the double vision and relative afferent pupillary defect) necessitates prompt surgical intervention to prevent permanent muscle damage and persistent diplopia.
  • Administration of oral corticosteroids: While corticosteroids can reduce inflammation, they do not address the mechanical issues caused by muscle entrapment or bony displacement and are not appropriate as an initial management strategy in this scenario.
  • Referral to ophthalmology for prism therapy: Prism therapy can be helpful for managing diplopia, but it is not a substitute for addressing the underlying cause, especially in the context of acute muscle entrapment due to fracture.

Orbital Fractures:

Types of Orbital Fractures:

  • Blow-out Fracture:
    • Typically occurs due to blunt trauma, leading to fracture of the orbital floor or medial wall.
    • Characterized by muscle entrapment (e.g., inferior rectus), presenting with diplopia, particularly on upward gaze.
  • Orbital Rim Fracture:
    • Involves the bony margins of the orbit and may not result in muscle entrapment.
    • More likely to present with facial deformity and sensory changes.
  • Zygomatic Fracture:
    • Involves the zygomatic bone and may cause asymmetry and functional impairment of the eye.
  • Frontal Bone Fracture:
    • Can present with periorbital edema and frontal swelling; optic nerve injury may occur.
  • Nasoorbitoethmoidal Fracture:
    • Associated with significant nasal involvement; may lead to complications such as meningitis or cerebrospinal fluid leaks.

Clinical Features:

  • Diplopia: Commonly due to muscle entrapment or mechanical obstruction.
  • Visual Changes: Including decreased visual acuity or relative afferent pupillary defect, indicating potential optic nerve compromise.
  • Sensory Changes: Loss of sensation in the distribution of the maxillary nerve (V2) can indicate orbital or maxillary involvement.
  • Physical Examination: Look for signs of ocular motility issues, periorbital swelling, and possible deformity.

Investigations:

  • CT Scan of the Orbit: The investigation of choice to assess the extent of bony injury, muscle entrapment, and potential foreign body presence.
  • MRI: Indicated for evaluating soft tissue injuries or optic nerve pathologies but less useful for bony assessment.

Management:

  • Surgical Intervention: Essential for significant fractures with muscle entrapment, large defect sizes, or diplopia that does not improve with observation.
  • Conservative Management: May be appropriate for non-displaced fractures without functional impairment.

Complications:

  • Persistent Diplopia: Due to irreversible muscle damage if not managed early.
  • Enophthalmos: Resulting from volume loss in the orbit.
  • Optic Nerve Injury: Potential for visual loss if there is direct trauma to the nerve or significant swelling.

References: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Chapter 10, Orbital Trauma, p. 335.

questions.text: During a routine psychiatric evaluation, a 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of persistent sadness, loss of interest, and feelings of worthlessness. The patient's facial expression appears flat and lacking in emotional responsiveness. Additionally, the physician notices a physical finding as seen in the picture below. Based on these observations, what clinical signs are associated with this patient's depression?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the patient's loss of interest (Anhedonia- inability to feel pleasure in normally pleasurable activities), is a common clinical sign of depression.
  • Additionally, an omega-shaped fold on the forehead above the roof of the nose (Omega sign).
  • This sign occurs due to excessive use of the corrugator muscle, which can be observed in some patients with depression.
  • The other options mentioned in the incorrect options are either unrelated or do not match the clinical signs described in the scenario. Psychomotor agitation is excessive motor activity often seen in certain mental disorders, and suicidal ideation is the presence of thoughts related to self-harm or suicide.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry - 11th Edition - Page no 366

questions.text: Which of the following orthopedic conditions is commonly associated with hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and Primary Hyperparathyroidism

Hypercalcemia:

  • Manifestations:
    • Renal: Polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis.
    • Skeletal: Excessive bony resorption, possible fibrotic tissue replacement (osteitis fibrosa cystica).
    • CNS: Confusion, stupor, weakness.
    • GI: Constipation, anorexia, nausea, vomiting.
    • Other: Dehydration, muscle weakness.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Cause:
    • Overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), often due to a parathyroid adenoma.
    • Surgical parathyroidectomy is typically curative.
  • Effects:
    • Affects usually one parathyroid gland.
    • Biochemical Changes:
      • Increased plasma calcium.
      • Decreased plasma phosphate (due to enhanced urinary excretion).
    • Increased osteoclastic resorption and poor mineralization due to low phosphate levels.

Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a condition associated with hypercalcemia, characterized by bone pain, deformities, and cystic bone lesions due to excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion ultimately resulting in hypercalcemia.

(Option A) Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, not directly related to hyperparathyroidism.

(Option B) Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer and is not specifically linked to hyperparathyroidism.

(Option D) Paget's disease involves abnormal bone remodelling but is not typically caused by hyperparathyroidism.

Metabolic disorders/ May know

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 63

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation presents with severe nausea and vomiting, leading to dehydration and weight loss. She has ketonuria on urinalysis. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of severe nausea and vomiting, dehydration, weight loss, and ketonuria suggest a diagnosis of hyperemesis gravidarum. This condition is more severe than typical morning sickness and requires more aggressive management.

OPTION B) Intravenous fluids and antiemetics:

The most appropriate initial management for hyperemesis gravidarum is intravenous fluids to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, and intravenous antiemetics to control severe nausea and vomiting. This approach addresses both the dehydration and the severe symptoms, providing immediate relief and stabilization. 

OPTION A) Oral antiemetics and reassurance:

While oral antiemetics are useful for mild to moderate nausea and vomiting, they are not sufficient for managing hyperemesis gravidarum, especially when there is significant dehydration and weight loss. Reassurance alone is not appropriate in this case.

OPTION C) Corticosteroids therapy:

Corticosteroids are generally reserved for cases that do not respond to other treatments or for chronic severe cases. They are not typically used as the first-line treatment for initial management of hyperemesis gravidarum.

OPTION D) Admission and nasogastric feeding:

  • Explanation: Nasogastric feeding is a consideration for long-term nutritional support if the patient does not respond to initial treatment. However, it is not the immediate first-line approach. Admission for IV fluids and antiemetics is a more appropriate initial step.

Type: Must know

Topic: Hyperemesis gravidarum

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Chapter 15 Vomiting in pregnancy Page no. 183

choices.text: Increased efficacy of clopidogrel and hence risk of bleeding

questions.text: A 55 Years old diabetic male is recently diagnosed to have coronary artery disease. He is simultaneously started on clopidogrel, Aspirin and Proton pump inhibitors. Which of the following drug interactions may occur with this combination of drug?
questions.solution:
• Although the evidence is mixed and inconclusive, a small increase in mortality and readmission rate for coronary events was seen in patients receiving a PPI while on clopidogrel in earlier studies.
  • The mechanism involves the competition of the PPI and clopidogrel with the same cytochrome P450 (CYP2C19) causing decreased activation of clopidogrel and hence less efficacy. (Refer to the table above)
  • There appears to be at least a theoretical advantage of pantoprazole over the other PPIs, but this has not been confirmed. This drug interaction is particularly relevant in light of the common use of aspirin and clopidogrel for prevention of coronary events and the efficacy of PPIs in preventing GI bleeding in these patients.
  • Patients taking clopidogrel with aspirin, especially with other GI risk factors for bleeding, should receive GI protective therapy. Although high-dose H2 blockers have been considered an option, these do not appear to be as effective as PPIs.
  • If PPIs are to be given, some have recommended that there be a 12-h separation between administration of the PPI and clopidogrel to minimize competition of the two agents with the involved cytochrome P450. One option is to give the PPI 30 min before breakfast and the clopidogrel at bedtime.
  • B. Due to competition between Omeprazole and Clopidogrel,there is decreased(not increased) efficacy of Clopidogrel and hence increased risk of bleeding.
  • C,D: Aspirin being a salicylate derivative,mainly undergoes phase 2 metabolism and hence doesn't show much pharmacokinetic interaction with Omeprazole and Clopidogrel

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2444

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female presents with Oral ulcers, Flaccid bullae on the trunk and extremities, Skin crusting and erosions.
Biopsy from a lesional skin shows:

Immunofluorescence: IgG deposits on keratinocyte surfaces (Fishnet like pattern)
Which of the following is the primary site of bulla formation in this skin lesion?
questions.solution:
• Patient’s history with IF findings of fishnet like pattern suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Image shows Suprabasalsplit with intact basal layer confirms the diagnosis.
  1. Bulla formation typically occurs in the suprabasal layer in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris Autoimmune blistering disease
  • Characterized by suprabasal and basal cell layer separation.
  • Intraepidermal blisters with acantholysis.
  • Antibodies against desmoglein 3 disrupt desmosome function in the suprabasal layer.
  • Immunofluorescence shows IgG deposits on keratinocyte surfaces, particularly in the basal and suprabasal layers.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1160.

questions.text: Boy presented with Failure to thrive, recurrent vomiting, Hepatosplenomegaly. Radiological Finding shows Bilateral Adrenal Calcification. Biochemical Test Reports shows deficiency of Enzyme Lysosomal Acid Lipase. What is most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wolman's Disease is lipid disorder caused by deficiency of Lysosomal Acid Lipase which leads to accumulation of cholesterol esters and TGs in visceral organs. Infant with adrenal calcification, adrenal insufficiency with recurrent vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly is suggestive of Wolman's Disease.

Adrenal gland calcification in wolman's disease.

Option A: Hunter's Disease is due to enzyme Iduronate Sulfatase deficiency. Mental Retardation is present.

Option C:Scheie's Disease is due to L iduronidase deficiency. Child Presented with Hepatosplenomegaly, Clouding of cornea.

Option B: Pompe's Disease is Lysosomal Storage Disease. Deficiency of enzyme lysosomal alpha 1-4 Glucosidase is present. Involvement of Heart, Liver and Muscle is seen.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 19 page 270

choices.text: Surgical excision of the rudimentary horn

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with severe cyclic pain and a pelvic mass on examination. MRI reveals a unicornuate uterus with a non-communicating rudimentary horn containing endometrial tissue. What is the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Surgical excision of the rudimentary horn is the recommended management for a non-communicating rudimentary horn with endometrial tissue.

OPTION A. Observation

Observation is not appropriate in this scenario because the presence of a non-communicating rudimentary horn with endometrial tissue can lead to severe complications such as hematometra, endometriosis, and chronic pelvic pain due to the accumulation of menstrual blood. Thus, observation alone is not sufficient.

OPTION B. GnRH agonist therapy

GnRH agonist therapy may temporarily reduce endometrial activity and pain by inducing a hypoestrogenic state, but it does not resolve the underlying anatomical issue. GnRH agonists are not a definitive treatment for a rudimentary horn with endometrial tissue and will not prevent future complications.

OPTION C. Surgical excision of the rudimentary horn (Correct Answer)

Surgical excision of the rudimentary horn is the recommended management for a non-communicating rudimentary horn with endometrial tissue. This approach addresses the source of cyclic pain and prevents complications such as hematometra, infection, or rupture. Removal of the rudimentary horn is necessary to alleviate symptoms and prevent further gynecological complications.

OPTION D. Myomectomy

Myomectomy involves the removal of fibroids and is not relevant to the treatment of a rudimentary horn with endometrial tissue. The rudimentary horn is not a fibroid, and myomectomy does not address the issue of menstrual blood accumulation or cyclic pain associated with the horn.

Surgical excision of the rudimentary horn is the appropriate management for a non-communicating rudimentary horn containing endometrial tissue, as it definitively resolves the cyclic pain and prevents further complications associated with this congenital anomaly.

Type: Must know

Topic: Mullerian anomalies

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 18 Anatomic Disorders, Page no. 421

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought in by his friend to the Emergency department with a sustained head injury following a road traffic accident. His GCS is 6/15, and he has a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, a pulse rate of 50 beats/minute, and SpO2 of 90% at room air. Given poor GCS, his airway is secured in the casualty. Which device, incorporating Murphy's eye, is utilized to secure the airway?
questions.solution:
• The above mentioned patient sustained a head injury and is not maintaining saturation at room air. She is intubated with an endotracheal tube with a murphy eye structure.
  • The main indications for intubation with an endotracheal tube are airway protection and control of the airway.
  • Indications include:
    • General anaesthesia
    • Congenital malformations
    • Diseases of the upper airway
    • Mechanical ventilation
    • Perinatal resuscitation
  • Acute respiratory distress
  • Murphy's eye is the part of the endotracheal tube just distal to the proximal opening.
  • Size of Endotracheal tube:
    • Adult Male: 8mm ID-9mm ID
    • Adult Female: 7mm ID-8mm ID
  • Pediatric size of the endotracheal tube
    • For age > 6 years: ETT size = Age/4 + 4.5 mm ID
    • For age < 6 years: ETT size = Age/3 + 3.5 mm ID

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Laryngeal mask airway:

  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA) are supraglottic airway devices.
  • They are used as a quick method to maintain an open airway during anaesthesia induction and as an immediate life-saving procedure for a failed airway patient.
  • It does not have Murphy's eye in its structure.

Option C - Anesthesia face mask:

  • The face mask does not have Murphy's eye in its structure.

Option D - Mapleson circuit:

  • Mapleson has no Murphy's eye in its structure.

Topic: Airway devices

Reference : Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no. 1393-1396

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of preterm delivery at 24 weeks presents for an infertility evaluation. MRI shows two symmetric uteri, each with its own cervix, and a longitudinal vaginal septum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of 2 uterus and 2 cervix is diagnostic of Didelphic uterus.

OPTION A. Septate uterus

A septate uterus is characterized by a single uterine cavity divided by a fibrous or muscular septum. It does not involve two separate uterine bodies, cervices, or a longitudinal vaginal septum. Therefore, this option does not match the MRI findings.

OPTION B. Bicornuate uterus

A bicornuate uterus has a partial fusion defect of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in a uterus with a heart-shaped appearance and a single cervix. It does not present with two completely separate uteri and two cervices, which differentiates it from uterine didelphys.

OPTION C. Uterine didelphys (Correct Answer)

Uterine didelphys is characterized by two symmetric uteri, each with its own cervix, and often a longitudinal vaginal septum. This condition results from complete failure of the Mullerian ducts to fuse. The MRI findings of two separate uterine bodies, each with its own cervix, and a vaginal septum are classic for uterine didelphys.

OPTION D. Unicornuate uterus

A unicornuate uterus results from incomplete development of one Mullerian duct, leading to a single, banana-shaped uterus and one cervix. It may have a rudimentary horn but does not have two separate uteri or cervices, making it inconsistent with the MRI findings.

The description of two symmetric uteri, each with its own cervix, and a longitudinal vaginal septum on MRI is characteristic of uterine didelphys, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Type: Must know

Topic: Mullerian anomalies

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 18 Anatomic Disorders, Page no. 421-422

questions.text: According to CDC guidelines, which antibiotic is commonly used to treat a confirmed case of Lyme disease?
questions.solution:
Lyme disease -Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted by the Ixodes deer tick

  • Natural reservoir is the mouse; deer are essential to tick life cycle but do not harbor Borrelia.
  • Stages-
    • Stage 1-early localized: erythema migrans (typical "bulls-eye" configuration is pathognomonic but not always present), flulike symptoms.
    • Stage 2-early disseminated: secondary lesions, carditis, AV block, facial nerve (Bell) palsy, migratory myalgias/transient arthritis.
    • Stage 3-late disseminated: encephalopathy, chronic arthritis, peripheral neuropathy

TIPS AND TRICKS- Remember LYME is to FACE

Facial nerve palsy (typically bilateral)

Arthritis

Cardiac block

Erythema migrans

Treatment: doxycycline (1st line); amoxicillin (pregnant patients, children < 8 years old); ceftriaxone if IV therapy required

  • A. Azithromycin: While effective for some bacterial infections, it is not typically used for Lyme disease.
  • B. Ciprofloxacin: A fluoroquinolone used for various infections but not a first-line treatment for Lyme disease.
  • C. Doxycycline: A tetracycline antibiotic commonly recommended by the CDC for treating Lyme disease, especially in early stages.
  • D. Erythromycin: An alternative antibiotic, but not the first choice for Lyme disease treatment.

Key Takeaway: Doxycycline is the preferred antibiotic for treating Lyme disease, especially if the infection is diagnosed early.

Reference: CDC Lyme Disease Treatment. CDC - Lyme Disease Treatment

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has a Pap smear showing atypical glandular cells (AGC). What is the recommended next step in management?
questions.solution:
Atypical glandular cells warrant a colposcopy with endocervical curettage to evaluate the endocervical canal for glandular abnormalities.

OPTION A. Repeat Pap smear in 6 months

Repeating a Pap smear in 6 months is not recommended for atypical glandular cells (AGC) because AGC is associated with a higher risk of significant cervical, endometrial, or other gynecologic malignancies. Prompt evaluation is necessary rather than waiting, making this option inappropriate.

OPTION B. HPV testing

While HPV testing is useful in the evaluation of abnormal Pap smear results, it is not the first step specifically for AGC. AGC findings warrant a more immediate and thorough investigation due to the potential for high-grade lesions or cancer, making HPV testing alone insufficient.

OPTION C. Colposcopy with endocervical curettage (Correct Answer)

Colposcopy with endocervical curettage is the recommended next step in management for AGC on a Pap smear. This approach allows for a thorough evaluation of the cervix and endocervical canal to identify any potential lesions, including high-grade lesions or malignancies that may not be detected by colposcopy alone.

OPTION D. LEEP procedure

A LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure) is a treatment option for high-grade cervical lesions but is not the first diagnostic step for AGC. It involves the excision of abnormal tissue from the cervix and is typically performed after colposcopy and biopsy confirm significant dysplasia or carcinoma in situ.

Reference: Williams Gyanecology 3rd edition, Chapter 30, Preinvasive Lesions of the Lower Genital Tract Page no. 36-6376

questions.text: A 34 year old female anxious patient brought to medicine outpatient department seeking treatment for gastroesophageal reflux disease. She was put on an appropriate treatment. Later she again presented to medicine department with complaints of headache, dizziness and drowsiness. Laboratory findings showed an increase of the patient's prolactin levels. Which of the following drugs could have caused the undesirable effect to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Metoclopramide is an antagonist of D2 and 5-HT3 receptors.
  • Blockade of D2 receptors in the central nervous system can cause dizziness and drowsiness
  • Blockade of D2 receptors in the pituitary leads to hyperprolactinemia, a common adverse effect of metoclopramide
  • Side effects of Metoclopramide :
    • Sedation,
    • Dizziness,
    • Loose stools,
    • Muscle dystonias (especially in children)

Long-term use can cause parkinsonism, galactorrhoea and gynaecomastia

Option A, B & C: All of these do not block D2 receptors hence they do not lead to typical side effects of Metoclopramide

choices.text: Right homonymous hemianopia due to ischemic stroke; expected findings include relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) in the right eye and visual neglect on the left side.
Right homonymous hemianopia due to a primary brain tumor; expected findings include ocular motility disorders and possible papilledema.
Right homonymous hemianopia due to a demyelinating disease; expected findings include nystagmus and a possible RAPD in the affected eye.
Right homonymous hemianopia due to a metastatic lesion; expected findings include visual hallucinations and changes in mental status.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with complaints of progressive vision loss in the right visual field over the past three months. His visual history is notable for a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) six months ago. On examination, he demonstrates a right sided field vision loss. Further evaluation reveals an abnormality on MRI: a right-sided occipital lobe lesion.
Given the patient's history and the findings, which of the following is the most likely etiology of his visual field loss, and what additional findings would you expect on examination related to this condition?
questions.solution:
• Option A is incorrect. While an ischemic stroke can cause homonymous hemianopia, it typically would not present with a RAPD unless there was a severe afferent defect (not common in pure visual field loss), and visual neglect would not be specific for occipital lesions.
  • Option B is incorrect. A primary brain tumor can indeed cause right homonymous hemianopia, but ocular motility disorders are more characteristic of brainstem lesions, and papilledema would indicate increased intracranial pressure, which is not always present.
  • Option C is incorrect. Demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis can cause visual field deficits; however, nystagmus and RAPD are not characteristic of an isolated homonymous hemianopia.
  • Option D is correct. A metastatic lesion in the right occipital lobe is a common cause of right homonymous hemianopia. This can lead to visual hallucinations due to the disruption of visual processing areas, and changes in mental status may occur depending on the extent of the lesion and associated edema or infiltration of adjacent structures.

Explanation:

  • Visual Field Loss:
    • Homonymous Hemianopia: Typically results from lesions in the optic tract or occipital lobe.
  • Common Etiologies:
    • Metastatic Lesions: Often associated with right homonymous hemianopia in older adults with a history of cancer.
    • Stroke: Affects the visual pathway but presents differently based on lesion location and size.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Visual Hallucinations: May indicate involvement of higher visual processing areas.
    • Mental Status Changes: Suggest potential increased intracranial pressure or cortical dysfunction.
  • Diagnostic Workup:
    • MRI: Critical for identifying lesions and their characteristics.
    • Neurological Examination: To assess for additional deficits and correlate with the findings.
  • Management:
    • Referral to Oncology: If metastatic disease is confirmed.
    • Supportive Care: Including vision rehabilitation and psychological support for visual disturbances.

Review:

McGowan, H. M., & O'Brien, P. (2016). Neurological Causes of Visual Field Loss. The Eye and Vision, 3(1), 1-10. doi:10.1186/s40662-016-0008-1

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of diabetic microangiopathy?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic microangiopathy results from a complex interplay of multiple mechanisms, including:
  1. Hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress:
    • High glucose levels increase production of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
    • ROS damage endothelial cells, leading to microvascular dysfunction.
  2. Advanced glycosylation end-products (AGEs) accumulation:
    • AGEs form when glucose binds to proteins or lipids.
    • AGEs accumulate in tissues, activating pro-inflammatory pathways and damaging micro vessels.
  3. Increased vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF):
    • VEGF promotes angiogenesis and increases vascular permeability.
    • Elevated VEGF levels contribute to microvascular damage and leakage.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1108.

choices.text: Minimal change disease is the most common cause
Corticosteroids are the first line of treatment

questions.text: A 4-year-old presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of swelling around the eyes and ankles over 5 days. You note the patient to have pitting edema up to the knees bilaterally and peri-orbital edema with no erythema. Urine analysis shows 3+ protein in the urine without signs of infection or red blood cells. No other significant history and examination findings are seen. Which of the following is a false statement for the condition?
questions.solution:
• The child most likely has nephrotic syndrome. Minimal change disease is the most common etiology(Option A)
  • Minimal change disease is characterized by nephrotic syndrome without systemic disease. Two-thirds of the cases present between the ages of 2 to 6.
  • The recommended treatment regimen is to start a course of high-dose corticosteroids and to follow urine protein to see if there is a response. Severe cases may need hospitalization for diuretic therapy; however, most cases caught early can be treated as an outpatient. (Option C)

(Ref. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2752)

questions.text: A 70 year old patient complained of difficulty in breathing and shortness of breath. He also developed foaming in the mouth. On doing an ECHO, the LVEF was found to be 20%. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary edema refers to the accumulation of fluid in the lung's interstitial and alveolar spaces, which can significantly impair gas exchange and lead to respiratory distress.

Types of Pulmonary Edema:

  1. Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema (CPE): Caused by increased pulmonary capillary pressure, often due to left-sided heart failure, valvular heart disease, or myocardial infarction.
  2. Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema (NCPE): Occurs due to increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary membrane, often caused by acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), sepsis, or inhalation injury.

Radiologic Findings:

  1. Chest X-ray (CXR)
    • The chest X-ray is the most commonly used imaging modality for diagnosing pulmonary edema. The findings depend on the stage and severity of the edema.
  2. Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema (CPE)
    1. Cardiomegaly:
      • Enlarged heart silhouette, often indicating underlying cardiac causes (e.g., heart failure).
      • CXR: The cardiothoracic ratio (ratio of heart width to chest width) is often > 50%.
    2. Vascular Redistribution (Cephalization):
      • Redistribution of blood flow to the upper lung zones due to elevated pulmonary venous pressure.
      • CXR: Increased prominence of the upper lobe vessels (upper zone vessels appear more prominent than lower ones).
    3. Kerley B Lines:
      • Thin, horizontal lines seen at the lung bases that represent thickened interlobular septa due to fluid accumulation.
      • CXR: Short, 1-2 cm long, perpendicular to the pleural surface at the lung bases.
    4. Peribronchial Cuffing:
      • Fluid accumulation around the bronchi, making the bronchial walls appear thickened.
      • CXR: Appears as “donut-shaped” or ring-like opacities.
    5. Batwing (Butterfly) Pattern:
      • Fluid accumulation in the perihilar regions, extending outward in a fan-shaped or butterfly pattern.
      • CXR: Central, symmetrical opacification radiating from the hila, often sparing the lung peripheries.
    6. Pleural Effusions:
      • Often bilateral, small-to-moderate pleural effusions are common in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
      • CXR: Blunting of the costophrenic angles due to fluid collection.
  3. Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema (NCPE)
    1. In NCPE, the radiologic features may overlap with cardiogenic edema, but there are distinguishing characteristics:
      1. Normal Heart Size:
        • Unlike cardiogenic pulmonary edema, the heart size is usually normal in non-cardiogenic causes.
        • CXR: Normal cardiothoracic ratio, no signs of cardiomegaly.
      2. Diffuse, Bilateral Alveolar Infiltrates:
        • Patchy or diffuse airspace opacities that are more peripherally located than the central distribution in CPE.
        • CXR: Bilateral, diffuse "fluffy" or patchy opacities without a predilection for the perihilar regions.
      3. Absence of Pleural Effusions:
        • Pleural effusions are less common in non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, although they can be present in certain conditions like ARDS.
        • CXR: If effusions are present, they are usually small and unilateral.
      4. Ground-glass Opacities:
        • These can be seen on high-resolution imaging and represent partial alveolar filling or interstitial thickening.
        • CT: Areas of ground-glass opacity with relative lung sparing.
  4. Computed Tomography (CT)
    1. Findings on CT:
      • Ground-glass opacities: More evident in non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, especially in cases like ARDS or acute lung injury.
      • Interlobular septal thickening: Corresponds to Kerley B lines seen on X-rays.
      • Perihilar consolidation: Often bilateral and symmetrical in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
      • Crazy paving pattern: A combination of ground-glass opacities and interlobular septal thickening, more typical of non-cardiogenic causes.
      • Pleural effusions: Better visualized on CT than X-ray, and small effusions may be detected even when not apparent on plain films.
  5. Stages of Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema on X-ray:
    1. Stage 1: Redistribution (Interstitial Edema)
      • Findings: Cephalization of pulmonary vessels, Kerley B lines, and peribronchial cuffing.
      • Cause: Increased pulmonary venous pressure.
    2. Stage 2: Early Alveolar Edema
      • Findings: Increased interstitial markings, more prominent Kerley B lines, mild pleural effusions, and hazy opacification in the perihilar areas.
    3. Stage 3: Alveolar Edema
      • Findings: "Batwing" or "butterfly" pattern of alveolar opacities, representing fluid in the alveoli, often with more extensive pleural effusions.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 398.

questions.text: In a small village of Madhya Pradesh with the population of 1.5 lakh, 10% are below <14 years of age and 70% population lies between the age group 15-64 years. Calculate the dependency ratio for the village?
questions.solution:
• The ratio of the combined age groups 0-14 year plus 65 years and above to the 15-65 years age group is referred to as the total dependency ratio. It is also referred to as societal dependency ratio.
  • Total dependency ratio = children between 0-14 years +population more than 65 years of age*100/population of 15-64 years of age.
  • Putting the values in above scenario 10%+20%*100/70%, which comes out to be 42.8%.

Reference: - Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.559.

questions.text: A 50 yrs old female patient having complain of swelling thyroid swelling and diarrhoea. She was diagnosed as a case of malignancy of thyroid. Her histopathology was given below. Identify the type of thyroid malignancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma:

  • Cell Type: Derived from parafollicular C cells (calcitonin-secreting).
  • Histology:
    • Polygonal to spindle-shaped cells.
    • Amyloid deposits (from calcitonin) are common.
    • Presence of nests or sheets of tumor cells.
    • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for calcitonin and CEA.

Option A. Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma:

  • Cell Type: Derived from follicular epithelium.
  • Histology:
    • Papillary architecture with fibrovascular cores.
    • Characteristic "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei).
    • Nuclear grooves and intranuclear pseudoinclusions.
    • Psammoma bodies (calcified structures) often present.

Option B ) : Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma:

  • Cell Type: Derived from follicular cells.
  • Histology:
    • Follicular architecture with small, uniform cells forming follicles.
    • Capsular and vascular invasion (distinguishing from benign follicular adenoma).
    • Lack of the typical nuclear features of papillary carcinoma.

Option D) : Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma:

  • Cell Type: Undifferentiated, arising from follicular cells.
  • Histology:
    • Highly pleomorphic, giant cells, spindle cells, or squamoid appearance.
    • No papillary or follicular structures.
    • High mitotic activity, necrosis, and extensive invasion.
    • Poor prognosis due to aggressive behavior.

Reference: Schwartz's principles of surgery; 11th edition; chapter 38 ; page 1647,1651,1657.

Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 55 ; page 871.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a known diagnosis of HIV/AIDS presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of floaters and a "curtain" over his vision in the right eye for the past week. His medical history is notable for a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³ and a recent diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia. On examination, visual acuity in the right eye is 20/200, while the left eye is 20/25. Fundoscopic examination reveals a pale retina with below findings.
questions.solution:
Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • B. Toxoplasmic retinochoroiditis: While common in immunocompromised patients, this typically presents with focal necrotizing retinitis rather than the fluffy white patches and diffuse hemorrhages seen in CMV retinitis.
  • C. Herpes simplex keratitis: This primarily affects the cornea and would not cause the retinal findings observed in this patient.
  • D. Bacterial conjunctivitis: This condition would not explain the retinal findings and visual acuity loss seen in this patient.

Ocular Manifestations of AIDS:

  1. Cytomegalovirus Retinitis (CMV):
    • Common in: Patients with CD4 count < 200 cells/mm³.
    • Symptoms: Floaters, blurred vision, and visual field defects.
    • Fundoscopic Findings: "Pizza pie" retina appearance with retinal hemorrhages and necrotic lesions.
  2. Toxoplasmic Retinochoroiditis:
    • Common in: Patients with CD4 count < 100 cells/mm³.
    • Symptoms: Blurred vision and floaters.
    • Fundoscopic Findings: Focal retinitis with necrotic lesions and associated vitritis.
  3. Herpes Simplex Keratitis:
    • Common in: HIV-positive patients; presents as dendritic ulcers on the cornea.
    • Symptoms: Pain, redness, and photophobia.
    • Fundoscopic Findings: Not applicable; primarily a corneal condition.
  4. Other Manifestations:
    • HIV Retinopathy: Cotton wool spots and retinal hemorrhages.
    • Uveitis: Inflammatory conditions associated with opportunistic infections.
  5. Management:
    • Antiviral Therapy: For CMV retinitis, consider ganciclovir or foscarnet.
    • Monitoring: Regular ocular examinations for early detection of opportunistic infections.

Adnexal Involvement in HIV-Infected Persons

  1. Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)
    • Cause: Varicella zoster virus (VZV).
    • Prevalence: Seen in 5% to 15% of HIV patients.
    • Presentation: Vesiculobullous dermatitis along the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Associated Conditions: Keratitis, scleritis, uveitis, retinitis, or encephalitis.
  2. Kaposi Sarcoma
    • Type: Highly-vascularized mesenchymal tumor.
    • Presentation: Painless, violaceous lesions on eyelid skin or conjunctiva.
  3. Molluscum Contagiosum
    • Cause: Poxvirus.
    • Presentation: Multiple small, painless umbilicated lesions on eyelid skin.
  4. Conjunctival Microvasculopathy
    • Prevalence: 70% to 80% of HIV patients.
    • Characteristics:
      • Segmental dilatation and narrowing of blood vessels.
      • Comma-shaped vascular segments and sludging of blood column.
    • Causes: Immune complex deposition, increased plasma viscosity, or invasion of vascular endothelium by HIV.
    • Correlation: Associated with retinal microangiopathy.

Posterior Segment Involvement in HIV

  1. Retinal Microangiopathy
    • Prevalence: Most common ophthalmic manifestation of HIV; associated with low CD4 T-cell counts.
    • Characteristics: Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and microaneurysms.
    • Pathogenesis: Similar to conjunctival microvasculopathy.
  2. CMV Retinitis
    • Prevalence: Affects 30% to 40% of HIV-infected individuals, usually with CD4 counts < 100/microliter.
    • Findings: Full-thickness intraretinal opacification, retinal hemorrhages; minimal AC reaction; generally clear vitreous.
    • Complications: Vision loss from macula or optic nerve involvement, retinal detachment, and immune recovery uveitis.
  3. VZV Retinitis
    • Characteristics:
      • Multifocal lesions that progress rapidly.
      • Associated with skin lesions.
      • Characterized by retinal whitening and hemorrhages.
  4. Toxoplasma Retinochoroiditis
    • Characteristics:
      • Usually bilateral and multifocal.
      • May be associated with CNS involvement.
  5. Ocular Syphilis
    • Prevalence: Seen in 2% of patients.
    • Presentation: Anterior segment inflammation or diffuse intraocular involvement.
  6. Infectious Choroiditis
    • Causes: Pneumocystis, Cryptococcus, or tuberculosis.

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Chapter 19, Ocular Manifestations of Systemic Disease, p. 659.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A ureter that drains outside the bladder is referred to as an ectopic ureter. This anomaly is 3 times as common in girls as in boys and usually is detected prenatally.
  • In girls an ectopic ureter causes continuous urinary incontinence from the affected renal moiety. UTI is common because of urinary stasis.
  • VUR is generally diagnosed in antenatal scan while screening or as a part of workup of UTI. (Option D)
  • Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed antenatally during scans with distended bladder. If missed, severe PUV can present with failure to thrive and recurrent UTI or difficulty in achieving diurnal continence. It is common in boys. (Option C)
  • Primary nocturnal enuresis will be having enuresis at night with no dribbling of urine otherwise. (Option B)

(Ref. Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2805)

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in eating and problems with digestion. He also had significant weight loss and was advised to undergo a CT scan. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Stomach cancer, also known as gastric cancer, is primarily adenocarcinoma that originates from the stomach lining.

  1. Upper Gastrointestinal (GI) Series (Barium Swallow or Barium Meal):
    • Findings:
      • Irregular filling defects: These are seen when the tumor disrupts the normal mucosal pattern.
      • Polypoid masses or ulceration within the stomach lining may be identified.
      • "Apple core" lesion: A narrowing or constriction of the stomach lumen due to an annular tumor.
      • Delayed emptying: This suggests a mass obstructing the gastric outlet.
  2. CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the primary imaging tool for staging gastric cancer and assessing the spread of the disease.
    • Findings:
      • Irregular thickening of the stomach wall, often greater than 5 mm.
      • Mass within the stomach, sometimes associated with ulceration.
      • Invasion of adjacent organs (e.g., pancreas, liver, or colon).
      • Enlarged regional lymph nodes (e.g., perigastric, para-aortic nodes).
      • CT can detect metastases to the liver, lungs, adrenal glands, or peritoneum.
      • Ascites: May indicate peritoneal spread of the tumor.
      • Omental caking: Thickening of the omentum from peritoneal metastasis.
  3. Positron Emission Tomography (PET-CT):
    • Findings:
      • Hypermetabolic activity within the stomach, indicating the presence of a tumor.
      • Distant metastases: PET-CT is highly sensitive for detecting distant organ metastasis, including liver and lung involvement.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Radiologic Features of Gastric Cancer:

Types of wall thickening:

Gastric cancer commonly presents as irregular gastric wall thickening. On CT or MRI, a normal gastric wall is thin (<5 mm), and wall thickening suggests a tumor. The thickness can vary based on the type of tumor.

Diffuse-type gastric cancer (linitis plastica) can present as uniform, diffuse thickening of the stomach wall, which causes the stomach to appear narrowed and rigid ("leather bottle stomach").

Polypoid Mass:Some gastric cancers present as a polypoid mass that protrudes into the stomach lumen. This may be associated with ulceration.

Ulcerated Lesions: Central ulceration can appear within a tumor mass, surrounded by a thickened and irregular wall. This is a common feature in gastric cancers visualized on CT, MRI, or endoscopy.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 511

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with infertility and gynecomastia. Semen analysis reveals oligospermia. Physical examination shows small, firm testes. Karyotyping reveals 47,XXY. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The scenario suggests that it is a case of Klinefelter syndrome

OPTION A. Testosterone replacement therapy

Testosterone replacement therapy is used to treat symptoms of hypogonadism such as low libido, fatigue, and muscle weakness. However, it does not improve fertility and can actually suppress spermatogenesis further. Therefore, it is not the appropriate next step for managing infertility in this patient with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY).

OPTION B. Varicocelectomy

Varicocelectomy is a surgical procedure to correct a varicocele, which can improve semen parameters in some men with infertility. However, it is not indicated in Klinefelter syndrome, as the infertility in this condition is due to testicular dysgenesis and not varicocele.

OPTION C. IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) (Correct Answer)

IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is the most appropriate fertility treatment for men with Klinefelter syndrome who have oligospermia or non-obstructive azoospermia. ICSI allows direct injection of a single sperm into an egg, which is ideal when sperm counts are very low or when sperm needs to be retrieved surgically. This approach offers the best chance of achieving pregnancy in this setting.

OPTION D. Clomiphene citrate

Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that can be used to stimulate endogenous testosterone production and increase spermatogenesis in men with secondary hypogonadism. However, in Klinefelter syndrome, it is unlikely to significantly improve sperm counts due to the underlying testicular dysfunction, making it less effective than IVF with ICSI.

Key Takeaway: IVF with ICSI is the most appropriate next step in the management of infertility for a patient with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY), as it offers the best chance of achieving pregnancy by directly injecting sperm into an egg, bypassing the limitations of oligospermia associated with the condition.

Type: Must know

Topic: Male infertility

Reference: Speroff’s Gynaecology 9th edition, Chapter 8 Normal & abnormal sexual development, Page no. 690
