questions.text: A 54 year old woman who underwent kidney transplant developed nausea, vomiting and diarrhea a few days after the surgery. The patient had received post transplant therapy with cyclosporine and prednisone. A decision was by her physician to substitute sirolimus for the cyclosporine. Which of the following action most likely mediates the immunosuppressive effect of sirolimus?
questions.solution:
• Sirolimus (formerly called rapamycin) resembles tacrolimus and binds to the same intracellular FK-binding proteins.
  • However, whereas tacrolimus and cyclosporine block gene transcription, sirolimus acts later to block interleukin-2- dependent lymphocyte proliferation.
  • This blockade is likely due to the inhibition of mammalian kinase (called mammalian target of rapamycin), an enzyme that is essential for cell-cycle progression. Therefore, the drug substantially inhibits T- and B-cell proliferation.
  • Sirolimus
    • This newer and potent immunosuppressant is a macrolide antibiotic (like tacrolimus), which was earlier named Rapamycin.
    • IL-2 stimulates immune system by activation of several T cells via activation of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR).
    • Sirolimus (rapamycin) binds to mTOR and inhibits the action of IL-2 without affecting its transcription.
    • It is used as immunosuppressive agent in organ transplantation and GVHD.
    • It is also incorporated in cardiac stents to decrease the chances of re-occlusion.
    • Its major adverse effect is thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow suppression and hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in
questions.solution:
In masochism, the person obtains sexual gratification by suffering pain.

Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia (autoerotic death).

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges, or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among males, who get sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc., of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism

Reference:

  • The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 35th edition - Page no 335
  • Review of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects - 394, 395

questions.text: Which fungus is known to cause Valley Fever, according to the CDC?
questions.solution:
Transmission:

  • Coccidioides is a dimorphic fungus and Infection occurs through inhalation of arthroconidia (spores) from the soil, often after soil disturbances (e.g., dust storms, construction).

Barrel shaped arthrospores and spherules

  • It is not transmitted from person-to-person.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Asymptomatic in most individuals (about 60% of cases).
  • Acute Pulmonary Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever): Flu-like symptoms, such as fever, cough, fatigue, chest pain, and arthralgias (often called "desert rheumatism").
  • Chronic Pulmonary Coccidioidomycosis: Can occur in immunocompromised individuals or those with underlying lung disease.
  • Disseminated Coccidioidomycosis: Rare but serious; may involve skin, bones, joints, CNS (causing meningitis).

Explanation:

  • A. Candida albicans: A yeast that commonly causes oral and vaginal infections, not Valley Fever.
  • B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Causes aspergillosis, a lung infection, not Valley Fever.
  • C. Coccidioides immitis: Responsible for Valley Fever, also known as coccidioidomycosis, affecting the lungs.
  • D. Cryptococcus neoformans: Causes cryptococcosis, which primarily affects individuals with weakened immune systems.

Key Takeaway: Coccidioides immitis is the fungus that causes Valley Fever, particularly in southwestern United States.

Reference: CDC

questions.text: Optimum glycaemic control in critically ill patients is essential for recovery. What is the target glucose levels in ICU patients as per current guidelines?
questions.solution:
Tight glucose control has been an area of controversy in critical care. Although one study showed a significant mortality benefit when glucose levels were aggressively normalized in a large group of surgical ICU patients, other studies of both medical and surgical ICU patients suggested that tight glucose control resulted in increased rates of mortality likely attributable, in part, to hypoglycaemic episodes. Thus, current guidelines suggest targeting glucose levels of ≤180 mg/dL in critically ill patients, rather than targeting tighter control.

Ref: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2188

questions.text: Following is an image pressure volume loop in 50-year-old male. The loop marked with solid line shows an increase in which of the following parameters in the dashed line?
questions.solution:
• Ejection fraction is the amount of blood which comes out from the ventricle in a single stroke divided by end diastolic volume.
    • Ejection fraction (EF) - stroke volume\EDV →. EDV-ESV\EDV
  • The dashed line shows curve shift to the left. It means stroke volume is same but end diastolic volume is reduced. Thus, ejection fraction is increased.
  • Option A- After load is the resistance the left ventricle must overcome to eject blood. An increase in afterload, It Leads to a higher end-systolic volume (ESV) because the heart has to work harder against increased resistance, resulting in less blood being ejected.
    It causes the loop to shift upward (higher pressure) and may also widen (higher ESV), but not to the left.
  • Option B - End diastolic volume is reduced when the curve is shifted to the left.
  • Option D - Preload refers to the volume of blood filling the ventricle at the end of diastole (EDV). An increase in preload would, increase the EDV, causing the loop to shift to the right (more blood in the ventricle before contraction). The leftward shift would not occur with an increase in preload.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1222 fig 30-2

questions.text: Match the following diagnostic tests with their associated conditions:
questions.solution:
• Patch test - C. Contact dermatitis: The patch test is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis by identifying allergens that trigger a skin reaction.
  • KOH mount - D. Tinea: A KOH (potassium hydroxide) mount is used to identify fungal elements in skin scrapings, such as those seen in tinea (ringworm) infections.
  • Biopsy - B. Lupus Vulgaris: A biopsy is often used to diagnose various skin conditions, including lupus vulgaris, which is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Slit skin smear - A. Leprosy: The slit skin smear is a diagnostic test used to detect Mycobacterium leprae in leprosy by examining skin smears for acid-fast bacilli.

So, the correct matching is: 1 – C, 2 – D, 3 – B, 4 - A

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 128.66, 32.35, 27.25, 28.14

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of endometriosis is being treated with a GnRH agonist. Which of the following is a common side effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. Hot flashes (Correct Answer)

Hot flashes are a common side effect of GnRH agonists. These medications work by downregulating the pituitary gland, leading to decreased estrogen production, which can cause menopausal-like symptoms, including hot flashes. This is one of the most frequently reported side effects in patients treated with GnRH agonists for endometriosis or other conditions.

OPTION B. Weight gain

While weight gain can occur with some hormonal treatments, it is not a primary or common side effect of GnRH agonists. The main effects of GnRH agonists are related to reduced estrogen levels, which more commonly lead to symptoms like hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and decreased bone density.

OPTION C. Acne

Acne is more commonly associated with medications that increase androgen levels, such as progestins or anabolic steroids. GnRH agonists lower estrogen and androgen levels, which typically do not lead to acne. Therefore, acne is not a common side effect of GnRH agonists.

OPTION D. Hyperglycemia

Hyperglycemia is not a typical side effect of GnRH agonist therapy. While changes in metabolism can occur with hormonal therapies, GnRH agonists primarily cause symptoms related to estrogen deficiency, and hyperglycemia is not commonly observed.

Key Takeaway: Hot flashes are a common side effect of GnRH agonists due to their mechanism of action, which induces a hypoestrogenic state similar to menopause, leading to symptoms like hot flashes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness.

Topic: GnRH agonist therapy in Endometriosis

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 10 Endometriosis, Page no. 240

choices.text: By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from NCD's.
By 2030 reduce the neonatal mortality rate to at least as low as 12 per 1000 live births.
By 2030 reduce the under-five mortality rate to at least as low as 20 per 1000 live births.

questions.text: In December 2015, the millennium development goals (MDG's) came to an end and post 2015, 17 sustainable development goals (SDG's) took their place. All of the following are correct regarding targets under goal number 3 except?
questions.solution:
• Following targets have been kept under goal 3 of SDG
  • By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from NCD’s through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.
  • By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at-least as low as 12 per 1000 live births and under-5 mortality to at-least as low as 25 per 1000 live births.
  • By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical disease and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
  • Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol.
  • By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
  • By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.825.

questions.text: Which one of the following drug has narrow therapeutic index?
questions.solution:
• The therapeutic index (also known as therapeutic ratio), is a comparison of the amount of a therapeutic agent that causes the therapeutic effect to the amount that causes death.
  • A therapeutic index is the lethal dose of a drug for 50% of the population (LD50) divided by the minimum effective dose for 50% of the population (ED50).
  • Generally, a drug or other therapeutic agent with a narrow therapeutic range (i.e. with little difference between lethal and therapeutic doses) may have its dosage adjusted according to measurements of the actual blood levels achieved in the person taking it.
  • This may be achieved through therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) protocols.
  • Therapeutic window' is bounded by the dose which produces minimal therapeutic effect and the dose which produces maximal acceptable adverse effect

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is particularly useful in the following situations:

  1. Drugs with low safety margin, e.g. - digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycoside antibiotics, lithium, tricyclic antidepressants.
  2. If individual variations are large, e.g. - antidepressants, lithium.
  3. Potentially toxic drugs used in the presence of renal failure, e.g. - aminoglycoside antibiotics, vancomycin.
  4. In case of poisoning.
  5. In case of failure of response without any apparent reason, e.g. - antimicrobials.
  6. To check patient compliance, e.g. - psychopharmacological agents.

Monitoring of plasma concentration is of no value for

  1. Drugs whose response is easily measurable, e.g.- antihypertensives, hypoglycaemics, diuretics, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anaesthetics.
  2. Drugs activated in the body, e.g. - levodopa.
  3. 'Hit and run drugs' (whose effect lasts much longer than the drug itself), e.g. - reserpine, guanethidine, MAO inhibitors, omeprazole.
  4. Drugs with irreversible action, e.g. - organophosphate anticholinesterases, phenoxybenzamine.

Mnemonic

TDM is required for - ( A Drug Possessing Low Therapeutic Index)

Aminoglycosides

Digitalis

Phenytoin

Lithium

TCAs

Immunomodulators

Topic: Therapeutic index

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 65-66

questions.text: A kabadi player sustained injury and dislocated his right shoulder about 2 years back. Since then he has dislocated multiple times and his anterior apprehension test is positive. All of the following are soft tissue lesions associated with shoulder instability except :
questions.solution:
Bankart Lesion: (Option B)

  • Definition: Avulsion of the anterior-inferior capsulo-labral complex, extending into the scapular periosteum with rupture of periosteal tissue.
  • Occurrence: Found in 90% of patients with recurrent anterior shoulder instability.
  • Originally described by Bankart as the essential lesion for anterior shoulder instability.

Other Capsulolabral Lesions:

  • Perthes Lesion - Avulsion of anterior-inferior gleno-labral complex with preservation of medial scapular neck periosteum
  • ALPSA (Anterior Labroligamentous Periosteal Sleeve Avulsion) Lesion (Option C)
  • Avulsion of anterior-inferior glenolabral complex with stripping of medial scapular neck periosteum but preservation of a medial hinge; loose fragment subsequently scars medially down scapular neck
  • HAGL (Humeral Avulsion of the Glenohumeral Ligaments) Lesion: (Option D)
    • Incidence: 1% to 9% of cases.
    • Avulsion of glenohumeral ligaments from their humerus-side attachment
    • Treatment: Traditionally required open repair; newer arthroscopic techniques are being developed.

Osseous Pathoanatomy:

  • Glenoid Bone Loss:
    • Occurs in almost every patient with anterior shoulder instability.
    • Types:
      • Bony Bankart lesion (identifiable fragment with capsule-labral structures)
      • Impaction and erosion.
    • Presence: 40% in first dislocations, 85% in recurrent dislocations.
    • Significant bone loss (20%-25% of glenoid width, approximately 6-8 mm) is associated with higher recurrence rates post-Bankart repair.
    • Bony Bankart fragment absorbs rapidly within 1 year.
  • Hill-Sachs Lesion: (Option A)
    • Definition: Posterior-superior humeral head injury.
    • Occurrence:
      • 40% in recurrent subluxations without dislocations.
      • 90% in first dislocations.
      • Nearly 100% in recurrent dislocations.

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 816

choices.text: It indicates the organism's resistance to multiple antibiotics.
It helps in differentiating Vibrio parahaemolyticus from other vibrios in clinical diagnostics.
It signifies the presence of a toxin that causes severe gastrointestinal distress.
It confirms the organism's ability to ferment glucose in anaerobic conditions.

questions.text: What is the primary clinical significance of the Kanagawa phenomenon in relation to Vibrio parahaemolyticus?
questions.solution:
The Kanagawa phenomenon refers to the ability of certain strains of Vibrio parahaemolyticus to produce a hemolysin that causes beta-hemolysis (complete lysis of red blood cells) when cultured on Wagatsuma agar. This phenomenon is used as a diagnostic marker to differentiate pathogenic strains from non-pathogenic ones.

  • It indicates the organism's resistance to multiple antibiotics: Incorrect. The Kanagawa phenomenon is not related to antibiotic resistance.
  • It helps in differentiating Vibrio parahaemolyticus from other vibrios in clinical diagnostics: Correct. The Kanagawa phenomenon is used to identify and differentiate Vibrio parahaemolyticus based on its specific hemolytic activity on Kanagawa agar.
  • It signifies the presence of a toxin that causes severe gastrointestinal distress: Incorrect. The Kanagawa phenomenon is related to hemolytic activity, not to the production of toxins or gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • It confirms the organism's ability to ferment glucose in anaerobic conditions: Incorrect. The Kanagawa phenomenon is not related to glucose fermentation or anaerobic conditions.

Key Takeaway: The Kanagawa phenomenon is a diagnostic feature used to differentiate Vibrio parahaemolyticus from other vibrios based on its hemolytic activity on Kanagawa agar.

This phenomenon is important for distinguishing pathogenic strains in clinical microbiology and understanding the virulence factors of Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

Reference: "Medical Microbiology" by Murray, Rosenthal, and Pfaller and "Bacteroides and Related Genera" by Derek J. Brown.

questions.text: A 11-month-old child presented with an abdominal lump. He also underwent an abdominal X-ray which showed an ill-defined calcified soft tissue density lesion. On CT scan, a heterogeneously enhancing lesion with coarse calcification was seen in the suprarenal region. It was seen displacing the adjacent structures and showed extension into the spinal canal. What is the possible origin of the above mentioned lesion?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children, usually arising from the adrenal glands or sympathetic nervous system.

Imaging Modalities for Neuroblastoma:

  1. Ultrasound (USG)
    • Initial imaging in infants and younger children, especially for abdominal masses.
    • Findings: A well-defined, hypoechoic or heterogeneous mass in the adrenal gland or along the sympathetic chain. Calcifications within the tumor may be seen, a key feature of neuroblastoma.
  2. X-ray
    • Abdominal or chest X-rays may be used as a first step if a mass is suspected.
    • A soft tissue mass may be visible.
    • Calcifications are often seen in neuroblastoma tumors on plain films.
    • Displacement of adjacent structures (e.g., bowels or ribs) may be noted.
    • Thoracic neuroblastoma can cause rib erosion or widening of the mediastinum.
  3. Computed Tomography (CT) Scan
    • Findings:
      • A large, heterogeneous mass, usually with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.
      • Calcifications are seen in up to 85% of cases, which helps differentiate neuroblastoma from other adrenal masses, such as Wilms’ tumor.
      • Infiltration of adjacent structures: Neuroblastoma may encase blood vessels without causing thrombosis, which is an important diagnostic feature.
      • Lymphadenopathy: Enlarged retroperitoneal or mediastinal lymph nodes may indicate metastatic spread.
  4. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
    • MRI is useful for evaluating soft tissue involvement, especially in the spinal canal or paraspinal regions.
    • Findings:
      • Neuroblastomas typically appear as heterogeneous masses with varying signal intensities on T1 and T2-weighted images due to areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and calcification.
      • MRI is particularly helpful in cases where neuroblastoma causes spinal cord compression by extending through neural foramina into the spinal canal (paraspinal neuroblastoma).
  5. Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) Scan
    • MIBG scintigraphy is a specific nuclear medicine scan used to assess neuroblastoma because neuroblastoma cells selectively take up MIBG, a norepinephrine analog. Hence help in detecting metastasis.
  6. Bone Marrow Biopsy and Imaging
    • Neuroblastoma often metastasizes to the bone marrow. Bone marrow biopsies are essential for staging, and imaging may show involvement of the marrow on MIBG scans or FDG-PET.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Neuroblastoma -

  1. Primary Tumor:
    • Location: Commonly arises from the adrenal glands (65%) or sympathetic ganglia (along the spine).
    • Heterogeneous appearance: Due to areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, or calcification.
    • Calcifications: Seen on CT or plain X-rays, they are highly characteristic of neuroblastoma.
    • Encasement of vessels: Unlike other tumors, neuroblastoma can encase major vessels without causing obstruction or thrombosis, particularly in the retroperitoneum.
  2. Local Invasion:
    • Neuroblastoma can invade adjacent structures, including the kidneys, liver, and spinal canal (causing spinal cord compression).
  3. Metastasis:
    • Common sites: Bone, bone marrow, liver, and lymph nodes.
  4. Spinal Involvement:
    • Paraspinal neuroblastomas can grow through the intervertebral foramina, compressing the spinal cord, which can be well-visualized on MRI.
    • Dumbbell-shaped tumors extending from the spinal canal into the paraspinal region are typical in these cases.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1968.

questions.text: From medial to lateral, which of the following is correct sequence of the structures related to ala of sacrum?
questions.solution:
Ala of the sacrum:

  • The base of the sacrum is directed upward and forward. It is formed by the superior surface of the first sacral vertebra.
  • It is divided into three parts: Median part, right and left lateral parts.
    • The median part is formed by the oval upper surface of the body of the first sacral vertebra. Its anterior border is termed sacral promontory.
    • The right and left lateral parts are fan shaped and represent the upper surfaces of lateral masses of sacrum called alae.
    • The lateral masses represent the fused costal and transverse elements of the sacral vertebrae.
  • The smooth medial part of the ala of sacrum is related to the following four structures from lateral to medial side (OILS)
    • Obturator nerve, Iliolumbar artery, Lumbosacral trunk, Sympathetic chain
  • The ventral ramus of L5 nerve is so taut that it grooves the ala.
  • The rough lateral part of the ala gives origin to iliacus muscle anteriorly and attachment to the lumbosacral ligament posteriorly.

Topic: Bones of abdomen

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Volume-2, Page No – 16

questions.text: A bone tumor has a "Sun-ray" appearance on the radiograph. Microscopy reveals malignant tumor cells with spindle cell morphology producing osteoid bone which is fine and lacelike. Abundant abnormal mitoses and extensive necrosis are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• "Sun-ray" appearance on radiograph: This refers to a characteristic radiographic pattern seen in osteosarcoma, where the periosteal reaction forms a pattern resembling sun rays. This is due to the tumor's aggressive growth and bone destruction.
  • Spindle cell morphology: Osteosarcoma typically consists of spindle-shaped cells with atypical mitoses and osteoid production with fine and lace like pattern.

B. Ewing's sarcoma: Typically has a "moth-eaten" appearance on radiograph and consists of small, round, blue cells.

C. Chondrosarcoma: Typically has a "rings and arcs" calcification pattern on radiograph and consists of cartilaginous matrix and binucleate cells.

D. Fibrosarcoma: Typically has a more benign appearance on radiograph and consists of fibroblasts with a storiform pattern.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1188.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was operated for open inguinal hernia repair by Lichtenstein's repair. What is the most common complication of open flat mesh repair ?
questions.solution:
Randomised trials show that hernia recurrence within the first 2 years is lower but acute pain scores are similar. Recent research comparing Lichtenstein’s repair with laparoscopic surgery has identified chronic pain as the most common complication of open fat mesh repair with rates reported as high as 20 % .

Reference: Bailey and love’s short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 64 ; page 1068,1069.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. On examination, she has a tender abdomen and cervical motion tenderness. A urine pregnancy test is positive, and a transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine pregnancy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a positive pregnancy test with no intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound suggests an ectopic pregnancy (OPTION C), most commonly located in the fallopian tube.

Threatened miscarriage (OPTION A) typically presents with bleeding but with an intrauterine pregnancy visible on ultrasound.

Complete miscarriage (OPTION C) would show an empty uterus with prior evidence of pregnancy loss. There will not be cervical tenderness either.

A molar pregnancy (OPTION D) usually presents with abnormal bleeding and markedly elevated hCG levels, and an ultrasound would show a “snowstorm” pattern without an embryo.

Topic: Ectopic pregnancy

Reference: Dutta’s Obstetrics 9th edition, Chapter 16 Haemorrhage in early pregnancy Page no. 213

questions.text: The criminal responsibility of mentally ill person is dealt under
questions.solution:
The criminal responsibility of mentally ill person is dealt under Sec. 22 of BNS

Sec. 20 BNS:- Act of a child under seven years of age. - Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

Sec. 22 BNS:- Act of a person of unsound mind.—Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

Sec. 23 BNS:- Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxica¬tion caused against his will.—Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong, or contrary to law; provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.

Sec. 24 BNS:- Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.—In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowl¬edge or against his will.

Reference: The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha, 2023

choices.text: Net sensitivity and net specificity both are increased.
Net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased.
Net sensitivity remains the same and net specificity is increased.
Net sensitivity is increased and net specificity is decreased.

questions.text: If the Hemoccult test result is negative, no further testing is done. If the Hemoccult test result is positive, the individual will have a second stool sample tested with the hemoccult II test. If this second sample also tests positive for blood, the individual will be referred for more extensive evaluation. What is the effect on net sensitivity and net specificity of this method of screening?
questions.solution:
• Sequential two stage screening: - In a sequential two stage screening, a less expensive, less invasive or less uncomfortable test is generally performed first, and those who screen positive are recalled for further testing with a more expensive, more invasive, or more uncomfortable test. Use of tests in a sequence results in a gain in net specificity and loss in net sensitivity.
  • Simultaneous testing: - When two simultaneous tests are used, there is a net gain in sensitivity and there is a net loss in specificity. When multiple tests are used simultaneously to detect a specific disease, the individual is generally considered positive if he or she has a positive result on any one or more of the tests, and negative if he or she tests negative on all of the tests.

Reference: Gordis Epidemiology 6th/e page no. 101, 105.

questions.text: The image displays a child with a vesicular rash on the trunk and face, with lesions in different stages of development (papules, vesicles, and crusts). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Appearance: Begins as small, red macules that quickly evolve into papules, then vesicles, and finally pustules before crusting over.

Distribution: Starts on the trunk and spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities ("centripetal distribution").

Polymorphic: Different stages of the rash (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) appear simultaneously.

Itchy: Highly pruritic (itchy), leading to scratching, which can cause secondary bacterial infection.

Lesions: Vesicles are described as "dew drop on a rose petal" due to their clear, fluid-filled nature on a red base.

Contagious Phase: Rash is highly contagious from 1-2 days before the rash appears until all vesicles have crusted over.

Duration: Rash usually lasts 5-7 days

Explanation of Options:

  • A) Chickenpox (Varicella): Characterized by a vesicular rash with lesions in various stages of development (papules, vesicles, and crusts).
  • B) Shingles: Presents with a vesicular rash limited to one side of the body in a dermatomal pattern, not widespread on the trunk and face.
  • C) Hand-foot-mouth disease: Typically presents with vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks, not the trunk and face. Caused by Coxsackie A16 and Enterovirus 71.
  • D) Impetigo: Usually presents with honey-colored crusted lesions rather than vesicular rash.

Key Takeaway: Chickenpox is characterized by a vesicular rash with lesions at different stages of development across the trunk and face.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Chickenpox (Varicella)." CDC, updated August 29, 2023. Available at: CDC Chickenpox

questions.text: A 64 year old male patient came to surgery department with history of chronic analgesic consumption with development of peptic ulceration. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of peptic ulcer caused due to chronic use of NSAIDs?
questions.solution:
• Esomeprazole is a weak base and is concentrated and converted to the active form in the highly acidic environment of the secretory canaliculi of the parietal cell, where it inhibits the enzyme H+K+-ATPase ¨C the acid pump and inhibits both basal and stimulated acid secretion.
  • PPIs are the drugs of choice for NSAID induced gastric/duodenal ulcers Maintenance PPI treatment reduces recurrence of NSAID associated ulcer

Uses of PPIs

  1. Peptic ulcer:
    • PPIs are an integral component of anti-H. pylori therapy
    • PPIs are the drugs of choice for NSAID induced gastric/duodenal ulcers
    • Maintenance PPI treatment reduces recurrence of NSAID associated ulcer. Ulcer complications like perforation, and bleeding are also reduced.
  1. Bleeding peptic ulcer:
    • Acid enhances clot dissolution promoting ulcer bleed.
    • Suppression of gastric acid has been found to facilitate clot formation reducing blood loss and rebleed.
  1. Stress ulcers:
    • Intravenous pantoprazole/rabeprazole are at least as effective prophylactic (if not more) for stress ulcers as i.v. H2 blockers
  1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):
    • PPIs are the drugs of choice. Higher doses than that for peptic ulcer, or twice daily dosing is generally needed.
  1. 5. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome:
    • It is a gastric hypersecretory state due to ‘gastrinoma’, a rare tumour secreting gastrin, which presents with difficult to heal gastric/duodenal ulcer(s).
  1. Aspiration pneumonia:
    • PPIs are an alternative to H2 blockers for prophylaxis of aspiration pneumonia due to prolonged anaesthesia.

Summary of drugs used for acid-peptic disease

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 701

questions.solution:
DNA Polymerase in eukaryotic have specific actions in DNA Replication.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male with established alcoholic liver disease scheduled for open reduction and internal fixation with plating for proximal fractures of the right radius and ulna under brachial plexus block using local anesthetics, which drug can be administered safely without requiring dose adjustment?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of fracture of the radius and ulna for which the patient is posted for open reduction and internal fixation under the brachial plexus block.
  • Ester local anesthetics undergo hydrolysis by cholinesterase enzyme principally in the plasma and, to a lesser extent, in the liver.
  • So procaine, a local ester anesthetic, can be given in patients with hepatic dysfunction with little dose adjustment.
  • The rate of hydrolysis varies, with chloroprocaine being the most rapid, procaine being intermediate, and tetracaine being the slowest.
  • The exception to hydrolysis of ester local anesthetics in the plasma is cocaine, which undergoes significant metabolism in the liver.
  • Severe liver disease may slow the clearance of the amino amide local anesthetics, and significant drug levels may accumulate.
  • So dose reduction of amino amide local anesthetics is necessary for hepatic dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lignocaine:

  • Lignocaine metabolizes in the liver primarily by oxidative dealkylation, followed by hydrolysis to silicide.
  • Lignocaine, an amino amide local anesthetic drug, needs dose adjustment in chronic liver diseases.

Option B - Bupivacaine:

  • Metabolism of bupivacaine includes aromatic hydroxylation, N-dealkylation, amide hydrolysis, and conjugation in the liver.
  • Bupivacaine is an amino amide local anesthetic and needs dose adjustment in patients with chronic hepatic diseases.

Option C - Cocaine:

  • The exception to the hydrolysis of ester local anesthetics in the plasma is cocaine.
  • Cocaine undergoes significant metabolism in the liver using hepatic carboxylesterase and is partially excreted unchanged in the urine.

Topic: Local Anesthetics

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia,9th edition, Page no. 885

questions.text: A 42 years old female patient presented to OPD with complain of diffuse erythema and skin oedema of involving more than one-third of the breast.What is your diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of inflammatory breast carcinoma

B. Inflammatory Breast Carcinoma (IBC):

  • Definition: A rare and aggressive form of breast cancer that blocks lymph vessels in the skin of the breast.
  • Symptoms: Red, swollen, warm breast, thickening of the skin, often mistaken for infection (mastitis).
  • Diagnosis: Clinical exam, biopsy, imaging (mammogram, ultrasound, MRI), PET/CT for staging.
  • Treatment: Multimodal approach with chemotherapy, surgery, radiation, and possibly targeted therapy.

Option A: Breast Abscess

  • Definition: A localized collection of pus in the breast tissue, usually caused by bacterial infection.
  • Causes: Commonly seen in breastfeeding women (lactational abscess) or in non-lactating women with underlying mastitis.
  • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, redness, warmth over the affected area, fever, and a fluctuant mass.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical examination, ultrasound to confirm the presence of pus.
  • Treatment: Antibiotics, drainage of pus (either by needle aspiration or surgical incision).

Option C: Phyllodes tumor:

  • Definition: A rare, fast-growing breast tumor that arises from the connective tissue (stroma) of the breast.
  • Types: Can be benign, borderline, or malignant.
  • Symptoms: Painless, rapidly growing breast lump.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical exam, imaging (mammogram, ultrasound), confirmed by biopsy.
  • Treatment: Surgical removal (lumpectomy or mastectomy), recurrence is possible especially in malignant cases.

Option D: Mondor’s Disease:

  • Definition: A benign, self-limiting condition characterized by thrombophlebitis (inflammation and clotting) of the superficial veins of the breast and chest wall.
  • Symptoms: Painful, cord-like structure felt under the skin along the course of the veins.
  • Causes: Often triggered by trauma, surgery, infection, or tight clothing.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical exam, ultrasound to confirm venous involvement.
  • Treatment: Conservative management with warm compresses, NSAIDs (anti-inflammatory drugs), and symptoms typically resolve within a few weeks.

Reference: Bailey and love’s short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58 ; page 922,928,930, 932.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct sequence of structures arranged in the root of right lumen from above downwards?
questions.solution:
The arrangement of structures in the roots of the lungs is as follows:

  • From before backwards (it is more or less similar on both sides):
    • Pulmonary vein (superior)
    • Pulmonary artery
    • Bronchus (left principal bronchus on the left side and hyparterial bronchus on the right side)
    • Mnemonic: VAB (Vein, Artery, and Bronchus)
  • From above downwards (it differs on two sides):
    • Right side: (BABV)
      • Eparterial bronchus
      • Pulmonary artery
      • Hyparterial bronchus
      • Inferior pulmonary vein
    • Left side (ABV)
      • Pulmonary artery
      • Left principal bronchus
      • Inferior pulmonary vein
  • The difference in the arrangement of structures from above downwards on the two sides is because right principal bronchus before entering the lung at hilum divides into two lobar bronchi.
  • The upper lobar bronchus (eparterial) passes above the pulmonary artery and lower lobar bronchus (hyparterial) passes below the pulmonary artery.

Topic: The Lungs

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Volume-1, Page No – 244

questions.text: A 60 year old female patient presented with complaint of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. She was diagnosed as having Acoustic neuroma. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
• M/c benign tumor of cerebellopontine (CP) angle.
  • Origin: Internal acoustic meatus (Schwannoma of vestibular nerve). Very slow growing tumor.

C/F:

  • U/L SNHL (Slow progression) + tinnitus in elderly (B/L & young in NF2).

Nerve involvement :

  1. CN 8 followed by CN 5 (Earliest sign: Loss of corneal reflex).
  2. Hitzelberger sign (CN 7) : Anaesthesia of posterosuperior part of external

auditory canal.

  1. CN 5, 6 : At upper pole of CP angle.
  2. CN 9, 10, 11 : At lower pole of CP angle.

Ix :

  • Pure tone audiometry: U/L or asymmetrical SNHL.
  • BERA (Best audiometric test): Interaural latency of wave V > 0.2 ms, ↑ Latency b/w waves I-V.
  • SISI - <20%

MRI : gadolinium enhanced MRI (IOC) - (Ice cream cone appearance).

Mx :

  • Slow growing → Observation.
  • Cystic tumors (Antoni B on histology) → Sx.
  • Postop rehabilitation → Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI) in the lateral recess of 4th ventricle

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition pg 134.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of intermittent inward deviation of his left eye, especially during periods of fatigue. His parents report that he often closes his left eye in bright sunlight and sometimes tilts his head to the right to see better. On examination, visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/25 in the left eye. The cover-uncover test shows a left esotropia of 30 prism diopters at distance and 20 prism diopters at near, suggesting a significant accommodative component.

Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to assess the underlying cause of the child's esotropia?
questions.solution:
• CT scan of the orbits: While useful in assessing structural anomalies, a CT scan is not the first-line investigation in a case of suspected esotropia without any neurological signs or trauma.
  • Visual field testing: This is primarily indicated in cases where there is suspicion of a neurological cause or compressive lesions affecting the optic nerve or pathways, which is not the case here.
  • Electrophysiological testing: While helpful in evaluating retinal or optic nerve function, this testing does not address the specific mechanics of strabismus or accommodation issues directly relevant to esotropia.

Cycloplegic Refraction with Accommodation Testing:

In this scenario, cycloplegic refraction is essential to rule out any significant hyperopia that might be causing accommodative esotropia. The investigation involves:

  1. Cycloplegic Refraction:
    • Identifies hidden hyperopia, which is common in children with esotropia.
    • Determines the need for corrective lenses.
  2. Accommodation Testing:
    • Assesses how the child’s eyes respond under different focusing conditions.
    • Evaluates whether the esotropia is primarily accommodative or if it has a non-accommodative component.

References: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th edition, Chapter 14, Strabismus, pg. 701.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and had pain in the perineal region. Anal swabs were taken and showed needle-shaped crystals with Picric acid. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Due to the presence of spermine (from prostate )in seminal fluid, yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate are formed when treated with picric acid.

Incorrect Options –

Option B – Creatine phosphokinase -Can detect 6 months old semen.

Option C - Acid phosphatase –(Walker test )Done for aspermia. Value >100 bodinski units indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 hours of examination

Option D- Florence Test – Due to presence of choline (seminal vesicle) in seminal fluid, dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide appear when treated with Florence reagent

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Due to the presence of spermine (from prostate )in seminal fluid, yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate are formed when treated with picric acid.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 434

choices.text: Both A and B can be used.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male painter, suddenly complained of colicky abdominal pain, on taking further history he told he had constipation from last 1 week associated with the loss of appetite. Investigations shows anaemia and stippling of RBC. On examination you saw the finding given in below picture, what will be the main chelating agent used for this condition?
questions.solution:
• All the symptoms, and findings mentioned above are classical of lead poisoning.
  • Lead probably exerts its toxic action by combining with an essential SH-group of certain enzymes, for example enzymes involved in porphyrin synthesis and carbohydrate metabolism.
  • Lead also has an effect on membrane permeability and potassium leakage has been demonstrated from erythrocytes exposed to lead.
  • Signs and symptoms include: - anaemia, blue line on gums, basophilic stippling, colicky pain, wrist and foot drop, encephalopathy, facial pallor.
  • Diagnosis is done by measuring coproporphyrin in urine, amino levulinic acid in urine, lead in blood and urine, basophilic stippling of RBC.
  • Treatment is done saline purge and use D-penicillamine/Ca-EDTA as a chelating agent

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.935.

questions.text: A patient presents with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
C. Hairy cell leukemia:

  • Characterized by massive splenomegaly
  • Pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration by hairy cells
  • "Hairy" cells on peripheral smear

A. MPN typically presents with elevated cell counts, not pancytopenia.

B. MDS has distinct bone marrow findings and doesn't typically cause massive splenomegaly.

D. Gaucher disease has a different pathophysiology and doesn't typically cause pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 603

questions.text: The image shows a patient with painful oral ulcers and a fever. The ulcers are surrounded by a halo of erythema and are located on the mucosa of the mouth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

  • A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV) stomatitis: Presents with painful oral ulcers, often surrounded by a halo of erythema, and is commonly associated with fever.
  • B) Hand-foot-mouth disease: Usually presents with oral ulcers along with a rash on the hands and feet.
  • C) Canker sores (Aphthous ulcers): Generally non-infectious, not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever.
  • D) Thrush: Caused by Candida species and presents as white patches in the mouth rather than painful ulcers.

Key Takeaway: Painful oral ulcers with a surrounding erythema and fever suggest herpes simplex virus (HSV) stomatitis.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Herpes Simplex." CDC, updated August 29, 2023. Available at: CDC Herpes Simplex

questions.solution:

Option A: Galactokinase deficiency leads to elevation of Blood Galactose causing Galactosemia and cataract.

questions.text: Identify the epithelium in the structure shown in the figure below:
questions.solution:
• The diagram is showing the small intestine (ileum).
  • The wall of the small intestine consists of four layers.
  • From within outward, these are:
    • Mucosa
    • Submucosa
    • Muscle layer
    • Serosa
  • Mucosa:
    • It is lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells.
    • The mucosa presents the following three relevant features.
    • Plicae circulares (or valves of Kerckring): These are circular folds, which are permanent and are not obliterated by distension.
    • Villi: The surface of circular folds is thrown into small (0.5 mm or less in length) finger-like projections called villi.
    • Microvilli: The surface epithelium covering the villi presents microvilli (or striated border).
  • Intestinal Glands (Crypts of Lieberkuhn)
    • In between the bases of villi, the epithelium is invaginated in the lamina propria to form intestinal glands. They secrete digestive enzymes and mucous.
  • Lymphatic Follicles
    • The lamina propria of the mucous membrane contains:
      • They form circular or oval patches called Peyer's
    • Submucosa:
      • It is made up of loose areolar tissue and contains blood vessels, lymph vessels, and nerve plexus (Meissner's plexus).
    • Muscle Layer
      • It is made up of outer longitudinal and inner circular layers of smooth muscle.
      • Auerbach's plexus of nerves is present between these two layers.
    • Serosa
      • It is formed by the visceral peritoneum and is lined by the simple squamous epithelium.

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page No - 183, 186, 187

questions.text: A 23 year student presents with deformity at the elbow joint as shown in the image below. He also gives a history of sustaining an injury to the elbow after a fall from tree and was treated by a bone settler in his village. Select the false treatment option for this case.

questions.text: Which antileprosy medicine causes pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Option B. Clofazimine:

Clofazimine is an antileprosy drug that is known to cause pigmentation of the skin.

It can lead to a reddish-brown to black (mahogany red) discoloration of the skin, which is a well-recognized side effect of the medication.

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids (such as urine, sweat, and tears) but does not typically cause pigmentation of the skin itself.

Option C: Dapsone: Dapsone is another antileprosy drug, and while it can cause side effects such as hemolytic anemia and hypersensitivity reactions, it does not generally cause pigmentation.

Option D: Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used for various infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with pigmentation changes in the skin.

Thus, clofazimine is the antileprosy medication known for causing skin pigmentation.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, pg no 88.25

questions.text: During a psychiatric evaluation, a patient displays a communication style characterized by speaking rapidly, providing excessive details, and occasionally getting sidetracked. However, they eventually return to the main topic and answer the question. This phenomenon is known as:
questions.solution:
• Prolixity refers to a communication style where thoughts are moving fast, but their speed is less than flight of ideas. The patient speaks rapidly, provides excessive details, and occasionally gets sidetracked. However, they eventually return to the main topic and answer the question. This matches the described scenario, making it the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Flight of ideas

  • Flight of ideas is a communication pattern where thoughts follow each other rapidly, and the person may not be able to answer questions because their thoughts are flowing very quickly. They may exhibit illogical and rhyming associations. The described scenario involves the patient returning to the main topic and answering the question, which does not align with a flight of ideas.

Option C - Circumstantiality

  • Circumstantiality involves providing excessive and unnecessary details in communication, occasionally getting sidetracked, but ultimately returning to the main topic and answering the question. The thinking proceeds slowly here. Although the scenario shares some similarities with circumstantiality, the term "prolixity" more specifically describes rapid speech and excessive details.

Option D - Tangentiality

  • Tangentiality refers to a communication pattern where the person goes off on tangents and never returns to the main topic or fully answers the question. This is different from the described scenario, where the patient eventually returns to the main topic and answers the question.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry - 12th Edition - Page no 9,10

questions.text: A 46-year-old male comes to clinic complaining of day time sleepiness and lack of energy. He snores loudly while sleeping and sometimes suddenly stops breathing. There is chance of increased risk of developing
questions.solution:
• Patient has obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
  • OSA is associated with an increased risk of developing hypertension. The repeated episodes of hypoxia (low oxygen levels) and fragmented sleep lead to sympathetic nervous system activation, resulting in elevated blood pressure. Over time, this can contribute to the development of persistent hypertension.

  • Option B) OSA does not directly increase the risk of developing bronchial asthma. However, patients with OSA may have worse asthma symptoms due to the impact of poor sleep quality and intermittent hypoxia on airway reactivity.
  • Option C) There is no direct link between OSA and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), a condition characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle (usually the left ventricle), which can lead to outflow obstruction.
  • Option D) Bronchiectasis involves permanent dilation and damage to the bronchi, often due to chronic infection or inflammation. It is not directly linked to OSA.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1526

choices.text: Binding of the tRNA anticodon to the mRNA codon follows complementary or Antiparallel Binding
A mechanism by which tRNA can Recognize more than one codon for a specific amino acid
61 tRNA species are require to read 61 codon

questions.text: In codon recognition, Wobble Hypothesis is _____?
questions.solution:
In translation process, Correct pairing of the codon in the mRNA with the anticodon of the tRNA is essential which is complementary and antiparallel.

  • Codon recognition by tRNA, wobble hypothesis state that a tRNA can recognize more than one codon for a specific amino acid.
  • Codon and anticodon pairing follows the traditional Watson crick rules for the first two bases of the codon but can be less stringent for the last base.
  • Movement of first base allows non traditional base pairing with the 3' base of the codon (the last base of codon). This is called wobble hypothesis. Due to this movement a single tRNA can recognize more than one codon.

Option A : Binding of the tRNA anticodon to the mRNA codon is both complementary and antiparallel, meaning the nucleotide bases pair complementarily (A with U, G with C) while the strands are oriented in opposite directions (antiparallel)."

Option C : Incorrect: The wobble hypothesis explains how fewer than 61 tRNAs can recognize multiple codons. The anticodon of some tRNAs can pair with more than one codon because the third base of the codon (the "wobble" position) can sometimes form non-standard base pairs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Wobble hypothesis-first 2 nucleotides of codon are essential for anticodon recognition while the 3rd nucleotide can differ ('wobble').

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SAE edition Chapter 37 Page 639

questions.text: All of the following scoring systems are used for assessment of severity for acute pancreatitis except?
questions.solution:
The Ranson and Glasgow scoring systems are specific for acute pancreatitis, and a score of 3 or more at 48 hours indicates a severe attack.

Several other systems that are used in intensive care units can also be applied.

These include the APACHE, SAPS, SOFA, MODS and modified Marshall scoring systems (the latter has the advantage of simplicity). Regardless of the system used, persisting organ failure indicates a severe attack.

A serum C-reactive protein level >150 mg/L at 48 hours after the onset of symptoms is also an indicator of severity. Patients with a body mass index over 30 are at higher risk of developing complications.

Mallampatti classification is used for airway assessment .

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 72 ; page 1271.

L - Leucocytes

I - Increased

T - Tremors (Most common side effect)

I - Increased Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, can be used for the treatment of SIADH.

M should be avoided in expectant Mothers as it causes Ebstein's anomaly

questions.text: A young female consults you for generalized weakness. Evaluation reveals anaemia. Peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anaemia, serum iron is 50 mcg/dL, TIBC is 200 ug/dL, Transferrin saturation is 20% and serum ferritin is 20 ug/L. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given are the salient features of differential diagnoses of microcytic anemia:


Pointers to clinch diagnosis:

In thalassemia and sideroblastic anemia, serum iron levels are typically normal or elevated. In contrast, serum iron is decreased in iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and anemia of chronic disease (ACD). Given the near-normal serum iron in our case, both conditions are possible.

The Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC) normal range is 250-450 µg/dL. Our patient's TIBC is decreased. TIBC is elevated in IDA, normal in sideroblastic anemia and thalassemia, and decreased in ACD. Therefore, the decreased TIBC suggests that the patient most likely has anemia of chronic disease.

Iron Studies Normal Ranges

  • Serum Iron:
    • Adults: 60-170 µg/dL
  • Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC):
    • Adults: 240-450 µg/dL
  • Transferrin Saturation:
    • Adults: 20-50%
  • Serum Ferritin:
    • Adults: 30-300 ng/mL
  • Transferrin:
    • Adults: 200-360 mg/dL

Notes:

  • Serum Iron: Measures the amount of iron in the blood.
  • TIBC: Indicates the blood's ability to bind and transport iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation: Ratio of serum iron to TIBC; reflects the proportion of iron-binding sites occupied by iron.
  • Serum Ferritin: Reflects the body's iron stores

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 751

choices.text: Compression of the third cranial nerve

questions.text: Rena a 38 year old female is presented to the emergency ward with severe headache and altered consciousness. A CT scan reveals large mass in temporal lobe producing uncal herniation. Which of the following features may be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
• The uncus of the temporal lobe over the edge of the cerebellar tentorium occurs due to space occupying lesions from large tumors, hemorrhage, stroke, abscess.
  • Option B-Uncal herniation often causes compression of the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve), which is located near the tentorial notch.
  • This compression can result in
    • ipsilateral (same side) pupillary dilation
    • ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), and
    • an eye that is "down and out" due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Option A - Biot's respiration is an abnormal breathing pattern characterized by groups of quick, shallow breaths followed by periods of apnea.
  • It is usually associated with damage to the medulla or pons in the brainstem and is not typically seen in uncal herniation

KEY TAKEAWAYS- BRAIN HERNIATION SYNDROMES

  • Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation under falx cerebri: Can compress anterior cerebral artery
  • Central/downward transtentorial herniation: Caudal displacement of brainstem -> rupture of paramedian basilar artery branches -> Duret hemorrhages. Usually fatal.
  • Uncal transtentorial herniation: Uncus = medial temporal lobe.
    • Early herniation -> ipsilateral blown pupil (unilateral CN III compression), contralateral hemiparesis.
    • Late herniation -> coma, Kernohan phenomenon (misleading contralateral blown pupil and ipsilateral hemiparesis due to contralateral compression against Kernohan notch).
  • Cerebellar tonsillar herniation into the foramen magnum: Coma and death result when these herniations compress the brainstem.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.559

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding origin of thyroid blood supply except
questions.solution:
• The superior thyroid arteries arise from the ipsilateral external carotid arteries and divide into anterior and posterior branches at the apices of the thyroid lobes.

Option B :

  • The inferior thyroid arteries arise from the thyrocervical trunk shortly after their origin from the subclavian arteries. The inferior thyroid arteries travel upward in the neck posterior to the carotid sheath to enter the thyroid lobes at their midpoint.

Option C :

  • A thyroidea ima artery arises directly from the aorta or innominate in 1% to 4% of individuals to enter the isthmus or replace a missing inferior thyroid artery. The inferior thyroid artery crosses the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), necessitating identification of the RLN before the arterial branches can be ligated.

questions.text: All of the following are morphological features of Papillary thyroid carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Nuclei shows fine dispersed chromatin and not smudged chromatin. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that exhibits distinct microscopic features, including:

  • Papillae: Finger-like projections of tumor cells supported by a fibrovascular core.
  • Ground-glass nuclei: Enlarged, pale, and clear nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin with a characteristic "Orphan Annie eye" appearance.

  • Nuclear grooves and pseudo inclusions: Deep grooves and pseudoinclusions (invaginations) in the nuclear membrane.
  • Psammoma bodies: Small, round, laminated calcifications (often seen in the papillae).
  • Multinucleation: Presence of multiple nuclei within a single cell.
  • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions: Cytoplasmic material within the nucleus.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1088.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with FIGO stage IB1 cervical cancer wishes to preserve fertility. Which surgical option is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
As per FIGO guidelines TAH+BSO would be the most appropriate management

OPTION A. Total abdominal hysterectomy + Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy involves the removal of the uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries, which completely eliminates the possibility of future fertility. This option is not suitable for a patient wishing to preserve fertility.

OPTION B. Radical trachelectomy (Correct Answer)

Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-sparing surgical option that involves the removal of the cervix and upper part of the vagina while preserving the uterus. This procedure is appropriate for young women with early-stage cervical cancer (like FIGO stage IB1) who wish to maintain fertility, making it the most suitable option in this scenario.

OPTION C. Radical hysterectomy

Radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus, cervix, part of the vagina, and surrounding tissues, which prevents any future possibility of pregnancy. Therefore, it is not a fertility-preserving option and is not suitable for this patient.

OPTION D. Chemoradiation

Chemoradiation is a non-surgical treatment that combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy. While effective for cervical cancer, it severely affects ovarian function and uterine integrity, thereby eliminating fertility. This option is not suitable for a patient who desires to preserve fertility.

Radical trachelectomy is the best surgical option for a woman with FIGO stage IB1 cervical cancer who wishes to preserve fertility, as it allows for the removal of cancerous tissue while retaining the uterus for potential future pregnancies.

Type: Must know

Topic: Fertility sparing surgeries

Reference: Williams Gyanecology 3rd edition, Chapter 30 Cervical Cancer, Page no. 670

questions.text: A young biker sustained a road traffic accident and severe injury to his left elbow. He was taken to the nearest tertiary care centre where a scan was performed which mentioned that he had a terrible triad injury of the elbow. What three injuries make up the"terrible triad" of the elbow?
questions.solution:
• Involves three combined injuries typically resulting from a fracture-dislocation: (Options A,B,C, and D)
    1. Radial Head Fracture
    2. Coronoid Process Fracture
    3. Elbow Dislocation (mostly due to rupture of LCL ligament)
  • Indicates an unstable elbow joint.
  • Requires surgical stabilization for proper management.
  • Associated with worse functional outcomes due to the complexity of injuries.
  • Additional structures may also be injured, complicating treatment and recovery.

Treatment:

  • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) of the coronoid process.
  • ORIF or prosthetic replacement of the radial head.
  • Lateral ± medial ligamentous repair.

If Persistent Instability:

  • Use a hinged external fixator or trans articular ulno-humeral pinning.

Postoperative Management:

  • Early range of motion (ROM) is initiated, based on the intraoperative arc of stability.
  • For the Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) repaired and the Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) intact:
    • Keep the elbow in forearm pronation to increase stability (pronation reduces stress on LCL).
  • For LCL repaired but MCL deficient:
    • Keep the elbow in forearm supination to increase stability (supination reduces stress on MCL).
  • For both LCL and MCL repaired:
    • Keep the elbow in a neutral position.

Upper limb trauma/Must-know

Tag: Easy

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1613

questions.text: According to CDC guidelines, which virus is most commonly associated with acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A virus (HAV), a non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus from the Picornaviridae family., which spreads via the faeco-oral route.

Incubation Period: 15-50 days

Clinical Features:

  • Acute onset of symptoms, often preceded by a prodromal phase with nonspecific symptoms like fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort.
  • After the prodrome, jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes), dark urine, pale stools, and pruritus (itching) develop.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and right upper quadrant tenderness are common.
  • Self-limiting: Most patients recover fully within weeks to months; chronic infection does not occur

Explanation:

  • A. HIV: Causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and is not typically associated with acute hepatitis.
  • B. HAV: A common cause of acute viral hepatitis, transmitted through contaminated food and water.
  • C. HSV: Causes herpes simplex infections, primarily affecting the skin and mucous membranes.
  • D. VZV: Causes chickenpox and shingles, not primarily hepatitis.

Key Takeaway: Hepatitis A Virus (HAV) is commonly associated with acute viral hepatitis, often spread through contaminated food and water.

Tag Line: Moderate

questions.text: A 54 year old Black woman was admitted to the hospital because of joint pain and erythematous maculopapular lesions on her neck, upper chest, and elbows. The patient was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus 5 months earlier and had been receiving piroxicam since then. After further examination, another drug was added to her current pharmacotherapy. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to administer at this time?
questions.solution:
The pharmacotherapy of SLE includes following drugs

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Antimalarials (Hydroxychloroquine)
  • Immunosuppressants and
  • Glucocorticoids

Antimalarials such as hydroxychloroquine are especially effective when the disease is mild and skin manifestations are prominent, as in this case.

  • This drug has been shown to prevent relapses and to reduce morbidity and mortality.
  • The mechanism of action of hydroxychloroquine is still unclear but is likely related to its anti-inflammatory properties.
  • A combination of an antimalarial and an NSAID is sometimes used in mild cases.
  • However, a combination of glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive drugs is a first-line pharmacotherapy for treatment of severe SLE.

Their proposed mechanism of actions are :

  • Reduce monocyte IL-I, consequently inhibiting B lymphocytes.
  • Interfering with Antigen processing
  • Lysosomal stabilization and free radical scavenging
  • Uses
    1. Oral CQ causes rapid fever clearance and disappearance of parasitaemia in patients of malaria caused by all P.ovale and P.malariae, most P.vivax and some P.falciparum that are still sensitive.
    2. Extraintestinal amoebiasis
    3. Rheumatoid arthritis
    4. Discoid lupus erythematosus
    5. Lepra reaction
    6. Photogenic reactions.
    7. Infectious mononucleosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 880

questions.text: Which of the following scores is used for identifying patients at high risk of sepsis for patients admitted in non-ICU settings (ward and emergency department)?
questions.solution:
• To aid in early identification of infected patients, the quick SOFA (q-SOFA) and the National Early Warning Score (NEWS) scores are proposed as clinical prompts to identify patients at high risk of sepsis outside the ICU, whether on the medical ward or in the emergency department.


APACHE score consists of :

  • Body Temperature
  • Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)
  • Heart Rate
  • Respiratory Rate
  • Arterial pH
  • Serum Sodium
  • Serum Potassium
  • Serum Creatinine
  • Hematocrit
  • White Blood Cell Count (WBC)
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

0-8: Low risk

9-14: Moderate risk

15-19: High risk

20+: Very high risk

These components are used to evaluate the severity of illness and predict outcomes for critically ill patients.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2188

questions.text: A known case of bronchial asthma presents with acute onset increased dyspnoea following dust exposure. He is brought to emergency. Examination shows respiratory rate>30 and there is no wheeze audible. Which of the following is first to be given for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Assessment and Initial Management:

  • As per the question,Respiratory rate (RR) > 30 with a silent chest indicates acute severe asthma.

Urgent Care Setting:

  • Assess Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) or Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1).

Treatment:

  • Administer nebulized β2-agonists every 20 minutes as needed.
  • Patients with PEFR > 60% of predicted will often respond to β2-agonists alone.
  • If no response in 1-2 hours:
  • Administer intravenous corticosteroids.
  • Administer supplemental oxygen to correct hypoxemia.
  • Consider administering a Leukotriene Receptor Antagonist (LTRA) and magnesium.
  • Nebulized anticholinergics can be given for additional bronchodilation.

Further Actions:

  • If PEFR remains ≤ 60% or there is persistent severe tachypnea over 4-6 hours:
  • Consider hospital admission.

In-Hospital Treatment:

  • Continuous Management:
    • Administer continuous bronchodilator nebulization.
    • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation may be used to assist with respiratory exhaustion and prevent the need for intubation.
    • Helium-oxygen mixtures may be used to reduce the work of breathing.
  • Antibiotics:
    • Administer only if there are signs of infection.

Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine Pg no. 2158

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of fibroids presents with acute severe pelvic pain. Ultrasound shows a 10 cm pedunculated subserosal fibroid with evidence of torsion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Pedunculated subserous fibroid can cause torsion leading to severe acute pain abdomen and hence immediate surgery is required to remove it.

OPTION A. Observation and analgesia

Observation and analgesia are not appropriate in this case because torsion of a fibroid is a surgical emergency. Delaying intervention can lead to necrosis, infection, or severe complications, making observation insufficient and unsafe.

OPTION B. Immediate surgical intervention (Correct Answer)

Immediate surgical intervention is the correct management for a torsioned pedunculated fibroid, especially with severe acute pain. Surgery, usually a myomectomy, is necessary to untwist or remove the fibroid to relieve the pain and prevent complications like necrosis, infection, or peritonitis.

OPTION C. Uterine artery embolization

Uterine artery embolization is used to treat symptomatic fibroids by reducing their size and blood supply. However, it is not appropriate for acute management of fibroid torsion, as it does not address the immediate issue of torsion or acute pain and can even exacerbate ischemia.

OPTION D. GnRH agonist therapy

GnRH agonists can shrink fibroids over time and are used for medical management of symptomatic fibroids, but they do not provide immediate relief and are ineffective in the emergency setting of fibroid torsion. They also do not address the risk of necrosis associated with torsion.

Type: Must know

Topic: Torsion of a fibroid

Reference: www.ncbi.com
