questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to your office with 24 hours of unilateral malodorous greenish rhinorrhea. His mother is concerned because the battery from her watch is missing. After you suction the nose, you see crusting on the septum. What should you do next?
questions.solution:
• This seems to be a case of foreign body impaction in nose (most probably, a disc battery)
  • Disc batteries require urgent removal or they can erode through mucosa and cartilage leading to septal perforation and further complication.
  • Washing nose can cause further chemical intoxication. (Option A)
  • Suctioning can cause dislodging of foreign body and aspiration. (Option C)
  • X ray would not yield any more information. (Option B)

Refeference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 510)

questions.text: A patient presented with back pain. On doing an examination, he was found to have an increased height above the normal and the upper limbs were long. What could be the cause of back pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the connective tissues of the body, resulting in abnormalities in multiple systems, including the skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular systems.

  1. Cardiovascular System
    • The most serious complications of Marfan syndrome involve the cardiovascular system, particularly the aorta.
    • Aortic Root Dilation / Aneurysm:
      • One of the hallmark features of Marfan syndrome is dilation of the aortic root. This can lead to aneurysm formation, typically at the sinuses of Valsalva.
      • Findings: Enlarged aortic root, often greater than 4 cm, with progressive dilation over time.
    • Aortic Dissection:
      • Marfan syndrome predisposes patients to aortic dissections, particularly type A dissection (involving the ascending aorta).
      • Findings: The characteristic appearance of an intimal flap separating the true and false lumen of the aorta.
  2. Skeletal System
    • Marfan syndrome is associated with various skeletal abnormalities due to the abnormal connective tissue. These can be easily identified on radiographs (X-rays), CT, or MRI.
    • Scoliosis:
      • X-ray: Shows abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, which is often severe in patients with Marfan syndrome.
    • Pectus Deformities: Pectus excavatum (sunken chest) or pectus carinatum (protruding chest) are common thoracic deformities.
      • X-ray or CT: Clearly shows the inward or outward deformation of the sternum and ribs.
    • Dolichostenomelia:
      • Refers to long, slender limbs, which are characteristic of Marfan syndrome.
      • X-ray: May reveal arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers) and excessive limb length relative to body height (increased arm span compared to height).
    • Protrusio Acetabuli:
      • The acetabulum (hip socket) is abnormally deep, allowing the femoral head to protrude into the pelvis.
      • X-ray or CT: Shows the inward bulging of the acetabulum and femoral head into the pelvic cavity.
  3. Ocular System
    • Findings: Displacement of the lens, often superior and temporal.
    • Dislocation or subluxation of the lens, a major diagnostic criterion.
    • Ectopia Lentis:
  4. Pulmonary System
    • Spontaneous Pneumothorax:
      • Marfan syndrome patients are at increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax due to apical blebs or bullae.
      • X-ray: May show evidence of a collapsed lung with air in the pleural space (pneumothorax).
      • CT: Can be more sensitive in detecting small blebs or bullae that predispose patients to pneumothorax.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1114.

questions.text: A 2.5 yr old Child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. Similar history was present in elder sibling a few days back. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Hand foot and mouth disease . Causative agents are Coxsackievirus A16 virus and enterovirus 71. It Presents with Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

Option B : Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum, present with asymptomatic papules with central umbilication.


Option C : Herpes virus manifests as

  • Herpes labialis
  • Herpetic gingivostomatitis
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Encephalitis
  • Eczema herpeticum

Option D : HPV virus manifest as Anogenital warts.

Key Takeaway: Hand Foot Mouth disease :

  • Etiology: Coxsackie A16, Enterovirus 71.
  • Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no 25.5

questions.text: Jennifer, a 29-year-old woman, gave birth to her first child one week ago. She has been experiencing mood swings, tearfulness, and irritability since the birth. She feels overwhelmed at times but is able to take care of herself and her baby. What is the most likely condition Jennifer is experiencing?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," is a common condition that affects many women after childbirth. It is characterized by mood swings, tearfulness, irritability, and feeling overwhelmed. However, women with postpartum blues are still able to function and care for themselves and their baby.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Postpartum depression: Postpartum depression is a more severe and persistent form of mood disturbance that may require pharmacological treatment.

Option B - Postpartum psychosis: Postpartum psychosis is a rare but serious condition characterized by hallucinations, delusions, and severe mood disturbances.

Option D - Postpartum anxiety disorder: Postpartum anxiety disorder involves excessive worry, restlessness, and fear, which are not the primary symptoms described in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is an ultra-long acting β2 agonist used in the management of asthma?
questions.solution:
Ultra-Long-Acting beta 2-Agonists

These agents (indacaterol, olodaterol, and vilanterol) have a 24-h effect. They are only used in combination with ICSs in the treatment of asthma

Classification of beta 2 agonists as per duration of action :

Short-Acting Beta-2 Agonists (SABAs)

  • Purpose: Quick relief of acute bronchospasm
  • Examples:
    • Albuterol (also known as salbutamol in some countries)
    • Levosalbutamol (also known as levalbuterol)
    • Terbutaline
    • Pirbuterol
  • Long-Acting Beta-2 Agonists (LABAs)
    • Purpose: Long-term control of asthma and COPD
    • Examples:
    • Salmeterol
    • Formoterol
    • Arformoterol
  • Ultra-Long-Acting Beta-2 Agonists (ULABAs)
    • Purpose: Extended control of symptoms with less frequent dosing
  • Examples:
    • Olodaterol
    • Indacaterol
    • Vilanterol

Options A,C : Salmeterol and Formoterol are long acting beta agonists.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2156

questions.text: After having an injury from rusted iron rod, Mukesh got vaccinated with tetanus vaccine. After a few days he complained of deep steady severe aching pain in shoulder and upper arm followed by weakness and wasting in arm and shoulder muscles of the hand on which he got the vaccine. Name the adverse event following immunisation?
questions.solution:
• Brachial neuritis: - Can be caused as an adverse event following tetanus vaccine. It involves dysfunction of nerves supplying the arm/shoulder without other involvement of nervous system. A deep steady, often severe aching pain in the shoulder and upper arm followed in days or weeks by weakness and wasting in arm/shoulder muscles.
  • Option A: Acute flaccid paralysis: - Can be caused as an adverse event following OPV vaccine. It involves acute onset of flaccid paralysis within 4-30 days of receipt of oral poliovirus (OPV), or within 4-75 days after contact with a vaccine recipient with isolation of vaccine virus and absence of wild polio virus in the stool, and neurological deficits remaining 60 days after onset, or death.
  • Option C: Injection site abscess: - Can be caused as an adverse event following all vaccines. It involves fluctuant or draining fluid filled lesion at the site of injection. Bacterial if evidence of infection (example purulent, inflammatory signs, fever, culture), sterile abscess if not.
  • Option D: Osteomyelitis: - Can be caused as an adverse event following BCG vaccine. It involves inflammation of the bone with isolation of mycobacterium bovis BCG strain.

Tag line: Difficult

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.126,127.

questions.text: Which of the following new drug has been approved for management of cystic fibrosis and acts by potentiating CFTR channel opening?
questions.solution:
Major effort directed toward high-throughput analysis of large compound libraries (including millions of individual agents) has identified effective new approaches to CF therapy. The first approved compound in this class, ivacaftor, robustly potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion trans- port. Ivacaftor overcomes the G551D CFTR gating defect, and individuals carrying this mutation exhibit pronounced improvement in lung function, weight gain, and other clinical benefit following oral therapy. Sweat chloride values are significantly reduced by the drug.

Lumacaftor and tezacaftor, two U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)- approved "corrector" molecules that repair CFTR misfolding (as distinct from CFTR gating "potentiators" such as ivacaftor)

Option A: Roflumilast is a medication used primarily in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Its mechanism of action involves the following:

  • Phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE4) Inhibition
  • Reduction in Inflammation
  • Improved Airway Function

Option B: Benralizumab is an anti IL-5 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of severe asthma, particularly in patients with eosinophilic asthma.

Option D: Risankizumab is an anti IL-23 monoclonal antibody used primarily in the treatment of moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2178

questions.text: A Stool specimen should be sent for microbiological analysis when Ulcerative Colitis is suspected in order to exclude the following organism except....
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus has nothing to do with ulcerative colitis

A stool specimen should be sent for microbiological analysis when UC is suspected in order to exclude infective colitides, notably Campylobacter, which may be very difficult to distinguish from acute severe UC. (option A)

Clostridium difficile colitis may need to be considered in populations at risk of this disease(option B)

Cytomegalovirus infection is a major pathogen in immunocompromised patients and can be difficult to distinguish from UC. Superimposed infection may precipitate fulminant colitis.(option C)

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 75 ; page 1321.

questions.text: Which antibiotic is recommended for the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections according to CDC guidelines?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is recommended for the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections according to CDC guidelines.

Mechanism of action -Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis of fungal cell wall .

Key Side Effects Mnemonic - ISONIAZID:

  • I: Increases liver enzymes (hepatotoxicity).
  • S: Seizures (can occur due to neurotoxicity).
  • O: Optic neuritis (rare side effect).
  • N: Neuropathy (peripheral neuropathy).
  • I: Interacts with other drugs (CYP enzyme interactions).
  • A: Anemia (aplastic anemia in rare cases).
  • Z: Zinc deficiency (rare).
  • I: Increased risk of rash or hypersensitivity.
  • D: Drug-induced lupus-like syndrome.

Prevention of Neuropathy:

  • "INH Prevents Neuropathy with B6": Remember that pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is recommended to prevent peripheral neuropathy caused by Isoniazid.

Explanation:

  1. Penicillin: Effective against many bacterial infections, but not used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  2. Vancomycin: Used for resistant Gram-positive infections, not for tuberculosis.
  3. Isoniazid: A first-line medication specifically recommended by CDC for treating tuberculosis.
  4. Doxycycline: A tetracycline antibiotic, not typically used for tuberculosis.

Key Takeaway: Isoniazid is a critical drug used in the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections as per CDC guidelines.

Tag Line: EASY

Reference: CDC Tuberculosis Guidelines. CDC - TB Treatment

questions.text: A 2 year old girl child presented with recurrent history of Dermatitis. She had blisters over face , hands and feet on sunlight exposure. Her clinical picture is like werewolves & discoloration of Teeth. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
2 year old girl child with clinical presentation of Dermatitis and werewolves like facial features is suggestive of Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria. It is autosomal Recessive disorder with deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen Synthase III. Child is having photosensitivity.


Option A) Porphyria Cutanea Tarda also leads to photo sensitivity, but more commonly seen in Adults and dental manifestation is not seen

Option C) Acute Intermittent Porphyria presents with neurovisceral symptoms after puberty. It presents with abdominal pain and psychosis with no cutaneous features.

Option D) Variegate Porphyria is due to deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen Oxidase, presents with photo sensitivity with neurological involvement and developmental delay.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition chapter 31 page 320

questions.text: Which is known for causing Johne's disease in cattle?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium paratuberculosis is known for causing Johne's disease in cattle, which is characterized by chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and eventually emaciation, despite a good appetite, eventually leading to granulomatous inflammation of the intestines, which interferes with nutrient absorption.

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Incorrect. This bacterium causes tuberculosis, not Johne's disease.
  • Mycobacterium leprae: Incorrect. This bacterium causes leprosy (Hansen's disease), not Johne's disease.
  • Mycobacterium paratuberculosis: Correct. Mycobacterium paratuberculosis is known as the causative agent of Johne's disease in cattle, and it is sometimes referred to as Johne's bacillus.
  • Mycobacterium kansasii: Incorrect. This species causes a pulmonary disease similar to tuberculosis, not Johne's disease.

Key Takeaway: Mycobacterium paratuberculosis is the mycobacterial species known for causing Johne's disease in cattle.

Tag line :Hard

Reference: Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Mycobacterium paratuberculosis." CDC Mycobacterium paratuberculosis Page. Accessed August 30, 2024

questions.text:
The resting membrane potential in a nerve is -70 mv. Equilibrium potential of different ions are mentioned below.

E Na+ = 60 mv
E Cl- = -90 mv
E K+ = -90 mv
E Ca++ = 125 mv
E Mg = 0 mv.

Which of the following ion is most important to develop resting membrane potential?
questions.solution:
• Resting Membrane Potential (RMP): The electrical potential difference across the membrane of a resting nerve cell, typically around -70 mV.
  • Equilibrium Potential (E) of an Ion: The membrane potential at which there is no net movement of a specific ion across the cell membrane.
  • The resting membrane potential is closest to the equilibrium potential for the ion with the highest permeability. Potassium ions are such ions with fastest permeability.
  • Option A: Sodium (Na+) has an equilibrium potential of +60 mV, which is far from the resting membrane potential of -70 mV. This means that if Na+ were the primary ion determining the RMP, the potential would be much more positive. Chloride (Cl-) has an equilibrium potential of -90 mV, which is closer to the RMP, but the membrane is much less permeable to Cl- at rest.
  • Option C: Magnesium (Mg²+) has an equilibrium potential of 0 mV, which is far from the RMP of -70 mV. Its concentration gradient is also minimal.
  • Option D: Calcium (Ca²+) has an equilibrium potential of +125 mV, which is much more positive than the RMP. This means if Ca²+ were the dominant ion, the membrane potential would be much higher.

References:

Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.38

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed page no 64-65

Topic: membrane potential

questions.text: A patient suffering from Rheumatoid Arthritis on Regular Methotrexate therapy presented with generalized weakness, lethargy, difficulty in Respiration. Investigation shows Low HB level. Bone Marrow histology shown in above image. Most Probable Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Drugs like Methotrexate inhibits Dihydro Folate Reductase enzyme which is used for conversion of Folic Acid into THF (Active Form).
  • Folic Acid Deficiency leads to megaloblastic Anemia caused by diminished synthesis of purine nucleotides and TMP.
  • Protein synthesis continues leading to accumulation of Hemoglobin in RBC , as large immature RBC Precursors as shown in Bone marrow histology.
  • So folic acid should be supplemented when the pt is on methotrexate.

Option B&C: Pernicious anemia is due to vitamin b12 deficiency most commonly caused by an autoimmune destruction of the gastric parietal cells that are responsible for the synthesis of IF. Lack of IF prevents Vitamin B12 absorption. So gastric Atrophy can leads to Vitamin b12 deficiency.

Option D: Heavy Metal poisoning like lead poisoning leads to Microcytic Anemia and not Macrocytic or Megaloblastic Anemia.

Reference: Biochemistry -Lippincott's Illustrated Review - SAE Chapter 32 Page 526

questions.text: Which of the following distinguishes Lichen Planus from Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Lichen Planus:

  • Hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, wedge-shaped hyper granulosis, saw toothing of rete ridges, band-like lymph histiocytic infiltrate obscuring the dermo epidermal junction.
  • Civatte bodies (apoptotic basal keratinocytes, PAS+)
  • Basal cell degeneration (flattening of cells)
  • Parakeratosis: generally absent

Psoriasis:

  • Regular acanthosis, often with elongated rete (psoriasiform)
  • Alternating zones of hypo and hyper granulosis in the epidermis
  • Thinning of the suprapapillary plates
  • Areas of parakeratosis in the stratum corneum with mounds of neutrophils (Munro micro abscesses)
  • Perivascular, predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate in the upper and middle portions of the dermis; few neutrophils or eosinophils may be seen
  • Collections of neutrophils in the spinosum (Spongiform pustules of Kogoj)

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1158.

choices.text: Filarial worms are transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated food and water.
Lymphatic filariasis is primarily caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi and leads to elephantiasis.
Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, is caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and transmitted by sandflies.
Filarial infections are primarily treated with antibiotics such as doxycycline and are not usually treated with antiparasitic medications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about filarial infections is correct?
questions.solution:
Transmission: Spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes (mainly Culex, Anopheles, and Aedes species).

Life Cycle:

  • Mosquito injects infective larvae (L3 stage) into the human host during a blood meal.
  • Larvae migrate to the lymphatic system where they mature into adult worms.
  • Adult worms can live for years, producing microfilariae (immature larvae) that circulate in the bloodstream.
  • Mosquitoes ingest microfilariae during subsequent bites, continuing the cycle.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Asymptomatic phase: Many infected individuals show no immediate symptoms but can still have microfilariae in the blood.
  • Acute phase: Characterized by episodes of lymphangitis (inflammation of lymphatic vessels), fever, and chills.
  • Chronic phase:
    • Lymphedema: Swelling of the limbs, breast, or genitals due to impaired lymphatic drainage.
    • Elephantiasis: Severe thickening and hardening of the skin and underlying tissues, most commonly affecting the legs, arms, and genitalia.
    • Hydrocele: Swelling of the scrotum, a common complication in men.

Pathogenesis:

  • Adult worms lodge in the lymphatic vessels, causing chronic inflammation and obstruction of lymphatic drainage.
  • This leads to tissue swelling, fibrosis, and permanent damage to the lymphatic system, resulting in lymphedema and elephantiasis.

Diagnosis:

  • Blood smear: Detection of microfilariae in a blood sample, typically collected at night when they are most abundant.
  • Antigen detection tests: Useful for detecting adult worm antigens in the blood, particularly in chronic infections.
  • Ultrasound: Can detect the movement of adult worms ("filarial dance sign") in lymphatic vessels.

Treatment:

  • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC): The drug of choice, effective against microfilariae and adult worms.
  • Albendazole and Ivermectin: Often used in combination with DEC for mass drug administration (MDA) programs.
  • Supportive care: Includes hygiene, exercise, and elevation of the affected limbs to manage lymphedema and prevent progression.

No nuclei at TIP

  1. Filarial worms are transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated food and water: Incorrect. Filarial worms are transmitted by insect vectors, not through contaminated food and water.
  2. Lymphatic filariasis is primarily caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi and leads to elephantiasis: Correct. These filarial worms cause lymphatic filariasis, which can lead to severe swelling and elephantiasis.
  3. Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, is caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and transmitted by sandflies: Incorrect. Onchocerciasis is caused by Onchocerca volvulus and is transmitted by blackflies, not sandflies. Ancylostoma duodenale causes hookworm infections.
  4. Filarial infections are primarily treated with antibiotics such as doxycycline and are not usually treated with antiparasitic medications: Incorrect. While doxycycline is used in some filarial infections, antiparasitic medications like ivermectin and albendazole are primarily used to treat filarial infections.

Key Takeaway: Lymphatic filariasis, a common filarial infection, is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi and can lead to severe conditions like elephantiasis.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). "Filarial Infections." CDC Filarial Infections Page. Accessed August 30, 2024.

questions.text: 10 year old boy presented with history of excessive urination, hunger and excessive thirst since 4 days. He had developed Nausea, Vomiting since 01 day with increasing weakness and lethargy. His blood reports shows Blood Sugar level -419mg/dl, Urine Ketone - ++. questions.text: The picture given below is process which is followed by ASHA under a national program. Identify the process and the program under which it is implemented?
questions.solution:
• WHO STEP-wise approach to NCD risk factor surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method for collecting, analysing and disseminating data on key NCD risk factors in countries. It is commonly used for survey under the NPNCD program.
  • The survey instrument covers key behavioral risk factors: tobacco use, alcohol use, physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, as well as key biological risk factors: overweight and obesity, raised blood pressure, raised blood glucose, and abnormal blood lipids.
  • The STEPS instrument is comprised of three different levels or "steps" of risk factor assessment: Step 1 (questionnaire), Step 2 (physical measures) and Step 3 (biochemical measures).

Tag line: - Difficult

Reference: - WHO STEP wise approach to NCD risk factor surveillance (STEPS).

questions.text: Which of the following tests measures ratio of weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in determination of whether the baby was born alive or not?
questions.solution:
The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in the determination of whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet's test.

Plocquet's test: It is based on the ratio of weight of lungs to whole body weight, a respired lung weighs 1/35 of the body weight.

  • Option A: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test: It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration. On breathing, the volume of the lungs is increased, which more than compensates for the weight of additional blood, due to which specific gravity is diminished. Hence, after respiration, the lung floats in water.
  • Option C: Breslau's second life test: It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live born child and detecting the presence of this air in stomach constitutes the basis for this test.
  • Option D: Wredin's test: Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue, not air. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and air replaces the gelatinous substances in a few hours to five weeks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS--The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in the determination of whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet’s test.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 34th Edition - page no: 340, 341, 342

questions.text: A 63 year old male with past history of smoking for the past 20 years presents to medicine department with an acute onset of left-sided chest pain radiating down the left arm with profuse sweating. An immediate ECG was performed in the emergency room which revealed a ST-segment elevation in leads V4-V6. A decision was taken to immediately thrombolyse the patient. For the purpose of pharmacological thrombolysis, 30 mg of streptokinase was infused intravenously. The immediate plasma concentration of streptokinase was measured to be 0.6 mg/dL. What is the volume of distribution of streptokinase in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Vd = Dose administered (I.V.) / Plasma concentration

Dose administered = 30 mg

Plasma concentration = 0.6 mg/dl

Vd = 30 mg / 0.6 mg/dl

= 50 dl

= 5 L

  • Volume of distribution (Vd)
    • It is the volume that would be required to contain the administered dose if that dose was evenly distributed at the concentration measured in plasma.
    • If more amount of drug is entering the tissues, it has a higher volume of distribution and vice-a-versa.
    • It depends on several factors like lipid solubility and plasma protein binding.
    • Drugs which are lipid soluble are more likely to cross the blood vessel wall and thus have high volume of distribution.
    • If a drug is highly bound to plasma proteins, (g., warfarin, benzodiazepines, furosemide, calcium channel blockers, digitoxin etc.) it will behave like a large molecule and more likely to stay in the plasma. Therefore, less will go to tissues resulting in reduced volume of distribution
    • The volume of distribution (Vd) is calculated by dividing the total amount of the drug in the body by its plasma concentration.
    • Vd = Dose administered (I.V.) / Plasma concentration
  • Factors governing volume of drug distribution
    • Lipid: water partition coefficient of the drug
    • pKa value of the drug
    • Degree of plasma protein binding
    • Affinity for different tissues
    • Fat: lean body mass ratio, which can vary with age, sex, obesity, etc.
    • Diseases like CHF, uremia, cirrhosis

questions.text: The graph shown below picturizes the relation between GFR and renal blood flow in healthy person. If the haematocrit is 50 %. What is the filtration fraction at mean arterial pressure of 120 mm hg?
questions.solution:
• To calculate the filtration fraction (FF), we use the following formula:
  • Filtration fraction = GFR/ RPF (Renal plasma flow)
  • GFR= 0.1 L/min =100ml/min
  • Hematocrit is 50 % means it is 0.5
  • RPF= RBF/ (1- hematocrit) = 1 / (1-0.5) =0.5 L/min.
  • FF = 1.0/0.5 =0.2
  • Option a, c and d are not true from the above calculation.

Tag: Glomerular filtration

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology 26th edition pg no. 1556

questions.text: Which of the following causes decrease in cytoplasmic calcium level preceding relaxation in cardiac muscles?
questions.solution:
• For cardiac muscle relaxation Ca++ should fall rapidly in the sarcoplasm. It is done by active transport mechanism.
  • Option a: The SERCA pump is the primary mechanism responsible for rapidly decreasing cytoplasmic calcium levels in cardiac muscle cells. After a contraction, the SERCA pump actively transports calcium ions from the cytoplasm back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), where calcium is stored.
  • Option b: The Na+/Ca++ exchangers is a membrane transport protein that removes calcium from the cytoplasm by exchanging it for sodium ions across the cell membrane. While Na+/Ca++ exchangers does help in reducing cytoplasmic calcium levels. It is driven by the energy stored in the Na+ electrochemical gradient.
  • Option c: Ca++ ATPase pump is another membrane pump that expels calcium from the cytoplasm to the extracellular space, using ATP.
  • Option d: All mentioned above options are true. It is the correct answer.

Tag: Cardiac muscle

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology 26th edition pg no. 149

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with criminal responsibility in mental illness?
questions.solution:
Nysten's rule is not associated with insanity, it describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death.

It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

Muscles are affected in the following order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart (left chamber of the heart is affected first).
  2. Eyelids.
  3. Neck and lower jaw.
  4. Face.
  5. Chest.
  6. Upper extremities.
  7. Abdomen.
  8. Legs.

Incorrect Options -

  • Option A -Durham's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.
  • Option B -Curren's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Option D -The American Law Institute test states that a person is not responsible for criminal conduct if, at the time of such conduct, as a result of mental disease or defect, he lacks adequate capacity either to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust his conduct to the requirements of the law.

Other such tests include:

  • Mc Naughten rule, also called the right or wrong test.
  • The irresistible impulse test, also called as New Hampshire Doctrine.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death

Reference - The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 494

questions.text: A 56 year old hypertensive female patient came to medicine department seeking treatment for diabetes mellitus. She was prescribed insulin to treat her diabetes. Which amongst the following drug is to be used with extra caution and appropriate advice should be given to the patient taking insulin?
questions.solution:
• Propranolol, as well as other nonselective beta blockers, tends to slow the rate of recovery in a hypoglycemic attack caused by insulin.
  • Beta blockers also mask the symptoms of hypoglycemia and may actually cause hypertension because of the increased plasma epinephrine in the presence of a vascular β2 blockade.
  • Propranolol delays recovery from hypoglycaemia due to insulin and oral antidiabetics.
  • Warning signs of hypoglycaemia mediated through sympathetic stimulation (tachycardia, tremor) are suppressed.

Limitations of Non-selective β-Blockers

  1. Contraindicated in bronchial asthma due to their bronchoconstrictor action.
  2. Hypoglycemia is commonly observed in diabetic patients receiving insulin and oral hypoglycemic drugs.
    • Symptoms of hypoglycemia (like tachycardia, sweating and tremors) are due to sympathetic stimulation that act as warning signs for the patient.
    • Beta blockers mask these symptoms (except sweating because it is mediated by sympathetic cholinergic system) and patient can go directly into coma.
    • Further, these agents delay the recovery from hypoglycemia due to inhibition of β2 mediated hyperglycemia. These drugs are therefore contraindicated in diabetic Patients.
  3. On long term use non selective β blockers can adversely affect serum lipid profile and can cause glucose intolerance.
  4. By causing vasoconstriction (β2 is vasodilatory), these drugs can worsen peripheral vascular disease (contraindicated in Raynaud's disease).
  5. These drugs can impair exercise capacity due to blockade of skeletal vascular β2 receptors.
    • Contraindication of propranolol (Mnemonic = ABCD)
      • A= Asthma
      • B = AV block
      • C = CHF
      • D = Diabetes

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 160-161

questions.text: Identify the concept given in the picture below
questions.solution:
• Rule of halves: - Hypertension is an iceberg disease. It became evident that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition, only about half of those aware of the problem were being treated, and only about half of those treated were considered adequately treated.
  • Iceberg phenomenon: - According to the iceberg phenomenon, disease in a community may be compared with an iceberg. The floating tip of an iceberg represents what the physician sees in the community i.e. clinical cases. The vast submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of disease i.e. latent, inapparent, presymptomatic and undiagnosed cases and carriers in the community. The waterline represents the demarcation between apparent and inapparent disease.
  • Tracking of blood pressure: - If blood pressure levels of individuals were followed up over a period of years from early childhood into adult life, then those individuals whose pressures were initially high in the distribution, would probably continue in the same track as adults. In other words, low blood pressure levels tend to remain low, and high levels tend to become higher as individual grow older. This phenomenon of the persistence of rank order of blood pressure has been described as tracking.

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.426.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy experiences severe pain in the right leg after performing a gymnastic floor exercise. On physical examination, there is marked pain on palpation of the right lower thigh just above the knee. Radiographs show a pathologic fracture across a discrete, 3-cm lower femoral diaphyseal lesion that has central lucency with a thin sclerotic rim. The lesion is completely intramedullary and well circumscribed. A bone biopsy specimen of the affected region shows trabeculae of woven bone scattered in a background of fibroblastic proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. This patient has a single focus of fibrous dysplasia.
    • This benign tumor-like condition is uncommon.
    • The histologic appearance of woven bone in the middle of benign-looking fibroblasts is characteristic.
    • Seventy percent of cases are monostotic, and the ribs, femur, tibia, mandible, and calvaria are the most frequent sites of involvement.
    • Local deformity and, occasionally, fracture can occur. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia may involve craniofacial, pelvic, and shoulder girdle regions, leading to severe deformity and fracture.
  2. An enchondroma typically appears in more distal bones and is composed of
  3. Ewing sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphyseal region of the long bones and is identified histologically by sheets of small, round cells.
  4. An osteoid osteoma has a small central nidus with surrounding sclerosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1195.

questions.text: What is a primary diagnostic tool for identifying Aspergillus infections according to CDC guidelines?
questions.solution:
The serum galactomannan test is used to detect galactomannan, a polysaccharide component of the cell wall of Aspergillus species.

It is primarily used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., those with neutropenia, hematologic malignancies, or organ transplants).

  • A. Blood culture: Not typically used for diagnosing Aspergillus infections; fungal cultures are more common for this purpose.
  • B. MRI scan: Useful for imaging but not specific for diagnosing Aspergillus infections.
  • C. Chest X-ray: May show signs of infection but is not specific for Aspergillus.
  • D. Serum galactomannan test: A diagnostic test specifically used to detect Aspergillus infections, especially in immunocompromised patients.

Key Takeaway: The serum galactomannan test is a key diagnostic tool for detecting Aspergillus infections, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems.

Reference: CDC Aspergillus. CDC - Aspergillus

questions.text: As shown in above image, there is excessive deposition of Cholesterol around Tonsils. Patient presented with Hepatosplenomegaly, Peripheral Neuropathy and HDL level less than 5 mg/dl. Mutation of which is responsible for this Autosomal Recessive Condition in above patient?
questions.solution:
In given clinical case scenario, Low HDL level, Deposition of Cholesterol around Tonsils and autosomal recessive condition is more likely suggestive of Tangiers' Disease. In which there is mutation of Gene ABCA1 - ATP binding Cassette protein. The Efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells is mediated primary by ABCA1. In Tangier's Disease virtual absence of HDL particles due to degradation of Lipid Poor apo A1.


Option A) CETP - It transfers cholesteryl esters from HDL to VLDL in exchange for TAG relieving product inhibition of LCAT.

Option B) Cholesterol taken up by HDL is immediately esterified by the Plasma enzyme Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase.

Option C) Cholesteryl Ester uptake by the liver is mediated by the cell surface receptor SR - B1 (Scavenger Receptor Class B 1) that binds HDL.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 23 page 360

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of some mineral dust exposure presents with progressive shortness of breath and bilateral lung crackles. Chest imaging shows bilateral pleural thickening and interstitial fibrosis. Lung biopsy reveals:


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This a picture of Asbestos body revealing typical beading and knobbed ends.
  • It consists of a central asbestos fiber coated with iron-rich protein material, typically iron and protein from the surrounding lung tissue. This coating gives the appearance of a golden-brown or yellow-brown color under light microscopy.
  • History, clinical symptoms and radiological findings also favors diagnosis of Asbestosis. (option B)

Option A , C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A73 year old patient has heart failure that has worsened over the past 12 months. Which of the following drugs is likely to slow progression even though it has no direct positive or negative effects on cardiac contractility?
questions.solution:
• Losartan, an AT1 angiotensin receptor antagonist, has been shown to slow the progression of heart failure, in common with the ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, and spironolactone, which also slow progression of this disease.
  • ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
    • These drugs are indicated in all grade of Congestive heart failure unless contra-indicated. These can decrease mortality in CHF.
    • These decrease the mortality via prevention and reversal of cardiac remodeling due to aldosterone (final mediator of remodeling).
    • ACE inhibitors cause both arteriolar and venodilatation in Congestive heart failure patients; reduce afterload as well as preload on heart and improve all haemodynamic parameters.
    • ACE inhibitors reduce episodes of decompensation, myocardial infarction and sudden death.
    • Long term benefits of ACE inhibitors accrue from withdrawal of Angiotensin II mediated ventricular hypertrophy, remodeling, accelerated myocyte apoptosis and fibrosis.
    • Indirect benefits occur due to reduction in sympathetic activation and aldosterone levels. Also causes natriuresis
  • These drugs decrease mortality in Congestive heart failure
    • Beta Blockers
    • ACE inhibitors
    • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
    • Aldosterone Antagonists

Option A & B: Positive inotropic agents such as digoxin and dobutamine do not slow progression although they may be useful for reducing symptoms.

Option D: Nesiritide is a peptide that causes vasodilation and sodium diuresis and may have value in acute but not chronic failure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 531

questions.text:
Due to sudden collapse of a multistorey building high number of casualties are reported. In field there are high number of casualties according to the triage rules arrange the sequence of following patients on the basis of priority given?
a) Patient having severe respiratory distress.
b) Patient who needs suture over minor injuries.
c) Patient with gunshot wound to abdomen with stable vital signs.
d) Patient who is not responding and found dead.
questions.solution:
The concept of first come, first treated, is not adopted during mass emergencies, instead triage is followed, triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical interventions. In triage internationally accepted four colour code system according to the priority is given as:

  1. RED indicates high priority treatment or transfer. This category requires immediate medical or surgical treatment.
  2. YELLOW indicates medium priority. This patient can survive without treatment for 6-24 hours
  3. GREEN indicates ambulatory patients with no life-threatening injuries and who needs only dressings or stitches.
  4. BLACK indicates dead or moribund patients.

In war like situations REVERSE TRIAGE is used where the priority sequence is GREEN>YELLOW>RED>BLACK, so that the less injured can again return to war.

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.923.

choices.text: It recognizes flagellin in bacterial flagella
It mediates the response to microbial proteins

questions.text: Which of the following is true about TLR4?
questions.solution:
• TLRs recognize and respond to the molecular patterns expressed by pathogens.
  • Various Toll like receptors (TLRs) present in humans are involved in following mechanisms
  • TLR4 - TLR4 is a pattern recognition receptor (PRR) that plays a crucial role in the innate immune response by recognizing lipopolysaccharide (LPS).
    • It binds bacterial lipopolysaccharide and a protein called CD14, and this initiates intracellular events that activate transcription of genes for a variety of proteins involved in innate immune responses.
  • TLR2 - mediates the response to microbial lipoproteins.
  • TLR6 - cooperates with TLR2 in recognizing certain peptidoglycans.
  • TLR5 - recognizes a molecule known as flagellin in bacterial flagellae.
  • TLR9 - recognizes bacterial DNA.

Topic: Immunity

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.178

questions.text: A 54 years old patient presented with repeated vomiting, lethargy and hypoglycemia. He had history of eating unripe Ackee fruits. Laboratory investigations reveals high amount of medium chain fatty acid in urine. Identify the correct sentence mentioning biochemical basis behind this metabolic disorder.

Above case scenario with history of Ingestion of Ackee fruit and repeated vomiting, hypoglycemia is suggestive of Jamaican Vomiting Sickness. Ackee fruit contains Hypoglycin A substance which inactivates Acetyl Co A Dehydrogenase & Beta Oxidation leading to hypoglycemia and excessive short and Medium chain Fatty acid levels.

Option A Toxin present in Ackee fruit is responsible for patient’s condition. No diarrhea, abdominal pain along with presence of Medium Chain Fatty Acid in urine is more likely to have diagnosis related to Jamaican Vomiting Sickness.

Option C Hypoglycin A impairs activity of Acetyl Co a Dehydrogenase which is responsible for Hypoglycemia.

Option D There is no excessive production of Insulin.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 23 page 225

choices.text: Fever and cough with sore throat

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Weil's disease, a severe form of leptospirosis?
questions.solution:
Weil's Disease: Severe form of leptospirosis characterized by jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, and sometimes pulmonary hemorrhage.


  • A. Skin rash and joint pain: Incorrect. While some forms of leptospirosis can cause skin rash and joint pain, these are not the primary features of Weil's disease.
  • B. Jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage: Correct. Weil's disease is a severe form of leptospirosis characterized by jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage. It is a potentially life-threatening condition that can lead to multi-organ involvement.
  • C. Fever and cough with sore throat: Incorrect. These symptoms are more characteristic of upper respiratory infections rather than Weil's disease.
  • D. Neck stiffness and photophobia: Incorrect. These symptoms are indicative of meningitis rather than Weil's disease.

Key Takeaway: Weil's disease is a severe manifestation of leptospirosis with hallmark features including jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO). "Leptospirosis: Clinical Presentation and Management." WHO Leptospirosis Page. Accessed August 30, 2024.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female undergoes thyroidectomy for thyroid nodule. Histopathological examination reveals:

1. Encapsulated tumor with follicular architecture
2. Cells with normochromasia and inconspicuous nucleoli
3. No papillary or psammomatous structures

Which of the following feature, if present in this patient can lead to malignant transformation of this tumor?
questions.solution:
• From the histopathological findings of Encapsulated with follicular architecture and Cells with normochromasia and inconspicuous nucleoli, this a Benign thyroid tumor Follicular adenoma.
  • B. Follicular carcinoma: Diagnosed by presence of capsular and/or vascular invasion.
    • Careful evaluation of integrity of the capsule is critical in distinguishing follicular adenoma from follicular carcinoma.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1086.

questions.text: A 52 year old man was found to have total cholesterol of 380 mg/dL and triglycerides of 230 mg/dL. The man had been suffering from hemophilia since birth and from external haemorrhoids for 2 years. An antihyperlipidemic therapy was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cholestyramine can cause severe constipation and is therefore contraindicated in patients with hemorrhoids.
  • In addition, the drug is contraindicated in patients with any coagulation defect because it decreases the intestinal absorption of vitamin K.
  • Bile Acid Sequestrants (Resins)
    • Cholestyramine
    • Colestipol
    • Colesevelam
  • They are neither digested nor absorbed in the gut: bind bile acids in the intestine interrupting their enterohepatic circulation.
  • Faecal excretion of bile salts and CH (which is absorbed with the help of bile salts) is increased.
  • This indirectly leads to enhanced hepatic metabolism of CH to bile acids.
  • Resins have been shown to retard atherosclerosis and coronary events, but no significant effect on total mortality.
  • They are not popular clinically because they are unpalatable, inconvenient, have to be taken in large doses, cause flatulence and other GI symptoms, interfere with absorption of many drugs (Vitamin K) and have poor patient acceptability

Option A, C & D: All other options are not associated with Vitamin K functions hence not contraindicated in patient with hemophilia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 686-687

questions.text: Confounding is not an error in the study, but rather is true phenomenon that is identified in a study and must be understood. There are various approaches for dealing with confounding. Which of the following approaches can handle confounding at the design stage of the study?
questions.solution:
• In a study whether exposure A is a cause of disease B, we say that a third factor, factor X is a confounder if factor X is a known risk factor for disease B and factor X is associated with exposure A but is not a result of exposure A.
  • The issue of confounding can be addressed either in designing and carrying out a study or in analysis of the data.
  • In designing and carrying out a study stage approaches that can handle confounding are individual matching and group matching.
  • In the analysis stage the approaches that can handle confounding are stratification and adjustment.

Reference: - Gordis Epidemiology 6th/e page no. 296.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast, ER-positive, PR-positive, HER2-negative, Ki-67 index: 20%. What is the molecular subtype of this breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Molecular subtypes of breast cancer:


  1. Luminal A: ER-positive, PR-positive, HER2-negative, low Ki-67 index (<20%)
  2. Luminal B: ER-positive, PR-positive, HER2-positive or negative, higher Ki-67 index (≥20%)
  3. Triple-negative: ER-negative, PR-negative, HER2-negative
  4. HER2-enriched: ER-negative, PR-negative, HER2-positive

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1050.

choices.text: It is chemically related to methysergide
It is safe for use in pregnancy

questions.text: Which amongst the following statement about ergotamine is true?
questions.solution:
• Ergotamine is a powerful Alpha-adrenoreceptor blocker, related to methysergide
  • Repeated administration of high doses may cause ergotism with gangrene and confusion.
  • It causes post-partum contraction of the uterus. Pleural and peritoneal fibrosis may occur, as with methysergide.
  • Ergot Alkaloids
    • These are derived from a fungus Claviceps purpurea.
    • Important compounds are
    • Ergotamine,
    • Ergometrine (ergonovine),
    • Ergotoxine,
    • Bromocriptine,
    • Dihydroergotamine
    • Methysergide.
  • These drugs possess partial agonistic and antagonistic effect at 5HT, α and dopaminergic receptors.
  • Ergot derivatives can cause dry gangrene of hand and feet as well as coronary vasospasm.
    • Ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are used for the treatment of acute attack of migraine.
  • These are contraindicated in patients with ischemic heart disease (due to their propensity to cause coronary vasospasm).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 191

questions.text: A cattleman got an injury over foot while working in the field. 2 weeks after this injury he came to the OPD with the complaint of fever with chills and headache. The disease resembled like influenza fever, but you had a doubt of zoonotic disease due to his close association with the cattle. Identify the disease and the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Q-fever is a highly infectious zoonotic disease with World-wide distribution. It occurs mainly in persons associated with sheep, goats, cattle or other domestic animals.

The causative agent is Coxiella burnetti. It can be transmitted by inhalation of infected dust from soil previously contaminated by urine or faeces of diseases animals or by direct entry into the body through abrasions or ingestion of contaminated foods such as meat, milk and milk products. Its incubation period is usually 2-3 weeks.

Option A: Trench fever is limited to central Europe. The vector is louse and the disease is transmitted by louse faeces. Man is the only known reservoir.

Option C: Man gets rickettsial pox through the bite of certain infected mites, which are found on the mice. Transovarian transmission occurs in the mite. The mouse acts as true reservoir as well as vector.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei) the patient basically complains of itching which is worse at night.

Reference: - Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.348.
